GAME: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition)
RANK: 46
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Would be the best game ever if only it were fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[Vote and comment refer to the standard game, without variants of any sort]
This game gives you everything you need to bring a great space saga on your table, however TI3 also offers a set of rules that in the end don't seem very well rounded, needing that last tweak or two to "click" properly. 
A role selection model is functional if, depending on the situation, each and every role can become your best choice. That doesn't seem to be the case with TI3: having to choose a specific role (Imperial) every round or another specific one (Initiative) whenever the former isn't available is not metagaming, it's an engine that you have to kick every round to make it work properly.
The balance among the strategy cards can also become a matter of debate, even considering the difficulties of trying to put together such a variety of contexts (commerce, political options, technological advancements).
Playing time is too long and that, of course, is not a fault of the game per se, it's me (you have to rule over an entire galaxy, for Pete's sake, what was I thinking?). The objectives usually support the enforcing of your position without leading to open conflict, with a "cold War" feel that doesn't really fit with my idea of space combat. Please, use at least the Age of Empire variant, unless you want to wander pointlessly around the galaxy while you wait to know what can make you win the game.
The command counters system has its own issues: production is coupled with movement, transfer actions are limited to two systems, the fact that command counters need their own economy adds much more problems than the ones they solve, not to mention the strange mix of aspects that they try to put together. I've decided to sell my goods and study some kind of new scientific gizmo, so I can't move my ships. REALLY?
Other minor complaints include the balance of some units and the overall "patchwork" feel of the rules, which of course can be a minor flaw as long as everything works properly, but still makes the learning curve quite steep.
On the other hand, if you're looking for an immersive experience, TI3 it's really up to the task with its (albeit sporadic) space battles, a complex technology tree, a bit of political role-playing, space exploration and almost everything else you could expect. 
Most of all, it's like a space-opera kit that you can use to tailor the game to your tastes, and somewhere in there you could probably find your favourite, mind-blowing, don't-call-us-for-the-next-few-hours space civilization game. The Shattered Empire rulebook is definitely worth a look, because some of its tweaks are easily applicable to the base game even without the extra bits.

The box, the amount of bits and cards, the table you need to keep everything at hand and, of course, the hole in your wallet (made even worse if you consider the expansion): everything about this game seems to be huge. Huge props to FFG's customer service: I got a couple of badly molded units and they took care of the substitution quickly and for free, even if I'm on the other side of the pond. Great overall graphics for a very well implemented theme. 
Good rulebook.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My initial thoughts after one game:

There is a lot to like about TI3. The components are awesome, the scope is enormous, the sheer amount of decisions and options is insane. That being said, after 1.5 hours of rules and 6 hours of gameplay, I didn’t feel like I did much of anything.

I was never able to move more than 2-3 tiles away from my home system. It would take two whole rounds (or three!) to really move your fleet, which is to say, 2-3 hours of game time. I was involved in only a couple battles, during which my entire fleet was wiped out. Except in one case where my wife destroyed another player in a battle, war seemed to cripple both players rather than help the winner advance – meaning it was more trouble than it was worth. 

The downtime also increased exponentially with each hour of the game. At one point near the end I went over 30 minutes without being involved in the game at all. Also, scoring VP is kind of baffling. I don’t think anyone had a realistic Secret Objective they could achieve (all had to do with controlling a laughable number of planets and/or Mecatol Rex) and the ISP was only chosen sporadically, so Public Objectives didn’t really come out until hours 4, 5 and 6.

The sheer length of the game is troubling considering that it takes so long to do anything. I suppose I should have researched it more, but I thought with the high rating on BGG and it being a 6-8 hour game that you would be doing a ton of stuff in an epic space opera. In reality it felt more like Sid Meier's Civilization, the board game, in space (a game I'd be content never to play again). I own and have played Empires of the Void several times, and I feel like I do much more in that game in a total game time of two hours than I ever felt in 6+ hours of TI3.

And yet, despite my misgivings, I have spent a lot of time thinking about the game in the days since. It looks like the expansion and variants like Age of Empires fixes most of the issues I have with it (the snail’s pace at the beginning, limited chances for VP, rewards turtling over warfare). I would try it again, but I would prefer to do so using a variant that fixes some of the base game’s many issues.

RATING: 9.7
Very good space empire game. Always willing to play and wanting to get people together to play a game. Sometimes I like to use a few variants to try to shorten game time. This monster of a game takes good planning to get to the table, but it is oh so satisfying...

As a long time fan of Master of Orion II and other civilization games and sci-fi games, the theme for this one is perfect for me. It's my "monster game" of choice.

I like this endgame variant:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/358579/an-easy-victory-variant-2nd-edition-style-twilig

but I'm thinking about changing benefits to:
stage II: tech cost -1, +1 yield for each trade contract
stage III: tech cost -1, +1 fleet supply limit, free tech
stage IV: tech cost -2, +1 yield from trade contracts

---

Tried it, but actually hope I hadn't. It confirmed (or even exceeded) all the doubts I had.

Awful, awful game, borderline broken. Long, tedious, random and boring. Ridiculous components, fiddly and messy gameplay - "do this to do that to get what you actually wanted to do done about three turns (and hours) later.. or maybe not at all." 

It looks like it wants to be coolest game of all time, but actually could not be further from it. I do like civilization and empire building games, but this is not really one, despite appearances.. It's actually hard to say what it in fact is, except utter waste of time and money.

RATING: 9
The most epic boardgame out there. Very competitive and a pure wargame in heart. Very different from eclipse in that respect (eclipse is more about management development economy and planning). It leaves a sense of epicness, and glorious memories, as long as it is played by people who appreciate roleplaying, gaming, complicated rules, and can devote 1-2 hours per player. I advise playing with 4 or more players to feel the galactic senate and competition better. 4 player games preserve the games feel, and can take 4 hours with a trained group, something you could pull even weekly with a dedicated group.

RATING: 9.25
The Daddy. I see no other game coming close to the epic feel of TI3. It's really amazing that a game with such long play times and player turns can always remain engaging and interesting. It's a testament to the design that I never feel bored while playing, even if I'm sitting there for five minutes until my next turn. There's always planning to be done, motivations to be determined, techs to research, tactical movements to be laid out, and devious machinations to undertake. It's always a tense and surprising game that always retains the same epic feel, while remaining unpredictable and different every time.

RATING: 6.5
The basic game falls short of its potential due to 'over-simplified' politics, trade and technology rules and unbalanced 'strategy cards'.

The expansion fixes many of the 'base game' drawbacks whilst adding [unnecessary] 7 & 8 player option.

The wider community have designed numerous rules modifications, the most comprehensive being 'Shattered Ascension V4' [http://ti3wiki.org/forum/YaBB.pl?board=CommunityVariants].

I'm currently looking for a good set of 'Exploration' type rules if anyone has any suggestions/links?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
*Rating based on one play.

TI3 was on my gaming "bucket list", a list of well-regarded or popular games that I want to play at least once.  Now that I've crossed TI3 off that list, I'm not sure that I'll ever return to it.  It's not that I disliked TI3, it's just not a game in my wheelhouse.  TI3 is a long, heavily thematic and interactive game, while I prefer shorter, multiplayer solitaire style Eurogames.

Putting genre biases aside (as much as possible), what did I think of TI3?  I would have to say it is one of the better "dudes on a map" games I have played, head and shoulders above the likes of Risk or Axis and Allies.  I like that you have means of being peaceful in the game (though I think winning is impossible if you don't take the gloves off at some point), and I like that players can interact in non-military ways, through trade and politics.  I like the technology tree system, though I would have liked to see each species have its own tree.  The graphics and bits are all quality, though the graphical design of the rulebook shows its age.

I like that the game's end goal is objective-based, and not simply "eliminate all opponents".  That said, I'm not sure I like how the objectives are handled in the game.  In my one play, I found I was usually able to score an objective the turn after it came up.  I even scored my personal, secret objective fairly early, which may have been a rookie mistake as it painted a big bullseye on my head.  When an objective came up that didn't seem achievable, I was left in a sort of holding pattern, not really having a clear direction to go.  When the next objective that came up was simply a more difficult version of the previous, I again felt directionless.  The galaxy was so crowded at that point that any attempt at territorial gains would result in a swift counterattack and could have left me open to losing much of my empire, so the game devolved into a sort of trench warfare where I was simply trying to maintain my borders and hoping the next objective to come up would be achievable.  It made the last third of the game an uninteresting slog.  Even the other players seemed relieved when the game finally ended after some 8 hours.

In the end, I'm glad to have experienced the game, but I don't know that I'll ever come back to it.  I've rated it a 6 as it is a mechanically solid game with a lot of things to like about it, and if it played in just an hour or two, I'd be willing to play it again.  But as an all-day kind of game, I'm not sure I'd want to come back to it.  It's just not my cup of tea.

RATING: 6.60666
We clubbed together to buy this for our group.
It's definitely vastly superior to 2nd Ed in my opinion, and I do enjoy the game more since it became more about diplomacy than piles of cruisers. Managing the counter balance on the player mats is particularly fun, but the game still takes a bit too long to finish for my liking (I'd prefer to play 3/4 shorter games).

*edit* a member of our group got the expansion, so this may go up in score once we play it

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
If you're committed to the play time, the depth of this game, and realize the potential repercussions of each action on the endgame, the effect is awe inspiring.

Throughout my first play, I kept thinking to myself "wow, there is so much to this game, and it would take a long time to truly master it".  Our group had committed 10 hours to our first play (it only took about 8, with only 6 of actual play time), and by the time it was over, many of us were sad that it had ended so soon!  I think preparation for what we were getting into, really helped with our initial attitude.

The first time you play, it's really long.  There's a lot of explanation and setup involved.  However, were we to play with the same players, that time would probably be cut down dramatically.  I imagine we could get through a game in 6 hours with 8 players.

I CANNOT wait to own this game for myself!

One other thing, it seems the Shattered Empire expansion pretty much bumps the awesomeness rating of this up several notches.  So you may be doing yourself a disservice by playing the game without it.

RATING: 5
Axis & Allies on (a)steroids. When you add a ton of luckbased features to a game where luck is already the main factor, you still end up with the sort of game where luck has more to say than actual strategy. Surprisingly few things happens during the many hours of play and the different options in the game adds only little challenge. For someone who drool over themes like 'starwars' and galaxies far far away this might be the top, but I'm not that someone. To me its an average game, nothing spectacular.

RATING: 9
TI is perhaps one of my favorite multi-player games of all time. It is easily one of the best strategy games I have played. While it can be difficult getting up to 6 players to devote the time needed for a game, the payoff is well worth it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Even though the objectives can feel disconcertingly out of place/theme, I am one of those players that can build a narrative out of TI3 and it helps that it has enough flash and chrome to assist in that. I truly feel like I am a space-faring alien race, out to bring glory to my people through combat, diplomacy, and treachery. 

I can certainly see how some gamers may feel there is not enough meat and certainly too much downtime to keep engagement and the narrative flow.

I enjoy both the long term strategic planning and the tactical considerations each turn gives. You always need to be planning one phase ahead to do well.

Marred by a very long play time. Don't play this with easily distracted people or the AP prone because then the ratio* of decisions to time invested gets out of whack. But with the right group of people this can be the epic game you want it to be. 

Another downside is that it can sometimes feel anti-climactic if Imperium Rex (game ends immediately card) comes out to soon. The uncertainty is part of the game though so it is hard to get too upset about it. One needs to prepare.

I find myself thinking about the game after it's over. I think about how my strategy did or did not work, my timing of the various play possibilities, and the other players moves. This is a good sign.

* Thanks to qwertymartin for the "ratio of decisions to time invested" concept.

RATING: 6
Overly long and complicated for what it is. The main issue (which looks like it may be fixed in TI4) is that all ships look alike on the board but due to tech etc some are WAY more powerful than others. The game needs iconography or something to show this but everything is on tiny impossible to read cards. So it's hard to weigh up opponents' strength quickly and subtly. Eclipse nails this and is imo a better and more streamlined game. I do like the planet based economy and the diplomacy elements however.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Twilight Imperium. What else is there to say about the greatest board game ever made? There is only one game that I am always willing to play, assuming I have the time, and it is this one.

I grew up around science fiction and, in particular, Star Wars. And Twilight Imperium perfectly captures the kind of sweeping, cosmic narrative that I loved as a kid—no other board game creates stories like this one, with clever diplomacy, trade, bribery and political intrigue, massive battles, and broken alliances.

Technically the base game has a couple of minor flaws, but Shattered Empire neatly resolves them and adds a ton of interesting content. Shards of the Throne is in many ways a weak expansion, but certain modules (Representatives in particular) add even more depth and interesting stories to the game. I play with most of both expansions and wouldn't go back.

(4X / civilization; 3x)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
EPIC.  If you can put aside the time to play a full TI:3 game and can spare the cash to buy it knowing that you will most likely just play it a few times per year at most (at least with the full 6 players) then definitely do so.  Twilight Imperium is a game like no other; it does warfare and player politics better than any I have ever played.  My first game took about 8.5 hours but felt shorter than my most recent playthrough of Eclipse which was around 2.5 hours.  You just cannot try to take it too seriously because inevitably only one person can win and the game takes pretty much a whole day (at least the first time).  I say TI:3 is like no other war game because the diplomacy/politics actually does something.  If someone goes all out on military and the other players are paying attention then that player is going to get taken back down a peg.  Additionally, the way the victory points are earned, pre-planning is rewarded but it does not favor warfare or peaceful play.  There are far too many concepts and rules to explain in a comment here but if you can GET THIS GAME.  It is incredible.

RATING: 9
It is "THE" empire builder game. It has everything you need to conquer the galaxy. If you are able to allocate free hours to play, than you will build explore the galaxy, colonize, build up armies, research technologies to aid you, make diplomatic and arrangements. It is byfar the most complex 4x game available, very immersive and also very huge, as it needs a large table to play on. It can accomodate up to eight players, but that will result in a very prolonged gameplay. It has lots of expansion modules, which you can combine as they suit you, giving more randomness than usual.

RATING: 8
It is a Space Opera, not a 4X like Space Empires, it is comparable to Eclipse in theme, but in mechanics it is very different. The playtime is very long, but the game is good enough to justify it. Like ameritrashes in general, there are events that can destroy the strategy of someone a lot, and this happened in the game I played after 7 hours playing and I didn't feel very good about this.

In general I enjoyed this game a lot, very beautiful miniatures, political and trade agreements present, the battle is the main focus, but not the only one. The thecnology tree is very good too, I like this a lot. The theme is great and very well implemented. A fine game but you need to be ready for political events that can be very agressives.

RATING: 8
THE big game of galactic conquest. The gaming experience is VERY much dependent on the group you play with. Players who tend to ignore the logic of a game and instead ally with their best mate in order to then start bashing their other opponents can ruin the fun quite a bit. Games can last up to 9 hours but you'll usually know within the first 120 minutes whether you will enjoy the session or not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
3 plays...I now feel no inclinaiton to play the game again, without some significant house rule changes.  However, I do feel a desire to try and fix it, into something that I will find playable.

The rest of my comments relates to the 'unpatched' version of the game. :)  

The role selection system looks like Puerto Rico's, but really, the first guy needs to choose imperial and the second needs initiative to get imperial, or else you just cant get to 10 points faster than the other guys (if you arent doing this, you fall hopelessly behind).
..After that, technology is almost always the best, so really, its just a heirarchy of who gets what for the first several picks.  The only actual 'choice' is at the bottom of the order.
Secondly, fighters seem overpowered, while dreadnaughts seem too expensive for their power.  I'm not sure about that, but it worries me.  It seems absolutely critical to build a fight re fleet, or you jsut CANT fight someoen who has such a fleet.  Sure, what capital ships you add to it might be interesting, but it takes so FRICKING long to get the necessary fighter fleet together, and you have to have it, that the ship types loses a lot of its interest for me.    
Third, the board setup mechanic, I dont know if I like either.  If you dont get any planets in your hand, you can have nothing decent anywhere near you, and be totally screwed.  Also, it seems that the way you set up, its unfair.  Whoever ends up placing last in a ring is getting screwed, especially if people put blanks near them.  Fourth, the game can often stall out in a 'turtling' excercise.  This makes for a boring 6 hours.  I've sat there for 6 hours and had not participated in a single battle all game.  And for everyone, if you fought someone, it meant the others would pounce on your remains very fast, because battles are so mutually destructive if you dont have overwhelming force.  Also, there often doesnt seem to be much at all to gain from winning battles, except maybe for a certain target due to your card or something.  And if you care about conquest, its because your card forces you to care, and then you only actually care about one location probably, either Mecatol Rex or an enemy home.    Late in the game, you get these huge buildups of 20 fighters and some ship on a location, and your opponent has the same, and if you fight you just annihilate each other and others can walk over you.  Why fight?  Most of the VPs come from taking imperial, and things like having 5 techs, having 3 space docks, paying 10 influence or 6 trade goods, have 1 of each color tech, etc, etc.  I can do that from my little corner of the board, with 5-6 planets next to my homeworld, where I build 6 PDS systems and get deep space cannon so I get 6 free shots at you for comign near me, and just turtle there and fulfill all the non-combat victory conditions and take imperial.   By the time you DO want to beat on someone because they will win, or to fulfill your objective, its so suicidal to do so, you just want someone ELSE to do it, so you can go take the remnants of their empire.  The game also takes FOREVER (around 6 hours, from my several experiences), and you dont seem to get any high level tech (except if you're Jol Nar), until it doesnt matter, because the game is already over.  Either that, or you go entirely for only one certain high level tech, and you get it near the end.  You choose one narrow branch of the tree to go through, out of like three brances that are actually any good. 

I really want to like it, but its very difficult.  There isnt a great deal of incentive to attack, and when there is its forced upon you by cards (and the secret objectives seem horribly unbalanced in their difficulty to achieve).  Even then, creating that war with your neighbor is usually suicidal and creates a power vacuum for others near you to rush to take advantage of, as two players fleets are destroyed.  I feel like if I was going to spend 6 hours on a game, it should be Die Macher or something.
Fifth, the action cards are rediculously different in power, ranging from things like gain 1 trade good per planet (~6-8), getting a ground unit per planet, or saying 'no one can take initiative this turn, so I keep the speaker and get imperial 2 turns in a row'.  On the flip side, are cards that barely screw one opponent, or that make your War Suns do a slightly better bombard (who fricking cares?).  They are just so wildly different in power that its a total crapshoot.
Some of the options, especially distant suns, piss me off.  Actually, distant suns pisses me off so badly it makes me want to quit the game after turn 1 when I flip up radiation and lose everything and get 0 planets, and that other guy gets 3-4 planets and a free spacedock and trade goods or a free tech.  Why play the game if after turn 1 you are screwed due to being far behind in the expansion race, and you have to sit there for another 5 hours to see how you lose?  Or everyone slows down to scout, and it adds an hour to the game.  

It really is the case that player 1 must take imperial, player 2 must take initiative, etc.  2 victory points is just such an enormously big part of your score.  There will be a few 1 pointers that come out that are easy, and some guy will get his secret objective for 2, and combined with 2 or 4 from 1-2 takes of imperial, he will win.  If you dont get your 2vps when its your chance, you are just screwed and cant make 10 first, no matter how much you might be killing people militarly.  Not only that, but there is a rediculous advantage to being the first guy to get imperial two times, since then you need only 6 points (6 easy one pointers, or 4 easy ones and an objective).  You just get your second 2 point gain before everyone, and have a tremendous advantage.  Or maybe the second guy to get it.  On the flip side, the guy getting it last is just screwed, as there is no way he gets it twice, and his secret objective merely gets him even with that guy who lucked out and got it twice.  There is just a tremendous disparity between going first (or very early) at the beginning, to going last.  And its because of how broken imperial is (which admittedly, is the 'clock' that makes the game not take  forever).  While its possilbe that a combination of several house rules might fix these various systems (though fixing the turtling problem seems very difficult to me, since there isnt much of any incentive to attack anyway, and you can defend so well with many deep space PDS systems).  So even though it might be fixable, I dont want to have to fix it, and it doesnt seem particularly exciting enough, or give enough cool game for the time investment, to warrant  trying to fix all these mediocre game mechanics.  And thats pretty much how I feel about it, a bunch of mediocre or unexciting or possibly broken game pieces, meshed together to make a very long, 6 hour experience where you sit there and dont get a lot accomplished.  And if you DO go military and manage to do it well without screwing yourself, then some guy has to fricking sit there for HOURS while getting beaten on and having no hope, since he cant possibly win.  I mean, the cool thing about this game is combat.  Late in the game, combat is pretty much suicidal, as even if you overwhelm them and win, you'll lose half your guys and then someone will be able to crush YOU.  If you do it early, when maybe you can catch them unprepared, and it works, then some guys has to suffer through hours of being screwed completely.   Note that my experience was probably more extreme because of playing two four player gmes, where everyone tended to have enough planets.  In the 6 player, some players dont feel that they have enough planets, and are more inclined to attack.  These combats still tend to hurt both players, most of the time, but at least things are more interesting...
It feels like a very average, but long and kindof slow/boring game, clouded in a cool theme, and the hype of its coming out.  
Yet another thing that annoys me about it is that influence is just so woefully underpowered compared to production.  I just dont care about influence, except to have some planet that gives 3 and no money to get an order token every turn.  Most of the laws are really minor, and the ones that do matter, even though you have 12 influence or whatever, if they decide they are screwing you with it because you're ahead or whatever, you cant really do anything about it.  Or you have all the influence and they play Thugs so you cant vote and screw you.  Whereas the industrial capacity is just so critical to doing anything.  If you get influence planets near you instead of industry, you just get screwed and cant do much of anything, and have trouble getting tech, or a big enough fleet to defend, let alone do anything militarily.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Все о чем можно мечтать. Глобальнейшая космическая стратегия.

RATING: 4
Did you ever play Civ 2 on the PC? Well, if you did, you'll remember that one of the weaknesses of an otherwise great game was that near the end of the game, after you ended your turn, you'd have to wait a very long time, sometimes well over a minute, to take your next turn because of how long the computer took to move all of its pieces. Then you would move your one legion or whatever, end your turn, and wait another minute or two while the computer moved. Well, if you want to relive the old times but with pieces you can touch and wait times 30 times as long, here's your game!

RATING: 3
We finally got around to trying this with 5 players. I have to say, at the start of the game and all throughout the 7 hours we played it to 6 points (the rules took an additional 1.5 hours), I was not liking it. I don't like games where there are tons of things to do, but a very limited path to victory points. I dislike it even more when some paths do absolutely nothing to affect points.

My biggest problem with TI is that most actions, and even the most prevalent ones, are not connected with getting victory points. For example, there is a huge military component to the game as most actions, modifiers, and pieces involve battles. However, you don't necessary get any points for following a military route. You can only score points two ways: One through the public objectives, of which all of our had to do with the technology tree. Which meant that capturing planets was only remotely needed to collect resources to purchase technology, except that you could get a technology for free with your strategy card selection (similar to selecting a role before your turn starts). My other issue is that the strategy card selection phase is in clockwise order from the person who selected Initiative from the previous round, which meant that the same players got to pick the attractive cards first. The second way to get points is through a strategy card that gives you 2 points. In our game, the winner got 4 out of 6 points from the sole act of picking this strategy card. Which meant there was little to really do except make sure you get or have enough resources to purchase technology cards (or get the strategy/role card that gets it for free), or make sure you get the freebie 2 VP card - very little benefit to battling others. And finally, the game was way too long for what it was worth and it took 4+ hours to get to our first battle.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Twilight Imperium 3rd is possibly one of the greatest games. Certainly one of the grandest strategy games. With the exception of a few flukes, it feels very balanced and epic on a galactic scale. If you get the opporunity to play this more than once or twice a year, you should consider it a great privilege. The only negative thing about this game is the reluctance most people have to trying such a new heavyweight game.

Update 2016: After many many action card/political deck changes and a few tweaks to weaker race abilities, I can say that Twilight Imperium easily meets a 10 on BGG. Truly its biggest setback is that the fat is not trimmed from the cards and some races are a bit underpowered. That having been said, we now give new players L1X1X/Saar/Hacan/Sol and veterans take a handicap with Xxcha and some expansion races, so they have a practical use at least. With every expansion added, there can definitely be some slowdown and large galaxy maps are actually not desirable. I can see this being a game that I continue to refine for years to come.

RATING: 9

The internets claim the base version is broken because of a dominant strategy, but that's easily fixed by tweaking the Imperial card a little bit to depower it (although this produces a longer game) or instituting minor house rules to curtail selection of the Imperial card.  Love it.

RATING: 3
Not for me.
No time for use of Star Fleet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I would probably rate TI3 higher than a 7, but I haven't had a game yet to convince me to do it. I've only played one learning game, and it had some issues.

I played with expansions and some idiosyncratic variants which started me off confused. I read the base game rulebook and was surprised how streamlined the information in it was. Turns out, adding in expansions and variants turns everything on its head. I was definitely lost for a bit. The base mechanics I was interested in were still there, but a bit muddied and different. 

Plus, we played with a pre-made map (boo!). I was really looking forward to building the galaxy. It's the only early game sense of exploration and agency available. Although we did play with domains, I forgot the rule (and it was never mentioned in game) about scanning domains before exploring! Still, I wanted some control over my galaxy.

The game itself has incredibly arcane, weird pacing IMO. Maybe experience might change things? But since we had no idea what kind of public goals would come up, I spent the first half of the game sort of bumbling around hoping to stumble into a position that would set me up to achieve goals once they actually appeared. I was not playing a particularly warlike race, so jumping into direct fights for control of places that the very warlike races *were* controlling looked like a dumb move. So, ho hum, the first half was pretty meh.

The second half was more interesting. But that's when the mountain of variants and unexpected rules started getting in the way--once we actually started trying to do things. Again, it was a first play, so what are you gonna do.

Another gameplay criticism has to do with the thematic options available. There's a claim made that TI3 is an empire building game. Honestly, I'm still trying to find a good empire building game. There's no real building of the empire at all. It's a strategic wrestling match hoping you can snag some goals and not have your fragile little foothold blow up. TI3 is not empire building, it's the frontlines of a murky war with a fairly heavy degree of luck filled battle mechanics and random objectives that pop up to snag points.

Honestly, the objective based dicey combat reminds me more of Nexus Ops than anything else. TI3 is like a blown up, epic space battle version of Nexus Ops with politics, activation markers, strategy cards, etc. I'm not saying that's bad, but it's not what I was looking for. I want a little more agency in building and managing my empire PLUS the frontlines of a space war. If we're gonna build a game this big, why can't we have that? Sigh. 

On a side note, I actually think that Nexus Ops's all secret goal system works better than TI3's primarily public goal system. AND Ops lets you get (less) points just for winning battles even though fulfilling goals is way better. I'm not saying TI3 should do that. But a couple more ways to score points inefficiently to give you SOME early game direction without feeling like you're completely wasting your time would be nice.

Finally, I found the narrative of TI3 pretty weak. For a thematic game, it just didn't feel all that thematic too me. Maybe it takes players more invested in their races, but the races are a little eh for me. I'm not particularly interested in pretending to be any of them. There wasn't anything about the gameplay that really "put me there" or told me the story about drastically different races vying for power. More like drastically similar races with minor strengths and weaknesses saber rattling and dancing around each other, am I right?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Fantastic game, well worthy of being one of FFG's flagships, though not without its flaws (many of which are fixed with the first expansion).  It's not a space wargame - there's not often full-on combat, it's more of a diplomatic space opera simulator where you sometimes need friendship and sometimes need to beat people over the head with the War Sun stick.  The goal of the game is to get points, so Imperial I is right out - we like using the Shattered Empire: Bureaucracy strategy card path.

The main issue other than Imperial I is that it's got a bunch of economic objectives, which can make it really turtle-y.  The more combat-oriented objectives in Shattered Empire make things much nicer.

RATING: 9
I love TI and how deep and fleshed out the game is. Of course, this assumes that you have both expansions. The base game without the expansions is actually pretty unfair (Imperial much?). For a long, epic, space opera game, I love how deep the political mechanics are, and that you are almost always involved in some action even in between your turn (secondary strategy actions). There are some Secret objectives that make the game focus too much on military might and making someone miserable, but house rules can mitigate that. Overall, one of my favorite games that I don't get to play nearly enough.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played once with elements of the Shattered Empire expansion.  Came to it with some foreboding as monster FFG games have a very poor track record with me and Twilight Imperium set the template for them.  

As so often with FFG, the bloated rulebook belies a game that is actually quite straightforward.  There is role selection a la Puerto Rico, complete with the opportunity for other players to use that role to a lesser effect.  The command chits that must be spent to do anything are quite cleverly implemented.  Technological development is present and handled unfussily.  Combat is of the bucket of dice variety, with retreats handled in a decidedly odd manner. The board assembled from hexagonal tiles, the different races, random objectives and tons of action and political cards offer a lot of variability.  Unfortunately, some of that takes a very cavalier attitude to game balance.  

In our game the pace seemed off.  The early hours were an arms race with little actual fighting.  We felt that better use could have been made of objective cards to promote more aggressive play from the start.  Just as the stalemate seemed to be broken and the game was getting interesting, the game over card was drawn, leaving everyone dissatisfied.   

Eight hours passed fairly quickly; TI kept me busy and reasonably entertained.  And yet, rather like Arkham Horror, I was left with the impression of a lot of chrome concealing not a great deal under the bonnet. In nothing but the time it took did TI feel epic. Nor did it present me with the kind of strategic dilemmas I expect of a truly big game.

Production quality and artwork are as good as you would expect from FFG.  The too obvious borrowings from Star Trek, Star Wars and Battlestar Galactica were something of a disappointment.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Epic 4X game with lots of tactical and strategic decisions. Long but enjoyable.

RATING: 8
The L1Z1X sent messages in binary, like this translated epistle to the Xxcha ninja turtles: "Rafael was my favorite of your 'leaders' BTW." 

Playing an eight-player game of TI was one of the most fun days ever.  And I mean DAY.  Eight hours of fun.  All encompassing dice-throwing goodness.  The superlatives just sound like blah, blah, blah after a while, but man...  [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/333715]please, please read my session report if you're interested in TI III.[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Where to start? This game should be my jam. I love space, I love 4x, I love epic. Let's break this down into positives/negatives.

So here's the positives for me: I love the activation system, I love the strategy cards, I love the idea of galactic politics (wish Eclipse had that!). Combat is okay. I really like that the activation system forces you to think about how you would like to go about attacking, because you can't build and then attack the same turn (without a strat card). 

On the negative side, three major flaws for me: Politics is such a cool idea... but we never really drew anything super interesting from the politics cards. Maybe we just got unlucky. Also (and this might be due to the strat cards we used), the slow slow burn/reveal of public objectives (and no 2pt imperial strat card) meant it felt like on some turns I had no idea what to move towards for points, so I was just stalling for a completeable objective. And the final, killer flaw for me: play time. Seven hours for our first game. The Puerto Rico turn mechanic can make some turns (as you wait for reaction follows) go forever, and if you have a big battle that you're not in, its just nap time. 

All that said, I would play again. This game/theme is still right in my zone, but it won't unseat Eclipse for me. I find myself wishing Eclipse would steal a couple mechanics - politics and strat cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Best game our group has played in a while. Very enjoyable, though VP bonus for the Imperial strategy card is too much and unbalalnces the game of makes the card choice a bit too predictable as it just goes round each player in turn. Expansions rectify this and give a lot more options to make the game varied.

Subsequent plays has seen this drop as interest wanes. Lots of variants but our group mainly goes for combat options. Also seems to take a long time.

RATING: 8
A monster of a game. If you've played either Sid Meir's Civilization or Alpha Centauri and thought it'd make a good  board game then this is for you. It takes elements for Axis & Allies and then adds a euro-layer to the game but adding political and non-military aspects to it through a mechanic lifted from Puerto Rico. A four hour game best with 5 or 6 people, it delivers, but its not for everyone.

This game if much improved by the expansion if only for the Imperial Strategy II card.

Expansions:
Shards of the Throne
Shattered Empire

I think this game is great, still has many flaws that I don't like, I guess that is why I kept eclipse instead of this one, but it is a great game, I just wish they came out with a TI4 so that they would fix all the crap that is wrong, streamline some of the game play, enhance the politics and trade and make everything balance.  In the end, both expansions are necessary because they help balance an unbalanced game, I enjoyed it, and if they come out with a new version, will probably buy it, but only if they fix a lot, and improve on the board hexes quality, mini quality and a lot more things that would make it better.

RATING: 5
We were with very good player this weekend to play TI3. Honestly not my favorite game. Some things doesn't work for me like the politic and trade cards. These aspects are not fully exploited, and they just increase the general luck of the game. The main focus of the game is the war. Personnaly, I would have like to have a way to win the game either by political or economical reason. On this game, we were killing each other wihtout a reason why. 4 turns before the end, I stop expending, stop fighting and retreat myself on my homeworld. I knew how much point I could get and when I was schedule to win, and that was not matter what the others would have tried on me. The plastic pieces are awsome and the battle resolution work, but the fighter and ground troops are overrated.

Have a good game.

the imperial card is of concern, but only if players dawdle and do not aggressively chase their secret objective...  if players do not play like this, the player who went 1st should win (probably).

RATING: 10
It has all you could expect from a Space Conquest game and much more: warfare, technology, diplomacy, the Imperial Senate,... Awesome game. The flow of the game, with the activation system is very good, with almost no downtime. Yes it's long, but a game with this scope can't be any shorter and not loose punch. Yes it's complex (but not so much, since the rules are very consistent and easy to remember), but the game is really, really worth it. Unfortunately FFG seems unable to get a game completely right, even if it's in its 3rd incarnation. Out of the box the Imperial Strategy Card is terrible, fighters are too powerful and politics is too bland. You'll need house rules and/or the expansion to get the perfect 10 game Twilight Imperium can be.

RATING: 8
Good strategic space game.  Once people built up to a certain point, the game was at a balance where whoever made the next attack would be at a disadvantage (since we'd all counter-attack).  Seemed to be very difficult to conduct a proper offensive.  However, this doesn't make for a bad game, it just means you have to make a plan and stick to it.  The technology system and political system are very nicely put into the system.  Combat is also very simple.  And the variety of races make for some good replayability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

The expansion takes this to another level, and just piles on more. If you like Twilight Imperium you need the expansion, it's a galactical space opera of the grandest scale in your living room, this is the epic game you are looking for!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
It frankly boggles the mind just how ambitious and huge this game is...not only in game length but scope. The ultimate space opera struggle, with well conceived, well balanced races, tons of components, and a great balance of luck and determination, the former brought through dice and random card draws, the latter through how you manage your control tokens and what strategies you'll pick as primary or secondary. Battles are relatively fast once you get the units squared away, and I doubt I'd want to play this without the Leader and Domain options, since those flesh out a more adventurous setting. Problem will always be how to set aside time and find people interested in learning to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Tentative rating based upon 1.5 plays.  There's a long learning curve on this one before you learn to optimize or even play well all the different races.  I like the economic and technology tree aspects of the game, but they can become a larger part of the game than control of the board.  This game plays radically different based on number of players due to some of strategies not being chosen each round with a fewer number of players which can handicap races needing technology, trade or other things.  With my group there's a real tendency to turtle, which makes the game less than it could be.

I swear that my friends conspire to get together and play this behind my back and then tell me about it later.

Tried the quick start and for those on a time budget that's the way to go.  This is a game that is all about the journey, not the destination.  However, over time I'm finding myself less and less willing to play this because of the length of time that it takes to play.  The introduction of Eclipse also caused this game to slip in the rankings.

I believe that this plays best with 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is probably my favorite game. Granted, I only played it once (I want to... no, I need to play it again). Magnificent game. Sure it may take a while to play, but that was nothing compared to when Arkham Horror goes mental on you:
-Woohoo, I'm not delayed anymore. I'll just move over here and try an encounter.
*they see me rolliiiiiing - dice!*
-Guess what? 
-What? 
-Now your lost in time and space!
o_o ... 
- Khaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaan!

TI3 gives you a lot of control and free reign to play as you want, and you feel like everything you do matters (because it does!). My only gripe with the game is the Strategy card that gives you 2VP... In a 4-player game we had a player that managed to snatch it 3 times in a row (he ended up winning the game because of it) but it is fixed in one of the expansions, so will get them at some point... Already hoping for a 3rd expansion. :)

Update 22.February 2015: Played the game for the second time, made a house rule so that the "Imperial"-strategy card only gave 1 point when it was chosen. It is a bit closer to the Imperial II version (which I don't have as I currently don't own the expansions). This made the game much more enjoyable and a much closer run to the finish.

I can without a doubt say that this is my favorite game ever. :)

RATING: 7
Not much to be said about TI that hasn't already been said. Personally, I prefer the core game with the old Imperial card. All optional rules in effect. The game flows well, and though it takes a while, it's a strategy game with tons of saber-rattling, so it scores high in my book.

------------

After my third game of TI, I have to adjust the marker a little bit. While this is still a great game, I'm dropping it to a 7 simply because I wouldn't want it to hit the table every week.

Our last game was amazing, but ended when the Imperial order got messed with (someone played an action card to prevent Imperial from being drawn, then someone else countered with an action allowing them to switch their strategy with Imperial, which in turn would allow him to draw it twice in rapid succession - as such, the game came down to an action card lucky play... and I don't prefer those) that aside, it was still a GREAT game... just not an event that I'm looking to recreate week after week (maybe once every 6 months or so). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After two (almost) full games it's finally time to make a judgement on the game... And it's a winner, with the caveat that you must have Shattered Empire to make it work properly. The game is heavy war game epic, with depth in every aspect, barring economy. Comparisons with the heavily euro Eclipse don't quite fit; this is a war game with heavy diplomacy. The game is won and lost in posturing and manuevering. Eclipse follows the same theme and plays much quicker, but without the weight of TI and with its clockwork euro design, feels like a very different beast, one of efficiencies and cleverness. 
Where TI finds better company is in games like Game of Thrones and Diplomacy - broad strategic play whilst balancing threats and relationships. This is something that comes to fullness with an investment of time - something that is consciously trimmed from other, more euro civ-builders.
The game has flaws- in true Fantasy Flight style, the rule book(s) are a mess - why a game this big didn't get the GMT style treatment is a mystery. Also, randomness has a lot to say. However, there is a broad decision space to mitigate this, and if that fails, one can try to talk out of trouble. By its nature, this will only get sporadic play, but it deserves more. An epic experience and a genuinely great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5

Lo malo es, en mi caso, convencer a gente que no está mnetida en  este mundillo a encerrarse 6-8 horitas de juego, + 1-2 de explicación... misión imposible.

Así que llevo dándole vueltas a mi valoración al TI3 y le voy a bajar mi nota de diez a nueve y medio. En realidad me muero de ganas por jugar a los dos, pero creo que el tiempo de espera y la duración, con lo que soy yo, me van a dejar un regustillo amargo.

RATING: 6
Pár nappal a játék előtt figyelmeztettek rá, hogy van egy túl egyértelmű stratégia a játékban (felváltva kell választani az 1. és a 8. stratégiakártyát). Ez a hiba ki lett küszöbölve állítólag, de nem volt időm utánaolvasni, szóval az eredeti szabályok szerint játszottuk.
Valóban túl egyértelmű, hogy ez a helyes kombináció, tehát a kezdőjátékos túl nagy előnyt kap. De nem csak ez a gondom. Mindannyiunk számára unalmassá vált pár kör után a tötyörgés, sok holtidő, a pontozón alig haladtunk előre. Zavaró, hogy lényegében egyedül célkártyákból szerezhető győzelmi pont (leszámítva a már említett 8. stratégiakártyát). 1 kör kb. 1 óra alatt ment le nekünk, és minden körben 1 vagy 2 pontot szerzett mindenki... És nem nagyon volt tétje 1-1 csatának: inkább csak úgy általában fejlődni kell mindenből, és reménykedni, hogy olyan célkártya jöjjön, amit teljesíteni tudunk. De kicsit céltalan az egész, talán egyedül a titkos célkártya jelent valami kiszámítható célt, de abból meg nem húzható új.
Alapvetően biztató volt a szabály, jó a hangulata a játéknak, és rengeteg ötletes elem van benne, (pl.a parancsjelzők elosztása nagyon tetszik, a szavazások is, stb.), és a 400+ kártya, 10 jól kidolgozott faj sok újrajátszhatóságot sejtetett, de így játszva mégse kaptam kedvet hozzá. Összefoglalva: kicsit többet vártam egy ilyen fajsúlyos játéktól, a nagy ki-bepakolás, sok alkatrész, másfél-két óra szabály, jópár óra játékidő nem áll arányban a játékélménnyel. De sok biztató rész is volt, ezért még kell neki adni esélyt mindenképp! Simán mehet még felfelé a pontszám.
(Még egy megjegyzés: nemrég próbáltam az Eclipset, ami szintén nem egy hibátlan játék, de sokkal inkább Euro, sokkal változatosabb, és egzaktabb mint ez, ezért az nekem jobban tetszik.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played once as a 6-player game with a ton of optional rules and also with the Shattered Empire expansion.  TI3  probably appeals more to gamers who enjoy making/breaking alliances with neighboring players.  The unfortunate thing is that you spend most of the game buying/stockpiling units on your initial homeworld and 2-4 neighboring hexes.  You then make an alliance with the neighbor on your right and play a game of chicken with the neighbor on your left.  If and when, you end up attacking each other, it's usually with 1/4th of your total units engaged in a battle over 1 hex.

In order for TI3 to really work, I feel that every player should know the rules at the geekiest level OR each and every player should have awesome player aids to reference.  In addition to this, players need to play at a decent pace and there should be an "active player" button that passes around.  To give you an idea of just how slow the game was moving, we completed Round 4 at the six hour mark.

RATING: 9.5
UPDATE - [1.14.18] FOR TRADE or SALE ($75.00 w/ Shattered Emipres Exp.)

I have an extra copy of the TI3 w/ the Shattered Empires Expansion.  Willing to trade or sell 2nd copy.

[5.1.17] I had a chance to play a partial game of TI3 with a group of 7 people, and it has laid to rest the (now older) debate between which is better TI3 or Eclipse.  

These games are at best superficially the same (space theme, elements of exploration, inclusion of tech trees, etc.), but at their core these are fundamentally different games.  

Everything about Eclipse is smooth and sleek and at its core the game centers around the efficient manipulation of your economy to do different actions (explore, build, research, etc.)

Conversely, TI3 is textured, and the game itself does not reward efficiency of manipulating game mechanics alone.  Yes, at its core, TI3 uses a Puerto Rico-esque role selection mechanic where the primary player is able to enact a slightly more powerful version of a secondary action that is offered, at a cost, to all other players.  Beyond this mechanic, however, is a modular board that bring tactics into the game that echoes that which is seen in the Milton Bradley Gamers Series titles such as Axis & Allies, Shogun, etc.  Also built into the game is a high degree of politicking, bluffing, and fragile alliance building/breaking. 

The game is wrought with twists and turns and at the end of the session you and your friends will have a story to tell.

I think this game can be best described as a game that is driven by euro mechanics, skinned by ameritrash swag, that results in a narrative to be remembered.  

It is well worth the investment of time to play.

[2.8.12]
Reading rules... Can't wait to play.  This game looks like it has a high amount of interaction both with combat and just person to person politics and diplomacy.  It is long, looks messy, crap all over the table, modular board - pure Ameritrash!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In my early teens I was a great fan of the first Civilization PC game (and later Masters of Orion). At the same age I made the first contact with Boardgames - Risk. 

When I played Risk the first time I really appreciated it, since it was a boardgame, which resembled the conquest aspect of Civilization - but of course I wanted the other aspects of Civilization as well. One could say that since then I always searched for a boardgame that succeeded in that - bringing all the aspects of Civilization or Masters of Orion to the table. I thought that this combination would generate the perfect boardgame. 

On my way I found out that a perfect boardgame doesn't need to have all this aspects and that too many mechanism can easily kill the game as a whole. Even though my favorites aren't al all like Civ or Moo I must say that TI really achieves to combine all the essential aspects of Civ or Moo and to be a great game as well.

Update: Literally after each session, I have the feeling that the gamesystem is suboptimal. The epic "build up and bash" of a good conqeust game is missing; instead of tension and narration you get a random VP hunt. Either this is state of the art turtling (since there are a few games in which a war between A and B benefits C more) or attacking has nothing to do with waging a war but is only a gamey move to earn VPs (if you use the expansion's Vp conditions). It starts to feel like the longest Eurogame in history.

The still somewhat joyful game is downgraded to a 7
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Played 2 turns of a game to get a feel for it, and then played a full game. With a break for dinner, this took us from 2pm until midnight, with 6 players who had never played before.

I had a great time. There is a lot of luck, and some of your choices are dictated by your race/action cards, but this is a great game. Player elimination could happen, but it is sufficiently rare that I can't see it happening more than once in 100 games.

My rating is a little off if you go strictly by what BGG defines them as, simply because I don't frequently have this much time to devote to one game. When I do though, this game will be the choice.

RATING: 10
3-player.
Very slow start on rules explanation/setup (we were all new to game, except 1 player having experienced TI-2).
8:30-11:30 for that first part.
11:30-4:15am for gameplay.
Managed 5 turns before needing to be elsewhere. I was likely third. Good experience, however. Yeah, it's everything all the fans crow about. I'm now a crow. On an incomplete TI3 diet. WANT MORE . . .!!!

2012-12-15 - Finally!! 3-player game, starting from scratch, using sample of options from all three parts. Rules discussion started at 9:30am - didn't finish until 12:30pm (we're detailed like that). Then time for setup - that took us until 2:30pm (had to have lunch in there somewhere!!). By then one of us had to leave, but as planned, the pinch-hitter arrived just in time for game start.  We got through 2 rounds by 7:30pm. My favorite part - the political intrigue component from Shards - that provided the richest experience. We didn't even get to mercenaries, wormholes, factories/etc. and a bunch of other options. That's okay. 2/3 enjoyed it (yay for Ameritrash!) - the third didn't like the random/luck factor (oh, bah humbug to you!). 
Love this game. Hope to train up other core players so that we reach that nirvana state of the experienced 6 player all day blowout. Sigh ... I can wish, can't I?

RATING: 7
My first game was spent just getting my head around the rules and some basic strategies. Game two I was still rusty but at least picked up from where I left off and despite making some shocking mistakes at least had an idea of what was going on. Deeply strategic and with wide possibilities that make nothing a foregone conclusion. Scales down well to 3 players.

As time has passed the long play time and heavy dice engine has resulted in this never getting on the table. It is unlikley to make it back so time to trade on.

Jan 2012: Indeed this one is too huge and takes too long to reteach to new comers. Along with its 4-5 hour playing time, this is a day long game and with the randomness and pivotal role of the dice in combat, I really would much rather play almost any other game in my collection. Down rated to a 7 and sold on.

RATING: 9.5
Just epic in its scope, which I adore on so many levels. I really enjoy how each race feels COMPLETELY different with their special abilities. These abilities should really dictate your strategy as you play. I also enjoy the combat. Normally not a fan of buckets o' dice combat, but here it works. Why? Because of the cards that can be played to really help you or mess up your opponent. I don't feel that the Imperial card is a game breaker, but actually acts as a timer for a game that will go at least 4-5 hours anyways. My only gripe would be the hexes for the galaxy. I am not a big fan of the garish color scheme, but hey that's just me. This one will never leave the collection. Also, did I mention....... WAR SUN!!!!!!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I have dreaded adding this note to my one and only play for sometime, because it was one of the most horrendous plays I have ever personally experienced. I was the ONLY one at the table with any experience with the rulebook, and it was my game and my first play! suffice to say that my reading and understanding of the rules had taken place MONTHS before we sat down, and no I had not revisited them. Also bear in mind that a copy of a game was in the house that we are all more familiar with, even though it was new and never played as well in the person of Starship Catan. Which was my vote to play, but since it had been months since I had obtained TI, my well meaning "group" My Wife, one of my very best friends and his wife, decided it was High time I got to play my last years Christmas Gift. seeing as how I had kinda planned to play Starfarers, I had not so much as glanced at my TI rules in MONTHS, so as you know, It was brutal, I got questions before I answered their last questions, and it went on and on and on. The fault is mine as the game was unpunched, and we had four players, and I also let it go on wayy too long, I should have called the session, before the dropouts started, that was my bad. 


But I did it because in between the questions and confusion, my buddy and I both got it, and we both lit up like six year olds every time something new happened...and that is when it hit me, again actually: This masterpiece is like the most tasty meal that once you get up from it you have at once had both all your favorite courses and desserts, yet are not stuffed, just supremely satisfied. The first time I had this feeling was after my third read and research through the rules that first time months before, when I KNEW this game and could have answered all questions. Needless to say the ladies are not too fond based on that one play, even though they promised to give it another shot. Even in all this adversity, the game showed me a glimpse of itself, and I await my "second" gaming group; made up of that same buddy and several others who all love this sort of thing, getting together around this one with HOURS to kill, and THAT alone has the score where it is for me, this is one of my Favorite games currently and of all time. Continual brushing up on the rules just keeps me more and more excited to play it, and overjoyed that I own it!

05/08/10
There is another play in there, partial though it is, with no real hangups, and not totally finished, it does not raise my score any, but it got close! it was basically a learning game, for me, to get me back on my feet after the brutality of the first one. This game will be played by myself and anyone I can corral into the seats opposite me for a long time. I won't add the play here, nor any other until I have a full table again, I am expecting to raise this score however, very soon indeed.

RATING: N/A
3-6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
One play, with an expansion, so take my rating with a game of salt.  However on further thought, I doubt I'll be playing this again, but I could be talked into it if a game needed a 4th player.  I've never hated and loved a game so much at the same time.

I played it in a 7-player game with 5 of us having never played before.  So..it took a little bit to get going because of both not knowing how to play, and having a board big enough to fit 7 people.  In hindsight, I made a metric crapton of mistakes, but next time around, I have an idea of what I'll be doing...  bwa ha ha ha ha.

Some notable moments:  threatening the guy next to me into a favorable trade agreement.

Next time around:  I think 5-player might actually be a little more fun with this game, and give me a chance to see a little ebb and flow happen with this.

.........

Additional thoughts the next day, on reflection of playing 3 games of agricola or 2 games of le havre or 6 games of finca or 4 games of thurn and taxis or 8 games of zooloretto in the same time as one game of twilight imperium:  You know what this game is?  It's a eurogame for grognards.  That is, it's as slow, prohibative, and tactical as any wargame you could possibly think of, with the addition of those zany eurogame antics about building things and getting 'special' rule-breaks that go on.  

In the end, I like a lot of conflict, and I mean a LOT of conflict...and when you can easily go an hour without getting in a fight with anyone, or heck, even winning the game without getting in a fight with anyone, you're just spending points and building things.  Spend points, build stuff.  Spend points, build stuff.   ...which is done much better in a game of CIV IV on the computer, or something.  Even the interactions with other people aren't as advanced and 'zany' as much as finding a way to be more efficient than they are.

Much more, most of the conflict I did have was with myself.  "Oh, I can't do this"  "Oh, I can't do that".  "Oh, I should be doing this..."  and it wasn't actually things I inflicted on other players or had them inflict on me.  I mean, in 4 hours, I think I said "You sunuva!" at someone else maybe three times and at the game itself probably 30.  Whereas, in most of the typical games on my shelf I've had to make something of nothing or make a block move, or grab something very useful at least 5 times in the first half-hour.

HOWEVER, I can't get out of my head, what I would do if I were invited to play this again.

The game:  We would all start with 4 additional technologies of our choosing.  Next up, everything would get +1 movement.  Additional victory points for taking out someone else's home planet.  3 additional action cards and 4 political cards to start the game with.  The board, if not for the +1 movement, could be made much smaller.  That would be AOK by me as well.

How I played:  I played with the lizix mindnet.  I'd want to play with them again.  I'd set my fleet capacity to 4, two carriers and two dreadnauts filled with fighters.  I'd make a daisy-cutter around the board taking down everyone in my path.  Victory points?  Screw that.  I care about one victory point:  "All your base are belong to me, b;tches!"  Pretty doable, build a bunch, send 'em out.  The downside is that a dreadnought with a movement of 1, and a board measuring three deep from entity to entity, at 10 minutes a turn, mean it's 10 minutes at least between butt-kickings.  

...which tells me one thing, and one thing only.  This is a wargame.  I played this game, and the only thing I want to do in this game is break stuff.  Break lots of stuff.  This wouldn't be bad, but it wants to be a diet-coke eurogame with most of the interactions being pretty much player v. board.  Why bother building all these warships when only 2 out of the 8 victory points that first come up have anything to do with offense?  Do I have to worry about anyone reaming my base when there's no points in it?  Systemically, I'd like to see more creative fighting goals to go with this game's very rich combat focus, because if it wants to be a eurogame, I can think of faster games that achieve the same ends giving me more of the eurogame buck for my minutes played.

RATING: 10
Finally, finally got this game to the table.  Took 7hrs to do a 5 person game, which is what I was expecting.  All of us were new, and while I was familiar with the rules, some of the other players were not.  Took a few rounds to get the hang of things, but overall the gameplay itself is actually relatively fast.

Although the playtime is long, the downtime is minimal.  Am looking forward to getting this game to the table again, and particularly enjoyed the difficulty in choosing how/when to spend command counters.  Rated it an 8 for now but could easily see this game shooting up to a 10 with a few more playthroughs.  Important to note that it does take a dedicated gaming group to make it enjoyable though.  Putting TI on the table is an event, not a game.

After playing it again, it's my favourite game. Hands down.  Just so complex, so amazing.

RATING: 7
I had a lot of expectations about this title. I've played and I will keep playing it. TI3 is a mix of rules and systems taken by many games, as aGoT. The result is a game with many good aspects, but not having a balanced assemble. Roles are not identical. IMO political part is too much unimportant. TI3 success and replaybility depends mostly by the group playing it. Can be an epic and fantastic game, as a boring and broken one. I prefer to play with the FFG website ISC variant. But that's is up to you. Conflict is not a true necessity and this is a shame. Who doesn't like a big interstellar war :-))) I guess there is need for further playtesting and probably, as aGot teach us, there will be an expansion fixing the game.Anyway FFG made a very good production job, as the game is gorgeous and has a very strong theme. There is room to improve it, as is in process to be done by FAQ and new rules appeared on FFG site.To resume this is a game that is good if played with the right attitude and not in an overcompetitive mood. In such conditions is very fun.Worth to be tried, expecially if you are a big fan of epic galactic empires conflicts.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
This really is an epic game. It takes a long time to play, but every second is worth it. It has everything you could wish for in an epic space game. There's civ building as you expand your empire to gain resources and influence. It has fighting, negotiation and politics (is there a difference) and interweves these in a brilliant way. Races strong in influence tend to be low on resources so there is always something to negotiate about. The tech development system and variable race powers make the game even more involved. But what makes this game rise above it's predecessor is the role selection mechanic they took from Puerto Rico. Take into account the bad rules organization, need for the first expansion and great components which are standard issue with a Fantasy Flight Game and you have a very good game if you can afford the time investment.

Gameplay: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Fun/Social: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Components: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Rules: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
With both expansions this is one of my favorite games, although I don't have that much experience playing it, especially with a full table.

My only complaint is that it is too long for a casual get together, but then that is a good thing, too!

This makes a great 2 player game as well. We've been playing with the following rules, which are heavily derived from the Shattered Ascension variation rules:
- use 2-ring galaxy with home planets set on opposite sides and an asteroid field in the middle. Players take turns choosing from randomly dealt tiles and then construct the board. First player to choose a tile is the last player to place a tile:
    - 2 red bordered tiles (besides asteroid field in middle);
    - 4 blank tiles;
    - 10 planet tiles.
- Strategy Phase: both players pick 3 Strategy Cards.
- Status Phase: both players only receive 1 Command Counter (rather than 2).
- Trade: Races may trade with themselves, but only 1 agreement.
- Politics and Assembly: a die is rolled to randomize vote (per Shattered Ascension).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The mother-load of tile-laying space conquest games.  Think RISK with a large unit selection, with a variable board (laid out by randomly picking tiles in turn and choosing where to place them before the game starts), resource management, and diplomacy.

Good expansions that add more complexity, although occasionally removing some.

This game is very good, but it is typically very long. You're really going to need to set aside an entire day to play this game through.  If like the sound of it, but the length scares you, I'd suggest looking at Eclipse instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Copy of game from Guy M. I'll need another shelving unit to store it and all my recent acquisitions...

I am still on the fence about this game, but see enough promise in it to be happy about this most recent addition to my game collection.

On the one hand, it's a superb piece of game design. The roles are integrated perfectly with the board, and the rules are robust. Only the objective cards and the Imperial SC need attention, and apparently they get that attention in the first expansion.

On the other hand, the last two games proved to me that I'm just not good at building an imperial tableau that is flexible enough to get a VP per turn. Last game with Damon made me really unhappy about the game itself. We were teaching two new players, and he and I got into something of a fight over whether to give strategic information to Linette and Leigh (a situation the would overwhelm them, but I maintain also hand the victory to Damon, the better player), or let them make their own mistakes (a situation I was unhappy with as I was still trying to grasp how to actually WIN this bloody game, though Damon had figured it out, and I wanted the game to go long enough to get a sense for how to win). In the end, Damon won by a margin of six points - AGAIN.

My problem is simple - the VAST BULK of movements on the board do not translate into VPs. In fact, the only thing that does score points is the selection of roles. I want to play it again to see if I can avoid getting distracted by the game and just play the roles. This is a sad sentiment, and reflects a bad design choice; namely that the least well-integrated part of the game undoes one of the most subtle and well-designed parts. That is, the blunt instrument of the objective deck basically trashes the glorious integration between roles cards and board.

As far as I can see, the objectives reward good play of the roles - they are based around technology, trade goods, resources - the only reason to have a fleet is to conquer enough to ensure these basic needs. In fact, once you have ten resources/influence you can afford technology every round, or pay for logistics to get more CP.

If I can get good at the base game, I might consider expansions. A big part of my problem is how bad I am at the game, and how easy Damon makes it look to build a game-winning, flexible tableau. So easy that I wonder if the game is somewhat broken, since we've never got past the yellow objective cards before he's won.

The sad thing is, I like the fact that you can win with no fleet. I just dislike the fact you can't choose a strategy - in fact, your strategy is chosen for you by the vicissitudes of the objective deck. The designers say "flexibility" is key, but in my three plays of the game thus far, it means a combination of aggressive exploitation of the role cards and bland generalisation of your empire. I especially don't like how your ability to move towards an end goal is sometimes simply foreclosed by the turn of an objective card that hands the game to your opponent.

I really want to stop one nasty experience (the last time we played, and taught Leigh and Linette) making me hate this game.

Two other things - I really dislike the "foregone conclusion" effect. The game has a nasty habit of reaching a conclusion but taking two hours to conclude. That is, one runaway leader can claim enough victory points to win twice over and you can't stop them (because they already have enough of whatever to win), but you need to play out the turns as resolution.

The rule we missed - that you can prevent this sort of thing by taking over a home system - is a bad fix, because all that does is knock that player out of the game. So the options are:

1) Give up and say they won. Save two hours,

2) Play the game through, knowing you can't win, or

3) attack their home system, making them grumpy and (probably) letting someone else win.

The more I think about it, the more I think that the objectives need to be much harder to achieve and much more specific, and possibly revealed at a rate of two or three per turn, so you have meaningful choices to make that are reflected in board position, not role selection.

Got rid of pre-Melbourne move
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 7
A game with huge scope, that takes a long time to play. Some areas the game explores are more prominent than others but in essence it revolves around a diplomacy of threats and disguising your strategies for as long as possible. Then massing fleets and brinkmanship.

Unfortunately, trading is inexcusably weak, pulling diplomatic attempts down. Politics is fun and engaging but all too often the politics strategy lies neglected since the reward to pick it is too small.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
PROS: This game solves several problems of previous versions. Mechanically it's best new feature is the addition of strategy cards which add flexibility while reducing down-time. TI3 also builds off its previous strengths; thematically this game is *stunning*. The artwork, components, and chrome are just luscious. CONS: Having the Imperial Strategy Card grant VP causes a selection loop that dominates the game and weakens gameplay. A couple of the objective cards are ridiculously imbalanced, as are many of the Action Cards. Nothing has been done to address turtling-up and amassing forces. OVERALL: A fun yet frustrating 4x game. It's still very glitchy, but the chrome keeps me coming back. Though play-time is shortened immensly from previous versions, at 5+ hours, it's still a weekend-only game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
