=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Have played several games now and, while fun, is really too long, slow-moving, and complex for what it tries to achieve. Some of the big problems involve the components themselves: The ships are much too large for the hex tiles--which are themselves fairly large. The player mats don't utilize their alloted space very efficiently and the flavor text for the races is wasted space that could be better used for something else. The Secondary Ability on the Strategy Cards should be printed on the backs, since players are usually performing their secondary ability action while the card is face-down. After that... Combat is fiddly if there are more than a couple ship types, techs, and action cards involved. The game is laden with several kinds of small cards which must be kept track of. Games drag after initial expansion phase. Turtling is a big problem...

What do I like? The opening turns of exploration, development, posturing, and sparring are fun. A game to just 10 turns can be fun. Deciding how to spend/allocate command points among Strategic Allocations, Fleet Supply, and Command Points is pretty fun. Battles with a up to a dozen pieces on a side are fun--mainly because they mean a lot if that is the best both sides can muster.

RATING: 7

I think the game would have played better if some of the secondary objectives would have stimulated conflicts ; for example "the first player that invades another player's planet gets 2 VP" 

Best with 4 players (plays quicker)
Much too slow with 5 or 6.

Runewars is leaving the collection but TI is staying.  Something about this game makes me want to play it!

RATING: 10
What a fantastic game. It has it all. Politics, intrigue, war, threats, manipulation, backstabbing. It takes a LONG time to play but well worth the time investment.

12/30 - 4 player game, 6 hours to finish, Played as L1Z1X Mindnet. Had control of Mecatol Rex and secret objective of having Mec Rex w/ a space dock and 6 ground forces. Was backstabbed by an 'ally' that came in when my home planet was shabbily defended and took control of it. I lost out on a Victory point because of this. Never got to finish my secret objective because the Imperium Rex card came out on the first turn of Phase 2 Objectives. Winner was Emirates of Hakkan with 8 VP, the others were at 7 and 6 and I had 6 VP as well. 

1/6 - 5 player game,Played as Sardakk N'orr. Imperium Rex bit me again. I was 1.5 rounds from winning and it had a 33.3% chance to come out. Person in the lead was devastated. Had no home system left and barely any fleet. He won when it came out.

5/26 - 5 player game, played as Naalu Collective. Person with the Clans of Saar jumped out in the lead and the rest of us never caught up. He won with VPs, our first time the game didn't end with Mecatol Rex coming out. We played with Shattered Empire expansion and strategy cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This one has been hotly debated over its lifetime of three versions and people tend to either love it or hate it. However, after initial reservations based on the strong tendency for the game to reward "turtling," I have had to adjust my assessment upward, especially with the release of the expansion which fixes much of what I found problematic with the series up to that point. The expansions offer a myriad of extras and options such that the whole series is really a game kit out of which you can make almost anything you want in a 4X space game.

Nonetheless, a persistent issue is the long playing time, even with the "fast-start" options. If you can picture yourself playing "Civilization" (the classic AH version) then this may be for you. The release of "Eclipse" has likely replaced this game for many as the "go-to" epic space-opera experience based on its more reasonable playing time and slick design. I do wish from time to time though that I could get my group to give this another try. This truly is the "Magic Realm" of space-opera games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm unsure of this rating. The game advances too slowly and once someone gets the upper hand it's almost impossible to catch them. Have tried different house rules but since it is a 4 hour game anyway there's almost never anybody willing to play it. I haven't tried the expansion yet, and I hope we will get around to it someday soon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Rating based on limited play - looks great but it's a long game (maybe too long) and the chit activation mechanic seems a little unfinished. Retreats for example are odd, you can only retreat to a system you've already activated - meaning it's possible to retreat forward (with careful chit placement) or be in a position where you can't retreat at all ... I prefer TI2.

RATING: 6

What I don't:  Too many objectives involving, and therefore too much emphasis on, Mecatrol Rex.  Hardly worth having big battles over any other system.  Action cards (for me) add too much randomness and extra time to the game.  The Political Action might be great in another game, but just added more down time and complexity to an already epic game.  At this point I would take out the Diplomacy and Political roles, and thus the action and political cards. Also, I would like to see better objectives, including one or two race specific along with the secret objective.

RATING: 9
I love the deepness of this game's mythos.  It's not just a game to play, but a story to tell and retell.  Yes, this is a monstrously long game, but I've always been partial to completely immersing myself in a world for hours on end.  The difficulty is finding other gamers who want to share such a lengthy and immersive experience.  High quality components, a modular board, and an inspired turn control system adds to the appeal.  A never-ending supply of rule technicalities detracts, but it a game this big and complex, I'd be more surprised if this wasn't the case.  This is my style, even if I can't find others to play very often.  It's a definite keeper.

RATING: N/A
Trade/Sell
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is like a longer and more involved game of Nexus Ops, I love the variability and depth in this game.  With Secret Objective Cards, Public Objective Cards, Political Cards, 10 Races, A good Tech Tree and a random Map this game will never be the same twice.

Twilight Imperium gives you an individual empire, then provides you with an opportunity to develop and deepen the individuality of that empire by expanding in terms of resources, influence, technology and military.  You can pursure different strategies and seek to develop along differnt lines, technology is the quickest way of stamping some individuality on your race for the game, but resource rich empires will get to build more, influence rich empires will have a serious impact on the direction Political Cards take the game and rules - and this can have a significant impact on the future of the game.

Players must actively peg back other players, they must be aggressive and in some cases merciless, if they want to get the edge that will help them win.  In this sense players must demonstrate some gamesmanship, cunning, clever play and be able to take on the metaphoric 'role' of their empires, threatening where required, blustering and bluffing where necessary and cutting their losses when a deal or situation goes bad.  This is not a game for the faint-hearted.

Altogether this game is a very enjoyable experience I look forward to having again.  I like the way the game keeps you involved, even when it isn't your turn, a game of this size needs to.  I like the many avenues open, and despite everything I had read and heard to the contrary I really liked the pace and time it takes to play - things happen quickly and the game time seems to go swiftly.  This is a real joy - I am very happy to own it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Too bad the game stagnates into a turtle-fest where attacking someone else is a sure way to screw you both. My friends and I gave it a couple of tries but this was one game that just didn't cut it.

RATING: 8
As originally presented with the Imperial Strategy Card the game is a 6 because while it is neat, being forced to select ISC for your first choice and Initiative for your second choice really sucked almost to the point of making me prefer the old second edition. Using a house rule to fix that problem such as just ditching the ISC card completely makes the game an 8, and using the Shattered Empire expansion makes it a 9.  In fact, I can't really imagine playing the game without the expansion now that we've used it. Makes me believe that the saying that Fantasy Flight releases incomplete games that are fixed by their expansions might really be true.  Too bad you have to pay $80-$120 to get a complete game.  But wow what a game! I prefer the 14 point game as the 10 point one ends too soon even though the length is more monstrous. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My prefered game without any doubt. Very deep and interesting
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Finally played this after months of talking about it. The rules are very complex at first (especially if you are someone like me who has never played Axis and Allies and who doesn't play war games generally) and yes the game really is very long! Once you can find people to play against and the time to play it, on top of learning/teaching the complex rules, the game is good. The role selection mechanic (along with the turn-order and secondary action considerations that go with it) is really what makes the game interesting: choosing between acquiring or removing command tokens, gaining free techs, getting action cards or choosing new objectives, etc., can be very tricky and provide a great amoung of strategic depth.

UPDATE: Who am I kidding? This game is a bloated, overwrought monster that because of its size, length, and complexity pretends to be more interesting than it really is. We will never play this again. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm actually shocked at how much I enjoyed this.  I typically hate Fantasy Flight Designs, but everything seems to work really well.  It can be a brutal game, and if you don't take it too seriously, this is actually a great time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Twilight Imperium is the ultimate Ameritrash game.  Awesome space ships, unique alien races, piles of dice.  All these things, built up around a fun, strategic core.

For me, TI has the perfect mix of theme, luck, politics and strategy.  Players must plan carefully, negotiate well and make good alliances to have a shot at the victory.  The game rewards a focus on objectives, while still providing lots of room to build up your civilization in fun ways.

The usual complaints are that the rules are complicated or that it takes too long to play.  The core of the rules is quite simple, but as with any game with dozens of unique player powers and thousands of cards, there will be exceptions.  Luckily, there is such a community built up around this game that it's easy to find answers.  As for time, in our group, we almost always finish in under an hour per player - a long game, but not nearly as long as Advanced Civilization or something.

RATING: 3
Had to lower my rating of this game because of excessive turtling (we even tried making a smaller map to stop this) and dumb luck, which can really make this game unenjoyable and drag out for the unlucky player... If the board happens to be set up so you have few resources near your home system, you're effectively screwed for the game. If you're supposed to play this for the next 3 hours, you shouldn't be screwed before you even start, that's just poor design. Luck plays too much of a role for this to be a game you play for the strategy. Don't buy it if you like to battle a lot either. Sometimes the political cards and negotiating/bribing with other players can be fun if the game is close, but that's about all the real action you get. Read Alexfrog's review to hear more, he put together a list of grievances. Make sure you do your homework on this game and decide if Alexfrog's comments bother you before you drop the cash for it; it definitely isn't cheap...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The most epic fail rules of all time.  Easily 90% of my games involved the big forces teaming up against the weaker guy.  How lame!

Epic fail system that promotes attacking the weak players.  Epic fail system that doesn't allow a surrender option in the rules when it's hopeless which would have been useful in 100% of my games.  Now because of that 5 out of the 6 games I've played...  Someone has quit(50% of my games), threatened to quit because this game sucks(2 out of 6 of the games), or someone has whined about how much this game sucks while playing it.

Now, you may think these stats are impossible, right?  Kublacon 16 hour game (1 person quit by putting all 15 CC's into fleet without a fleet - suicide...), anonymous#1's house (everyone quit because the outcome was obvious but we didn't want to play for another 3 hours to find out), PbF#1 Letnev threatened to quit by leaving for half a month, PbF#2 Yssaril quit in round 1 turn 1 (Basically; if it looks like you are not winning; just threaten to quit or demand a reroll), Anonymous#2's house(houseruled all VP points open to everyone, ?? still threatened to quit because this game is $$)..

There was only one extremely houseruled game where nobody quit and it ended pretty fast.  The person who won never attacked anyone, and never was attacked.  That says a lot for this game...

Hence, a game that MUST be houseruled to be even playable is NOT a game at all.  I would easily give this a zero for the game play and crappy rules, but the components and story/theme is worthy of a point or two.  All you are buying here is the components and story; but you need to create the game yourself to make it playable.  Perhaps you can play TI with pure roleplay with a GM, just like in D&D roleplay games.  At least this way the broken rules can be GM'd away.

Epic attempt for an epic fail game. 3 out of 10

RATING: 9.25
With 2 Expansions:
- Shattered Empire
- Shards of the Throne

Play it 3-4 times a year, but oh my, what a great 3-4 days a year I have. This game has flaws- but they become part of it's charm. After 8 hours of play, the only description of how I feel is: gamergasmic

I have won a couple of games being a warmonger, with plenty of dice rolling, yes. However, I have also won a game (8 hours) without ever rolling the dice, not once. There is plenty of diplomacy in this game, which if played right, can steer you out of luck dependent situations (such as battles with dice).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Played this for the first time in many, many years recently (with the first expansion which was a first for me).

So first up: I have a heavy bias against these types of extremely long "epic" games with tons of rules overhead, etc. It's just really, really not my bag. [i]Additionally, I'm not even into 4X games[/i] as they tend to be all about turtling, which I really dislike, and is certainly true of this game. Being the first to strike at someone else generally just means you're opening yourself up to attacks from other players.

That said - with the first expansion mixed in this is about as much fun as I can have with one of these kinds of games. I can genuinely have fun with these, but it's very much a mood thing for me.

This game still gets a 4 because without the expansion's replacement role cards, the game of keep-away that happens with the "gain 2 vp" role card just irritates me. Yeah it makes the game shorter, but christ, there must be other ways to achieve that (play to less VP, for example) without instead making the whole game revolve around this one stupid role card.

Unsurprisingly for an "epic" American 4X game, combat is pretty cumbersome and mostly revolves around a fairly standard roll-to-resolve system with some swingy action cards to shake things up. It also becomes increasingly long and complex as the game progresses as players obtain more relevant tech, with no real interesting decisions to be made during combat rounds. Building up your fleet and tech trees is fun and satisfying, but I will always take a game with more going on [i]during[/i] combat over this.

And speaking of tech trees, one of my huge complaints with this game is just the presentation. It feels like there's been no attempt made to help the players keep track of their ever-changing stat bonuses and perks. In a game with SO much to keep track of, having these dinky little tech cards all over the place just doesn't cut it. The game would have benefited HUGELY from some kind of adjustable character sheet (ala Eclipse). The next time I play I'm definitely going to try out one of those fan-made iOS apps, because the way it is now is just garbage and does nothing but lengthen the game unnecessarily.

In general, it feels like there's a bunch of neat ideas here that presented some real balance and length issues and the way the designers attempted to correct them is just to add a ton of swingy content and these little micro-systems all over the place. 

For example, the only way I can imagine the leaders are a necessary part of the base game is if they're there for balance purposes. But addressing a balance issue by adding in this tiny ancillary system that feels like it could be removed wholesale just makes me rage. It may seem like a small thing but all of these little things add up.

And don't even get me started on the swingy content. Ancient Artifact, where you can wipe someone out from Mecatol Rex entirely? Or how about all of those "You win the game!" objective cards? All of these things speak to greater issues with the game.

Update: Last time we played I tried one of the iOS companion apps - it really, really sped the game up for me. So (a) I highly recommend using one if you're going to play this and (b) I have confirmation that the game's poor presentation w/r/t your units' ever-changing stats, etc., slows the game down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
A little bit too long for this type of game. The action cards are a big let down - surely a highly intelligent race would be able to make its own decisions on what it can do, rather than being given a random event they can perform. It also feels like there is something missing half way through, and the battles can take quite a long time, and hence the downtime can be quite frustrating. Most of the new mechanics have been taken from the likes of P/Rico. Stay with the previous edition, much quicker gameplay, downtime a fraction of 3rd, and a four player game can easily be completed within a couple of hours. Pieces are certainly a lot better in third, but that's all that's better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Beautiful production.  Oodles of bits.  Huge color rule book with lots of optional rules.  Is that good?  Time will tell.  Plastic mini's are a pain to get to come out clean.  
Initial Reaction:  Some action cards can really effect the balance.  In the second round the Sol player had a card that gave him advanced fighters.  Advanced fighters allow the fighters to fly around without a transport.  Fighters don't count against fleet limits.  Fleet limits is one of the three things that you have to balance with command tokens.  Understand?  I will need more play to determine how much the action cards really turn things upside down.   Edit 8/31/08:  Some things in this game are not balanced.  Does a game always have to be perfectly balanced to be fun?  TI3 suggests the answer is no.  With lots of options and the right people to play with, this game is FUN!!!  I'll move up to 9 and there it may stay.

It didn't.  Other more elegant games, scratching the same itch, have replaced it for me.  Still good memories and good game.

RATING: 8.5
The best 4x sci-fi tabletop game. 

Though you have to play with people who play to win; if your friend brings his girlfriend, and she plays kingmaking for him or vice-versa, it's impossible to stop his/her victory. You have to manage very limited resources to expand your empire in every direction (colonizing, techs, fleets, defenses, laws, victory point, diplomacy etc), so if one player gets support in exchange of out-of-game benefits, the balance of the game goes thought the window and 2/3 of your friends will feel like they lost 6 hours of their time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Bought TI3 and its expansions from a guy as it is one of the games any serious gamer must have played at least once I think. However, I quickly realised that I would probably never get it to the table as I don't know a lot of guys who would be willing to spend 6-10 hours+++ on this game... But fortunately I later got to try it twice (so far):

In the first game, I was positively surprised by Twilight Imperium 3. While I certainly don’t want to play it all the time, and probably only a couple of times in a decade (due to its massive length!), it is actually not a bad game. I had feared that I, being a hardcore eurogamer, would hate it, but it actually has a lot of euro features which I was very fond of. Sure, you roll dice etc. and the combat can be very random and swingy (along with MANY other random elements...), but the main mechanism is about role selection and fulfilling victory conditions which give you points, and the first to 10 points wins the game!

I like the tech tree and various technologies (although it can be a little overwhelming and confusing the first time), the secret objectives (such mission cards, which can also be found in games like Nexus Ops, is something I love), the various units, how you spend actions points in three different areas etc. 

But the length of the game, yikes… That, along with the random die rolls which can mean a lot and is especially annoying when playing a game lasting for at least 8 hours, is the main reason why I don’t always want to play it. But, to be sure, I had expected it to be much worse. After my second play, I have decided to lower my rating as it is too long (the game took 10 hours with 5 players; a couple of beginners and the rest had tried it before). Also, there was too much luck to my taste with the hidden tokens on each planet - I mean, what's up with the fact that you can lose all of your troops, while another lucky person might get a free tech?! Even if you play it with the rule that only good tokens are placed around your starting planet, it's still random and unbalanced and actually loses some tension. Furthermore, it sucked extremely much to have the game end in a 3-way tie after 10 hours...

I am willing to try it one more time, but it has to be with 6 players (as the game doesn't really work with 5, even if you use the setup variant), and people have to be willing to negotiate. Still, in 10 hour I can play SO many of my favorite games instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The set up phase is fun but can totally wreck your chances of winning if your home system gets surrounded with wormholes and empty space (unless occupying the wormholes is your goal). After three or four turns the game can stagnate if no one is willing to attack first. Some races' special abilities aren't much cop compared to others. The base game needs a few fixes which are addressed in the Shattered Empire expansion. The Imperial card, for instance, that gives a 2VP bonus is a dull but essential choice and can screw up the chances of players near the end of the initial turn order if they don't get to pick it as often. Rated a 7 with 3 players. Not so good with a full complement simply due to the downtime.

--update. After much deliberation on the ISC (which is Imperial Strategy Card I finally figured out, wondered where the SC part came from 8P), I have decided I hate it.  The timer on the game is the 'end-game' mission.  The ICS is stupid and forces role selection and diminishes all the other roles.  I say, just throw it away and play with the other cards; not sure if that variant works but that's how I feel about it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Players: 3* − 6
*2 player variant available.

Very large game with an epic play time. Rules are not as fiddly as you might think, with something so grand, and are generally understandable after a few rounds. Borrows a lot of mechanics from other games, but blends them well. 

The victory point mechanic seems out of place in a Fantasy Flight flag ship game, given their current Ameri-centric lean on the game market, however it becomes a necessary component. Without it, the game would be a great deal more shallow.

If the game was meant to be won by obtaining the most planets, or having the largest war fleet alone, then any other action wouldn't be a viable strategy, however this game excels in the fact that other strategies are completely viable. It's much more than just "Risk in Space". The victory track helps here, keeping track of players achievements in all areas of the game.

While many decisive events within the game are decided upon by conquest and war between players, aspects such as politics, trade or technology are not overshadowed and serve to offer balance and alternative paths to victory. Focusing on a singular strategy leaves a player unguarded, one way or another. Switching focus plays a big part throughout the game.

Components are decent, adding a lot to the theme. The presentation can get quite cluttered, but all and all each bit serves a purpose. With players' vast, omnipotent view from above, it all seems a touch impersonal, compared to other games in which you're pushing plastic around. 

The story up front is very rich, but mainly goes out the air lock as soon as the game is underway. Flavor text seems best coming from the political cards, strangely enough. 

The political mechanics are one of the more interesting aspects of the game, to me, even though they are paper thin in a lot of cases. The only real hard-fast political rule is diplomacy, any other deals or favors are subject to betrayal, just as real as in real life.

Player elimination is a possibility... and in a game this long, that would suck. A lot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Awesome game.  I'm not overly fond of the role-selection mechanic in a game like this, but the rest of the game is sooo dripping with theme and appropriate mechanics that its completely forgivable.  Takes a very long time to play and needs a dedicated group to tackle.  When you get it on the table, though, I have not found a more satisfying multiplayer game, period.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
What if Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri was made into a great board game? The result would be TI3, which combines diplomacy, civilization building, and an Axis & Allies warfare-in-space game into a single 3-4 hour time block (which is acceptable to me, as a Miniature gamer). I would have no problem playing this game anytime, anywhere. 
Only two problems plague this game to me: one, like many others, I am disappointed by one of the Strategy cards that gives victory point directly - it's not a matter of measuring the exact amount of victory points to give in order to make it comparable in power to the other Strategy Cards, it's that the ability to give victory point directly should not be a power at all for the game). Second, (also a big gripe amongst people), the game's box is unnecessarily big - I fit the game into a box only 2/5 of the size of the original box, which actually allows me to bring with me to play at other friends houses, instead of being stuck at home.

RATING: 2
Anticipation of what's possible makes this game move quickly - for a while. But, the realization of just how long it takes to get anything of significance accomplished dampens the experience. The theme is great but it's too easy to be put completely out of realistic contention - and the game just continues on and on way past that point. 

It also suffers from the problem of Player A attacks Player B, both are weakened, then Player C comes in and cleans up - which is a classic problem with games that have attrition/triangulation issues. For more on this concept, check out my blog here:

http://mike-compton.blogspot.com/2007/12/triangulation-issues-in-resource.html

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I downgraded my rating from a 10 to a 7. Why? Because I feel that the system is to bland for what it wants to be. All of the alien races have these supposedly cool powers but they always use them for the same end, so it doesn't really matter. When I play with my friends we fall into our roles no matter what race we play because the penalty really isn't that great when we do, so Angel will be aggressive, even if he is the Jol-Nar, Rob will be a pacifist and Steve and I will bicker over resources. Which brings me to another gripe- resources. The game is SO random during the setup. If you get a one planet and the rest space in the draw you can pretty much give up right from the git go  because there is a tight curve you need to follow or be left behind and squashed because you only ever want to attack a player that is much weaker than you so you do not have to fear a counterstrike and mutual annihilation because there are no rewards for combat or consolations for losers. Often what will happen is player 1 and 2 will get into a fight severely weakening both sides, so players 6 and 3 will attack their neighbors and face little opposition. At least they fixed the ol' ISC in the expansion. Even with all this said I am still up for a game, just not as much as before.
Update 3/08
House rules to the rescue! I have finally found a good game with a few house rules added- now you get 3 planet systems, 1 wormhole/empty sytem and 1 red system durning set-up, Play with the ancient Empire varient WITH the Buracracy card, so that there will be twice as many objectives out, vote for Voice of the Council is manatory and its VP are PERMENENT, play with arfifacts, but use all artifacts avalible and add blanks when each playerr places one, play to 10 VP. Played like this 3 times and WE FINISHED EVERY GAME! AND IT WAS CLOSE! The winner usually bribed heavily early in the game to get a voice of the council vote or two, then took or had to defend key artifacts for a win, they were really great games!

11/08

personal preference, I can no longer teach newbies this game as there is just too much for me to explain, if someone new wants to learn and play then they would have to read the rules and especially all of the action cards before hand before I would play with them.

12/08
I think that we are pretty much done with this game, It is a great game when everyone is in the right mood, but poor otherwise with a great deal of downtime between turns.

10/09
Should be playing this soon again, probably with more house rules, I think 1 AC for the loser of a space battle, 1 Trade Good for the winner would work well, same for ground invasions, except perhaps the attacker couldn't get a card if he lost.

If you're into these sort of games, TI's rules will simply blow your mind with its depth and many cool mechanics such as different laws (i.e. rules) coming into play that the players must cast their votes for or against, or how about having both space AND ground combat? There's even a freakin' technology tree covering no less than 24 technologies! I admit it, I'm amazed. But really - this game IS just as good as everyone says it is, while still not as complex and difficult to learn as one may THINK. Throw in the expansion and this game gets a 10 out of 10. Wow...

RATING: 7.5
I respect what this game is trying to accomplish in becoming an epic space civilizations game. I'm a huge sci-fi nut. I've enoyed playing Masters of Orion for years.  Unfortunately, I think my window for getting really excited about this game may have closed. We'll see if more playings change my preliminary rating.

After my introduction to the game, there was a lively discussion about strengths and weaknesses and possible tweaks.  I am convinced that there is probably the right combination of variant rules to make this game really work, although I'm not so sure the rules out of the box do that. Granted, I realize I may be desiring the game to be different than the designers intended it or than another player may be looking for.

I just doubt that I have the interest to play a game this long and this light.  I have too many heavier games sitting unplayed.  If I want to play a game this long, I'd rather it be die Macher the majority of the time. I'd be up for this maybe twice a year at this point.

My biggest disappointment is that I want  a variety of strategies to be viable...but they aren't. I want a player to be able to win by military conquest...but its not possible. I want a player to be able to gain power through diplomatic maneuvering and calling votes....but he can't. I want a player to be able to gain victory through economic domination, but it doesn't work that way. You win by meeting a number of objectives that seem rather arbitrary to me. 

I know people won't ever play it with 4-6 players as it ought to be played, but for my money Babylon 5 CGS is superior to this game by about an order of magnitude.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've flucuated on my opinion of TI:3 for well over a year now and I think that finally, after the release of the Shattered Empire expansion, I've made my peace with all of the minor flaws and quirks in the game and I've come to realize that it is- bar none- the best game of its type likely ever released.  It's really an amazing piece of design considering the vast scope and scale of the theme that it plays in a very reasonable amount of time while managing to present a fairly comprehensive game rich with detail, atmosphere, theme, and excellent mechanics.  There's certainly no lack of depth or player interaction in TI:3- to play the game is to be engaged in a much larger picture, reacting and negotiating with other races while jockeying for position and reaching for every victory point or objective possible.  Sure, there's some shaky bits here and there but to drag them out into the light really just magnifies the fact that this is a huge game with so much _good_, and so much _great_, going on that these problems are really quite minor.  My biggest problem before Shattered Empire was a general lack of momentum which was largely precipitated by a lack of focus in victory conditions.  Playing with the new strategy cards and the Age of Empire variant, this doesn't seem to be nearly the game-breaker it once was.  TI:3 has become one of the _great_ games, and it is likely to be one that is savored and enjoyed for many, many years to come.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Now, with the Shattered Empire expansion, this game goes from good to great.  The expansion fixes everything that held TI3 back and adds some new stuff.  Don't play without it if you can help it.

Small update:  14 point game is just too long.  Players have too much downtime, and the progression of points (at least in our game) were just too slow.  Granted, having the objectives 5 planets outside your system, 10, and 15, didn't help.


This game is an odd beast.  It has some thing in it that drive me nuts--brutal player elimination, unbalanced secret objectives, overly long gameplay, and very random combat.  Also, players who do not take the time or are polite enough to think about their move while others play, is just plain annoying.  However, everytime I play this game, I like it.  Played again this past weekend (5/25) and once again enjoyed it and got to try a new race.  This game is not perfect, but its fun.  I really want to try a 3 or 4 player game to see how it plays.

Races Played:

Saardak Nor x2 (loss, loss)
Yssaril Tribes x2 (win. loss came in 2nd)
The Federation of Sol (win)
The Winnu (loss, came in 2nd)

Variants Tried:

Age of Empires:  This give you more options for planning ahead, and certainly gives the game more flavor.  I think I slightly prefer the chaotic nature of not knowing the public objectives except each turn they are flipped.  Both are good.

Imperial II (new power cards):  These are good.  I really like the update to Imperial.  Having a power that everyone takes just because it is 2 VP is just sillly.  However, if you play with this and the other "tweaked" powers, you need to play with Age of Empires.

Artifacts:  Not a fan.  They seem placed just to create more conflict than anything.  I don't hate them, but I don't think it really added much to the game either.

Distant Suns:  I like this variant a lot.  I cannot see playing a game without it.

RATING: 8
The game with something for everyone.  I think I'd even start to rate this higher if I could just get to play a game without one person at the table learning it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
After one play, I'd say the game suffers from the same problem as a lot of these types of games -- the slooooooow build-up of forces and then the explosion of battle. The first half of the game was a crawl, and then things started to pick up. However, the dicefest nature of the battles means fights are slow and create a lot of downtime for the other players. I want to give TI3 another shot sometime soon, though.

Feb. 4, 2008 -- I finally got to play this a second time yesterday. I still haven't made up my mind about whether I like it or not, though, so my rating will remain the same. It seems like the public objectives are far too random. It would be nice to know what I should be doing to gain VPs. Instead, I feel like I'm floundering around waiting for a sign from the game as to what I should do. 6/10

March 22, 2008 -- Although we still slipped up on a few minor rules, we got the core rules down pat this time. This led to fewer rules arguments, less looking up of rules and a better game. For optional rules, we used the Shattered Empire strategy cards (with Bureaucracy), Distant Suns, Age of Empire and Caretakers of Mecatol Rex.

The addition of the Age of Empire option made the game much more enjoyable and allowed for more long-term planning. The public objectives ended up being very heavy on technology, so that made for a fairly tech-heavy game, I think.

While we had fun, the game took about six hours from start to finish, and the last hour seemed to drag on and on and on. I knew I was out of the running (from poor tactical decisions in the last few turns), and that's when everyone decided to go full throttle in terms of warfare, making for a very long turn with a lot of player downtime. In total, we had eight turns of gameplay before we moved the turn marker to Imperium Rex.

I'm still not fond of several elements of the game that I feel detract from my fun. Combat slows things down too much and creates too much downtime. The style of combat mechanic is one I'm not fond of. The pace of the game does rely a lot on the players, though. If they don't think about their moves ahead of time or are too slow to do things, TI3 can get really bogged down.

I'm not going to be in any hurry to play again, but if the owner of the game wants to get it on the table again in a few months, I'd probably join. No change in rating. 6/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After my third game of TI3, I upped my rating from 9 to 10. This is simply an outstanding game. The number of options available to the player, from combat to technological advances to diplomacy and negotiation, provide a wonderful variety of entertaining choices to make. The dynamic nature of the game setup as well as the sheer number of races and action/political cards make the replayability factor on this game very high. My only regret is that I cannot make enough time to play this game every week.

Note that I've only played it with Shattered Empire (incorporating various combinations of rules from that expansion, but never using the original ISC). In my opinion, Shattered Empire is a must-have. Nearly everything in it is an improvement.

Edit: I'm bumping this back down to a 9. I love the game, but its serious drawback is the difficulty new players have in picking it up. A game involving new players generally drags. If you have a regular group that can play on a semi-frequent basis, it's a 10. Otherwise, if people are having to constantly learn/relearn/remember the rules, it starts dragging.

Edit 2: Down to an 8 - family life intervenes. This does not get to the table frequently enough due to length and complexity. Sold.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The game is massive and often takes six to eight hours to finish with four or five players. And. I. Love. It.

I've owned this game since 2006 and my copy has seen dozens of plays. I have the expansions. Nowadays we pull it out for a play too rarely, but that was expected when I and my friends chose this get-a-family-and-start-working-and-have-an-actual-life business. Still, when we play this game the experience is epic.

If you are looking for an epic strategy game with a multitude of ways and tactics to victory and have ample time to finish each play this is the game. Look no further. On the other hand, if you and your friends are not prepared to sit down for six to eight hours to finish each play, this game is probably not worth it for you.

Pros:
- Diplomacy. Oh sweet diplomacy. I might just have estranged my closest friend in real life but I just had to extort those three Trade Goods to finish that Dreadnought fleet. Onwards to victory!
- Changing and complex map. Why do I have to start next to two supernovae and you guys start next to a bunch of lush worlds filled with innocent seafaring unicorns?
- Rules to come out of your ears. Well, actually, the rules are not that bad to get down and it's relatively simple to get going but once you start to cheat with those Action Cards that break the regular rules you are in an endless swamp.
- Varied races. I shall play with the ruthless Space-Gollums, you play with those Furries that try to trade their way into victory. Sneers.
- Research. Develop your race and leave your petty roots behind. Where you once relied on tin cans and x-ray lasers now you hop around with slave wormhole generators and blast at enemies with antimatter bombs.

Cons:
- After the map for the play is generated you can see who will probably struggle and who will probably be a strong contender for victory. This can be a bad thing due to the lenght of each play. It's not very fun to play for eight hours when you know you probably won't be even close to winning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Love the epicness of this game. A bit tough to teach - I learnt it from the tutorials online.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Maddie
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best Science Fiction space based epic euro game on the market PERIOD!!!  And the Shattered Empires and Shards of the Throne expansions to TI3 are awesome too!  Twilight Imperium 3 has it all - conquest of the galaxy, economics, politics, technology tree, moving target victory conditions, space battles, lots of unique alien races with starting special abilities, and a million different optional rules between the base game and the expansions to constantly change the dynamic of play and replayability.  This game scales well and can handle up to 6 players (8 players with the expansions) - although I usually prefer 6 around the table.  The galaxy uses hexagon tiles and has everything from planets to asteroids to worm holes to Ion Storms to Nebulas to Super Novas to many, many more tile types with the expansions.  The game pieces are cool molded plastic pieces.  The alien races are artistically tasteful, and with the expansions, there will almost always be different races in play in every game played.  TI3 can be a long super heavy euro style game taking anywhere from 5 to 14 hours to play.  I usually prefer to have players commit to an entire day starting in the mid morning, knowing that the game may be over in the afternoon or may go well into the evening.  There is also very little downtime in TI3 as players are constantly negotiating, cutting deals, threatening other players, voting on laws, planning their next move, reacting to other players primary action by taking the optional secondary action and oonstantly evaluating the target opportunities on the board for scoring victory points.  The combat involves rolling lots of 10 sided dice and most space battles are fought to the death.  Planetary invasions can follow as well.  This game is not for the feint hearted and should be played either after watching videos online or played with an experienced player at the table.  Lastly, this game has undergone constant development and change over the years to get to the polished level it is now at.  TI3 is one of my top 10 all time best games I enjoy playing!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Bought it, never had a chance of playing. Sold before moving out of the country. Would love to try it one day. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Astoundingly cool game suffering somewhat from a long play-time and much more from a myriad of rough spots which need (or benefit greatly) from filing down / houseruling: ISC, overpowered Fighters, underpowered Dreadnoughts, Microtech's badness, and more.

Situations can arise (both due to the board-building procedure and racial selections) where one player or another is in a notably better or worse position. [EDIT: This can be mitigated by using some partially-preset board arrangements, available online.] The imbalance can be easily compensated for via table dynamics, but the game is diverse enough that recognizing any but the most eggregious of such cases can take some experience...and getting that experience will take a while, as the game isn't fast. 

If you don't mind making lots of house-rule tweaks, your play-group is OK with keeping track of them, and you like games with ambiance, this is  fantastic.

But if you're looking for a beautiful masterpiece of mechanics, you're not going to find it here, and if you don't want to deal with house rules...well, it's not particularly well-tuned out-of-the-box. It's certainly playable, though, and possibly worth it just for the atmosphere, especially if your group enjoys in-character sabre-rattling. 

As others have said, this is [b]not[/b] a space wargame. It is a space opera game with warships. Very important distinction.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a big, complicated game.  Not for everyone.  Allot more than 6 hours for this game.  It looks like a wargame (and it is), but is more of a political game.  

Its kind of like "Axis and Allies" (plastic piece armies) meets classic "Civilization" (lead a civ to glory, buy technology) in space.  And winning is about having the most victory points, rather than eliminating other players.  Players can be eliminated though.

Has a bit of EuroGame influence in that people pick roles for every turn (reminiscent of Puerto Rico) and a hex map built by the players (reminiscent of Settlers of Catan), but is really a cut-throat Ameritrash game.  Lots of beautiful plastic ships, and dice rolling.

Original rulebook is like 40 pages, expansion rulebook is maybe 25 pages, and the FAQ is 10 pages.  So it is not simple.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

For big group games with hours to kill you can't go wrong with Imperium.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a great game about sci-fi civilization. You get war, technology, colonizing, politics, everything you could think of. The gameplay also combination of Euro and AT, making it awesome. It's the best 4X (Explore, Expand, Exploit, Exterminate) boardgame to date. Simulates most of everything, there are no other words beside: EPIC! This what you get inside:

- (Lots of) Variable player power
- Many technologies to research, giving special abilities
- Although the ship models are same, but different technologies and race power can give a very different characteristics of gameplay
- Colonizing planet is one of the key to victory, but not always. Enough is the word.
- Diplomacy and negotiation CAN affect your victory.
- Role selection mechanics for determining phase of the game, but not strictly govern it.
- Neat mechanism about action points and movement in this game. 

The base game itself would rate about 2-3 (yes, really!) since it's so broken for 3+ hours game. But the expansions making it perfect. NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE! Even in your 1st play. 

I repeat:
NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE!
NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE!
NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE!
NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE!
NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE!
NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE!
NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE!
NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE!
NEVER PLAY WITHOUT SHATTERED EMPIRE!

RATING: 9
Really like this game.  Wish I had friends up here to play this with.

RATING: 10
NIS.

Also for sale.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
An overwrought, under-developed Frankenstein of a game that practically screams invitingly at adolescent males, yet completely fails to convey a sense of interstellar empire-building to anyone with a solid background in serious science fiction.  The rude proximity of the systems on the undersized map give the game a feeling of conflict in suburbia, rather than across hundreds of light years.  The system works, for the most part, but tries to be too many things to too many people, resulting only in being mediocre in all respects.

The game, without substantial modification, rewards turtling, which results in tedium and yawning in epic proportions, but little else.

Seldom have I seen in a game so much time spent by so many players, resulting in so very little.

RATING: 10

But be careful as only one person can win.

RATING: 5
Played 3 times.  The length kills this game for me. It's simply hard to justify a 9-hour 6-player game of TI.  4-player takes less time (6-hours), and I think it's more interesting.  

More specific problems include: (1) the Imperium Rex card that ends the game needs a re-working; and (2) some beginning objectives are much easier than others.

In the game's defense, however, TI offers a very immersive experience.  It involves a lot of choices and a lot of meta-gaming, paying attention to your opponents, etc.

RATING: 10
A game I constantly am looking to play. The only problems that I have with this game are gamepace and choosing opponents.

Game pace: It is a long game, I don't mind because it flies by, but sometimes the pacing of the game gets bogged down because of a star battle or side conversations. I rate this game a 10 because the game doesn't do this the players do, but it still happens.

Choosing opponents: This game can go sour if you are playing with people who are not fun. I have played games of this where I felt like the life was being sucked out of the room because they don't converse, play rigidly, get angry when you back stab or even just attack them, etc. 

This game is in my opinion one of the greatest games. It is well balanced, has many game mechanics working together in a glorious fashion, many modules to add, wonderful plastic pieces, great looking board, wonderful player interactions, so so much packed into a nice large box! :-)

RATING: 8
The game is too long.  But it can be an incredibly fun strategy AND social game.  As long as you take steps to decrease the length (play with a preset board, force time limits on player turns, allow players to take simultaneous turns, don't play with all possible extra content, keep good track of each player's tech, etc) you should be able to have a good time with this one.

But the 4 hours suggested on the box is a joke.  I can't imagine how even experienced players could find themselves done with a game in less than 5 hours.  Space combat die rolling alone takes forever....

RATING: 9
First play, although incomplete, was very enjoyable! The replay factor is quite high in this game, as so many elements are randomized. Game is much more subtle than simply conquering the known galaxy, although that's an option! Looking forward to more plays soon!!!

Now, with five plays under my belt, including the first with the Shattered Empires expansion, I would maintain my high rating for this game. It can go on a little long, and it may not be perfectly balanced (from one race to another), but it still is a lot of fun and has a high replay factor. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
My favorite "All Day" (read: 8 hours or more) game that I've played.  It wouldn't be as enjoyable had Mr. Petersen not implimented the Euro mechanics in order to minimize the downtime.  I also like the Objectives, which are a necessary deviation from the typical Ameritrash game where you win by eliminating your opponent's units or taking territories.  Don't misunderstand me though, there is a lot of conflict in this game. It's just not the only way to win.  The game emphasizes diplomacy, technology, trading and the rest of the things that go along with empire-building.  There's A LOT of game here, but this should make for endless replayability.  The problem is that it takes an entire day to play and I've read it's best with 6 players.  Still, it's completely worth the time--what a great game!  Epic.

Update: This game is frustrating to me now. After 7 plays, I'm still horrible at it, and I think the issue is the restriction on only being able to claim an Objective (earn VPs) at the end of a turn. Too many times, one small thing has prevented me from completing that objective, and it's just too hard to recover from that. In a short game, this would be easy to accept, but not in a 6 hour game. I still like it, but it's turning sour on me. My gaming time is just too limited to make me as excited to spend an entire day playing just this game.

I don't mind not being good at a game or winning. I can still appreciate a game despite that. However, this game takes about an hour to both set up and discuss/debate which additional content (expansions) to use and which optional rules, etc. Even playing with experienced players, and there is some time delay due to rules referencing. While I love the theme and story behind the races, I am just reminded that this is a pure FFG game. It has the rules bloat, swingy action cards and political cards (less of an issue for me), and just too much chrome. 

All my plays included the Shattered Empire expansion at a minimum. Not interested in playing just the base game, based on recommendations against just that.

It's a great game that wouldn't be near as good without the story and theme. The art is phenomenal as are the miniature sculpts (unlike Eclipse). The gameplay is fun, yet flawed. As I stated above, I have a problem with the difficulty of fulfilling the objectives, which only lengthens the game. The restrictions on Retreat and building Space Docks are just bizarre. The clunkiness of the various techs is AP-inducing and difficult to remember all the benefits. Direct Hit Action Cards change the game too much. No one takes hits on their ships that can sustain damage any more, making that ability useless. Racial abilities are great, but some change the game so much, such as the Pirate race being able to steal trade goods. As a result, no one saves TGs in games where that race is in play. Despite the issues, the experience is incredible. I find 4 players to be my sweet spot. Choose a single role each round. Makes the game easier to get played, and in a shorter time without losing out on anything. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great space opera due to the unique alien special powers and wild politics cards and how there is a lot of space provided for negotiation and surprise reversals of fortune without feeling broken through action card play.

4X game that has a lot of area control and diplomacy as a result.

Great role selection cards with primary and secondary ability game mechanism. Seems like a couple of the role cards work together to create an imbalance which is later addressed in an expansion with alternate role cards.

Thrilling dice combat with both space and land battles.

Lots of rules and phases of play which results in a steep learning curve. Experienced players may be able to play this game in about an hour per player or less.

Modular game variants in base game give a lot of replayability to the game.

Lots of cool minis but it is a pain to cut the ships out of the plastic sheets.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This is a very good civ game, the different player powers making things interesting. Has a smaller but similar problem to Imperial where warmongers can screw someone else out of VP by constantly attacking. A large number of rules, but they only take time to explain, once players grasp that most of the rules are defined by the text on everything and that they can only take 1 action a turn, things will go quickly. There can also be the "Australia problem" where players pile units onto one hex and sweep across the board. You can use your own style of play, but the objectives will often determine how your race develops.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fun, relatively simple multi-player version of Master of Orion done as a board game. After several plays I've had to drop my rating because, with the base game at least, there's a serious disconnect between warfare and victory conditions. The [i]Shattered Empires[/i] public objectives, as well as some of the alternate strategy tiles, are now IMO necessary to make the game interesting, and bring the game back up to an 8 or 9 rating. Another knock against the game is that newbies always get obsessed with building large fleets and attacking without any particular objective in mind. They just want to mix it up because, hey, big fleet!

The playing time can also be a problem, and it has caused me to avoid this game at gaming conventions because, between the rules explanations and general futzing you'll be lucky to reach turn 3. That being said, even a little experience goes a long way in reducing the playing time, probably more significantly than any other game I know.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Epic. I really like this game. It's like Masters of Orion on cardboard. A 4x game; eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate. It provides multiple races offering a diverse set of special abilities, a fascinating technology tree to explore, intriguing politics and diplomacy, and a big 'ol box-o-bits filled with Star Fighters, Dreadnoughts, and War Suns (Death Stars). 

I do have some issues with the game, but none that can't be addressed with a few house rules:

1) It's simply too difficult to get victory points...unless you take the ridiculously overpowered Imperial card each turn for 2 VPs. You could also choose the Bureaucracy card that lets the player choosing the card waste his turn to put out VP conditions that anyone can capitalize upon. I think a Victory Condition should just automatically reveal a card each turn, without the need of player activation. 

2) The game takes 6 hours. While some people would love it if the game lasted 3 times that long, many people would rather have a 3 hour game. I think the above rule suggestion would help resolve this, but the number of VPs required to win could also be reduced.

3) For a game that proportedly involves so much diplomacy, why is it not possible to agree to let a fellow player fly through your star system?!? Solution? Make it so!

Anyway, it's a great game, with a few flaws that can be overcome. It's got that 80's game feel that I love. Check it out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
game of epic epicness
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The following is my opinion.  I have played the game over 30 times.

This is the greatest board game that currently exists. However, to be specific, this is the greatest 4x/Civ/Hex/SciFi/War/Political board game that exists.

4x - Exploration. Extermination. Exploitation. Expand. This game encompasses all of it to the point where most compare this game to the iconic Masters of Orion on PC. In my opinion using the variant of unknown tiles/distant suns makes Exploration that much more rewarding (or painful). Extermination - War....War never changes. Exploitation - Politically or with planets - either way, create.  Expand - encompass the galaxy for VP or dominiation.

Thematically - Few games even come close thematically.  Every race has a deep backstory. This allows players to take on the role of the race, or, to learn more of the story of the overall universe - and just why is Mecatol Rex (in game) such a big deal.

Civilization - Every race is unique.  Every race has multiple abilities that seperate it from others.  It gives players a unique feeling/modifier.  There's a reason you're playing that race.  There are advantages and disadvantages to it.  It's awesome.  Additional unique techs/ship are available in the expansions.

Politics - There is a round for politics.  Players vote for laws that modifiy the entire game.  Or they vote on negative/positive one time effects on players/the universe as a whole.  Political maneuvering, back stabbing, alliances, all share a new form of beauty in this round.  While not everyone enjoys politics, at least in a board game, you can appreciate it.

SciFi - Not much outside of Star Wars Rebellion or Star Trek Ascendancy come close to the deep SciFi elements of the game.  

Hex - Modular based on players.  You and the other players take turns CREATING the univers. Or you can just randomize the tiles.  Either way, it has unique methods of making every game feel new.

War - Dice based combat.  Techs to upgrade ships/combat modifiers.  Quick tactics cards to allow players to swing a battle.  While the combat phase tends to be one of the longest, it is also a lot of fun.  However, there are some small issue that people have with RNC - I understand, but good luck trying to figure out a better method than what is in this game.

I've gone on far more than I expected - this game has more.  So much more.  I haven't played every variance. I haven't played every card.  Rules are complex. the GAME is COMPLEX.  The weight is a 5/5.  

Have fun.  Know that the game will be 5+hrs with 4 or more people.  I've only ever done a few 3 players games in under 5 hours.  

This game truly is amazing.  Highly replayable. Extremely fun. Intense. Strategic.  Litterally every positive adjective.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Lista.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[December 2017 - 8]
I had higher hopes for TI4, and actually might prefer TI3 with some house rules. While TI4 definitely speeds up the game, it also takes away some of the nuance and need for battle. Resources and trade goods flow a lot easier in the update, meaning you don't really have to go take too many planets. It reminded me more of Scythe in that you just try to stay in your little corner of the galaxy and do your thing. And a lot of the objectives re-enforce that by mearly saying... get 10 of these, or that. 

Games like Blood Rage and Kemet accomplish the objective/war/negotiation game much more effectively.

[October 2015 - 8.7]
Twilight Imperium is a tough game to rank. Its length of play (our games have averaged about 8 hours) is a handicap for sure ... but, if you're prepared for it, and only playing a few times a year, then it's a really fun experience.  

My best praise for the game (with its expansions) is that despite the length, after countless hours, everyone can still be in the game. I've played other board games that last about 3-4 hours, and after the first hour, a player can effectively be out of the game and forced to suffer another 2-3 hours. An eight-hour game that everyone is in it is better than a four-hour game that some are not.

Still ... eight hours is a trek and I think there's potential to streamline the game. Some of the expansions help, but in other areas just lengthen things. I find the political process, especially with all the ambassadors, spies and bodyguards a bit of a time suck and laborious. And moving your fleet takes forever. That being said, there is a beauty in the slow build-up and moving around the board. It's the anesthetist of the immediate-gratification generation and gives me that same frustration-love feeling as Few Acres of Snow, where it takes time to build up that perfect force and then move.

My biggest complaint about the game is some of the random elements like the distant suns and relics, etc.  I think the die rolling is enough randomness for me. 

I also find the Speaker token/order a bit uneven. Whoever starts out with it will always be in relative good shape, because the player to his left (who could take it and have the first player now be last) will likely never try to take it, being happy with second choice in the choosing of strategy cards. Meanwhile, the player in last turn has every incentive to take the speaker token, but if he/she does so, then the previous first player now just moves to second. To solve this, I would have the turn direction (for strategic card choice) to rotate back and forth between clockwise and counter-clockwise every time speaker token exchanges hands.

Finally, in teaching this game to people, don't bog down on the details.  Focus on how you score points, how you, build, how you move and how you take planets/battle.

If it was a wee bit shorter this one could be an 8 or 9

RATING: 5
[2011-06-23 Rating: n.a. -> 5]

Twilight Imperium (TI) has a lot of thinks to like. There is the control counter mechanism. I do like that the players turns are broken up into little actions. I don't even want to imagine the downtime, if everyone would do all their actions one after another. (Not that there isn't any downtime in TI as it is.) 
I think the public objective cards are a great mechanism.
But despite of all the thinks to like, I can't rate this game any higher. It is just too long and fiddly. I don't want to invest four to five hours into a game these days. And I don't want to remember all these little rule breaking tricks other players can do because of their tech-updates. TI just isn't a game for me.

RATING: 7.5
It's in space, so it gets an automatic +1. I enjoy playing it, and some of the ideas and mechanics are well done, but for me at least it feels too much like a tabletop war-game, it usually takes far too long (6+ hours is typical), takes too long (the night before!) to set up, and it feels too unfinished. A card for every planet you own, action you take, and technology you develop seems too cumbersome, when there must be plenty of other simpler ways to represent game state (c.f. Eclipse). Great theme and great quality bits though, as one expects from Fantasy Flight.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Idea:
Galactic war/diplomacy and politics/resourcemanagement.

Mechanism:
First create map from pile of hex tiles to create new galaxy each time. Also 17 playable races to make each game different.
Played action at a time until all pass. Before round each choose strategy card from common pool in order that give certain boni. Reveal victory conditions and try to fulfil them. Voted political laws change rules of game.

To whom 
If you like long strategygame (8h) that relies to dierolls too. Base rules have some bad design flaws (to my taste but some dont think that way) but are easily repaired by houserules. If you own copy you can play it PBeM too. Similarity to compugame: Master of Orion, if you liked that this is your game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The longest board game I've ever played, and one of the most satisfying. I've powered through it twice as of this writing, once with just the base game and one with some expansion material (and eight players). 

It's a game that revels in its own excess, and you must be on that page in order to enjoy it. I also recommend playing with people you know, and people you know you like to play with. Because you will be with them for 6-12 hours, and their behavior will affect how much you enjoy this gargantuan game.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
I usually list TI as my favorite game when people ask.  There are others I might rate higher, and due to the length it's not something I feel like playing all the time, but it still tops my list.  I love big 4X space games, and jumped at the chance to learn this, way back when.  FFG has done an amazing job condensing the genre into board game form.  Long and complicated though it may seem, it's actually pretty simple.  You can do this many actions, consisting of these steps.  At the beginning of the round, you pick a specialization that will benefit your race.  Techs give you bonuses and let you break the rules, trade agreements give you cash, and laws impose new rules on the game.

The first thing you have to learn about the game is that only 2 things matter: points, and keeping control of your homeworld (so you can score points).  This also leads to one of the problems with the base version of the game.  
It comes with the Imperial strategy card, which scores 2 points (a fifth of what you need to win) for the holder.  This means that there's a lot less choice in strategy cards than it first appears.  You have to take the imperial card or, if the player to your right is start player, the initiative card in order to get it next turn.  This is by design, a clock that keeps the game moving.  However, there are some serious unintended consequences.  If you get randomly chosen as start player, you get your shot at the points first, when nobody else can really mess with you.  The game will last around 7 turns (give or take), so you'll probably get a second bite at the imperial card, while the person to your left might get one.  This means that the single most important die roll of the game is the very first one, determining start player.  
Worse still, there are action cards in the deck that mess with this progression - either banning someone from taking a strategy card or letting you hold one for 2 consecutive turns - and having one come out at the wrong time can be a major swing.   
Now, there are variants even in the base game rules that will mitigate this.  Reducing imperial to a single point doesn't eliminate the problem, but lessens it a lot.

This variability is one of the game's greatest strengths.  If you don't like an aspect of it, there's almost certainly a variant (official or otherwise) that addresses your concern.  For some reason, this game really sparks peoples' creativity, and you'll find plenty of customized races, strategy cards, systems, etc.  Our group regularly plays with a custom strategy card set nowadays.  

Turtling can be kind of an issue, as most of the public objectives in the game don't require conflict, just accumulating resources and techs.  This is partially mitigated by the secret objectives, which nearly all require you to take territory from someone or contest the central planet (Mecatol Rex).  But you can have games which are all buildup, and then a series of furious space battles in the late game that decide the victor.

The whole experience of the game is about as good as it gets.  You'll begin as a fledgling empire, grow & expand, make deals or come into conflict with your neighbors.  You might make a play for Mecatol Rex, or try and take over a foe's territory, or just sit and defend.  You'll have to decide whether to invest resources in your space fleet or R&D.  Wheel and deal with the other powers to get the juiciest trade contracts and avoid having laws pass that hinder your efforts.  There are so many possibilities, so many cards and planets.  If you can cordon off a chunk of time to play this, it will definitely leave an impression.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I love this game, and I love spending half a day playing it. Other people, not so much. Unless you have some hard core friends to play this with, it won't get much play time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Impressive components, very thematic game.  TI3 fixes a few things from TI2 (such as components, PDS/fighter/ground force cost, makes Mecatol Rex more important, technology less expensive, more balanced trading, better objectives for victory—although the objectives need some tweaks, such as more combat-oriented ones).   But it leaves much untouched which needed changing, such as very sluggish/static play, excessive game length, often irrelevant political cards, unbalanced map and technologies, and no formal alliance system (except the diplomacy strategy card).  The new rules for command counters/limited activations and strategy cards are interesting and make the game seem new, but increase the analysis/planning in the game and increase the energy and dedication needed to play, and thus restricts the playing opportunities further.  I question the more-detailed combat units in a game that doesn’t really encourage a lot of combat.  A playtested variant should have been included for a simpler, quicker conquest game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I finally got my hands of the actual game and we have played 2 4-player and 1 6-player games since. FFG has made a masterpiece here. Normally, I would knock off a point for the playing time but in this case, it is actually a good thing. I could not imagine playing this game in 2-3 hours only. There is nothing wrong in this game and it is scalable with optional rules if your desire more or less luck/playing time. A lot of discussions have happened aroung the 2 pts. ISC but in our 3 games so far, this was not a problem at all. Call me a fanboy. This to me is a classic and well deserves my rating of 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.13
The ultimate game in my collection, which I abandoned because it was too difficult to move from place to place so I left her with my gaming group in my hometown.
It is the heaviest game I played, full of intrigue, drama, thrill, role play and a whole bunch of exceptions and house rules.
I think it is the mother of all space opera games. The setting and the lore are beautiful, although borrowed from every space themed classic you love.
I love the way every race is conceptually totally different, and I love modular hexagonal space board which offers so much replayability.
But great stuff oft come with dire consequences. The game is too heavy and so immensely long. It is impossible to finish a game in less than 6 hours. Setting up and cleaning up alone take almost 1 hour. We always include one meal order in one session of TI.
Besides that, there are quite a few imbalancing and limiting factors in the basic rules which are easily avoided with two awesome must-have expansions.

[b]Edit:[/b] I have a huge amount of unrecorded games.

[b]Edit:[/b] Upgraded to from 6.5 to 7.5 with Shattered Empire expansion.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] 17 awesome, conceptually different asymmetric races that you can choose from.

RATING: 4
As an attempt to design a "Master of Orion"-style boardgame, I would give this game a 10 for ambition and effort. However, perhaps the ambition was too great, as TI3 fails to deliver on gameplay. The production quality and detail are great and others have waxed lyrical on them but they don't save the game completely. The glacial and unengaging game play, particularly in the time it takes to build up a fleet may appeal to RTS players grown on a diet of Command & Conquer, Warcraft etc, but is unacceptable in a boardgame. It takes so long for anything to get done that players simply lose interest halfway through the game. Teething problems will ensure that there will be a TI:4, and 5, and 6....

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Writing about Twilight Imperium while trying to be synthetic is really hard.
It is a Huge game, in many ways.
It requires a huge amount of time to be played, a huge number (6 is huge for my gaming group) of hugely experienced and "devoted" gamers in order to be played optimally (and a huge amount of tablespace).
It has a huge number of flaws rules-wise and balance-wise.
But it has tons of flavour in it, and one can enjoy it immensely in the right situation.
It gives the player an incredible degree of freedom in managing its empire, and provides an exciting amount of interaction with the whole table.
Unfortunately, I was able to play it satisfyingly only a couple of times, so as of now for me it is still a big unfullfilled promise.
If you can meet all the requirments, it is an unparalleled game.
I'm still waiting for all the stars to align in order to have my chance to play TI at its finest.
Until then, rating is an 8 for its potential.


After having many more plays under my belt, all I can say is I still feel like there is something I cannot grasp.
Ii is a great game, has an epic feel but it's very very hard to play it regularly and gives me the strong impression that there is a lot of potential that hasn't been fully exploited.

If I had to rate it just considering how much I enjoy playing it, I would rate TI a 10, but considering its "weight" and (minor) imperfections, I think 8.5 is more appropriate.

Considering the weight of the game and its far-from-perfect balancing, it goes down to a 7 for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3.363
I used to think this game was the greatest thing ever.  But the more I started playing games that took less time, were more developed and balanced, and not-so-darn fiddly, I began to hate it more and more. 5/31/2012: No change in rating.  I just wanted to continue to rant about how much I do NOT like playing this game.  That is all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I appreciate the complexity of this game, but it also has many nuances that I feel will always leave bad tastes in my mouth for a game that requires this much time and energy. For the most part I wasn't a big fan of the victory point goals, the bland stats assigned to ships for god-awful dice combat, the ridiculous swinginess of the action cards, and the confusing slog that assigning/distributing combat commands create each round (yes, pretty much the whole game. It's not necessarily for me, but I DID like it and want to play again).

However, the universe that was created here is so epic and beautiful and demands to be played and experienced. The races felt unique. I enjoyed setting up the universe at the beginning of the game, and given the opportunity I really think I'd have fun trying some different approaches with the Tech Tree. There's a lot of fun game here to play with, but it's just a shame its so hard to get actual playtime out of it and so much of your effort planning out turns can be destroyed by someone else getting lucky card draws and/or die rolls.
