RATING: 4
The time spent on this game is not completely wasted but in comparison with what could have been played in the same amount of time, it is very hard not to be disappointed.  The role choosing mechanism is a nice touch until you realize that the #1 and #2 are always the same.  The different player power are not evenly balanced.  I can understand however that other players might like it; we spent a lot of effort coming up with possible fixes and tried a variety of house rules.  In the end I'm pretty sure that there may be a game under the chrome yet, I'm just not in the mood to fix a game especially if I have to shell out as much dough for such a big box.  Hello?  Who has the shelf space for such behemoths nowadays?!?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I enjoy this even more everytime I get to play it.  This game has become one of the favorites in my collection - enjoyed by everyone in the family.  I usually play with the "Age of Empire" options regarding ISC card.  I find the 2-player game lasts about 2 hours, the 3 player game goes for 3 hours.  It takes 4 hours when I'm teaching the game for 3 players.

This game gets played a lot within our family.  It's my wife's favorite game.

The expansions are all very cool.

Check out my tutorial/walk-through at http://www.preeminent.org/steve/games/ti3/ti3demo/

I think one of the reasons I give this game such high marks is that it's a "sandbox".  There are no real boundaries or path set to how you should play the game.  Yes there are certain logical things to do when you begin the game because you need economic strength, but this game as a high level of freedom.  Even with the longer game length this requires, it still gets a lot of replay ability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
On paper, this should be my favorite game of all time.  My one play was with four other rookies, and I'm guessing we were half to two-thirds done with no end in sight before we called it.  Everyone was exhausted and brain-fried, and at least one person had no desire to play again.  Also, many of us wished there had been more political activity.

Still, I haven't given up on it. I like the idea of the preset maps on the FFG website, and there are some variants in both the main rulebook and the expansion (Age Of Empire, Imperial II strategy card, and simulated early turns, for example) that I wish we had used in our game.  In fact, the expansion looks like it addresses nearly every issue I have with the game, so who knows.

EDIT: I have a friend who owns Eclipse now, so I may never play TI3 again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.11
Updated 7/7/08

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekbuddy.php3?action=doanalyze&gameid=12493&groupid=4204&B1=Analyze]Ratings[/url]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Pros
-lots of strategic options available every time/turn
-tactical timing is immensely important
-very detailed and good variety of game play elements
-lots of components, high quality components (but somewhat pricey)
-promotes aggressive play (as opposed to turtling)
-lots of variants including in book
-social game, lots of negotiation, politics etc
-players need to be involved at all times

Cons
-difficult to learn initially, information overload, hard to analyze what options to take during game play
-long game (I can't find anyone to play!), setup also takes fairly long
-lots of pieces, fiddly and very spacious (takes lots of table space)
-not a fan of some of the strategy card (but expansions remedy this)
-possible king making or ganging up (esp on player in the lead), may be unfair and ruin the experience for that player
-political system seems a tad weaker than expected
-dice based combat can be frustrating
-downtime between actions may be very high (i.e. combats you're not involved in)
-requires minimum 3+ players, ideally more
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It is a FANTASTIC game.  However, I rated it so low simply because TI3 isn't a game, it's a lifestyle.  Blocking out a day to play just isn't all that possible too often, and when it is we start to lose steam around hour 5.  I play Descent and Imperial Assault less often nowadays because of the setup time, so it should be clear that Twilight Imperium hasn't come out of the box in years.  In fact, it has recently been relegated to the storage unit.  Not getting rid of it, its a game to keep forever, but I don't foresee playing it more often than once every few years.

RATING: 8
I played my faction wrong but still enjoyed the game. This is a long game and that should be considered before sitting down to it. If you enjoy in depth war games with goals and changing roles this is a game for you. I enjoyed the San Juan style jobs which were selected by a revolving first player and then the remaining jobs were passed to the next player. Each job gave different bonuses and along with planetary resources allowed you to perform specific actions for that round. Unpicked actions were not played. The type of action was also assigned a value and more valuable jobs went later in the rotation for the round. This is a complex game with several rules and I had to ask about specific rules several times.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Vale cada minuto. No jogo cada um comanda uma raça interestelar que tenta construir um império galáctico. O jogo tem muitas peças, muitas regras, muitas estratégias mas passa longe de ser um jogo difícil. É pesado, sem dúvida, mas não é difícil. A mecânica do jogo é basicamente escolha de ações primárias, realizadas pelos jogadores que a escolheram, e ações secundárias, permitas somente para os outros jogadores. Intercalando com essas ações os jogadores tomam outras decisões como, movimentar, atacar e/ou produzir. Inicialmente ocorre uma corrida por setores e planetas vazios, desenvolvimento tecnológico e formação de frotas. Depois quando os jogadores se encontram nos mesmos setores ocorrem as batalhas. O jogo também tem uma parcela de conflitos decorrentes das questões comerciais e políticas. A resolução das batalhas é feita de acordo com as os números que saírem na rolagem dos dados (D10). As unidades têm características diferentes como, por exemplo, custo, velocidade, capacidade e o número mínimo nos dados para causar danos as naves inimigas. As tecnologias e habilidades das raças melhoram ou pioram essas características. Os objetivos, secretos e/ou abertos, ditam o progresso do jogo e as estratégias dos jogadores.O fato é que o jogo é bem envolvente e cativante. Vale cada minuto. Infelizmente o tempo e o peso dele faz com que seja um jogo para jogadores experientes (gamers). Isso diminui as oportunidades para jogá-lo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This is an impressive large scale space combat game.  I don't like it nearly as much in the original form as the expansion.    Improvements to the almost every aspect of the game are found in the expansion so I rated it higher

RATING: N/A

I have't quite decided on the ISC yet, i'll give it a few more games. The fact that a game that takes as long as TI hit the table three times in one week however, shows how great i find it, despite its flaws.

RATING: 7

RATING: 7
Played it several times with two different groups. And the gamed was played total different in the two groups. 
Group one. (5-6 players). TIE3 should have been our upgrade from Axis & Allies, wich we have been playing for several years. Played it 4 times with an average playing time of 14 hours, in these games there have been a lot of turtling, early player elimination and  of course a lot of down time. After the 4. play noone would ever play this again. Rating 5

Group two. (3-4 players). Mostly have been playing eurogames. The incredible components made this group really want to try this, and it have been fun. 3-4 hours playing time, lots of smaller fights all over the universe and together with diplomacy, trade and politics, its fun. But in the end its still a race for VP´s.  

Rating 8

So what i am trying to say is, that I think TIE3 need the right group to be a fun game.

RATING: 6
Great mechanics. I sure love that technology tree, implemented with a technology card deck for each player. Unfortunately, developing a beautiful technology for your armed forces has little impact on the victory point conditions, which are largely based on which type of planet you own. Why even bother? If you have the strongest military in the galaxy, you'll probably lose to some stupid victory point cards that have nothing to do with military strength. Revamp the victory point cards or do away with them; then this will be a FUN military game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is great for it's epic scale and cool bits and number of interesting and interweaving mechanics, but those positives  also cause it's one major negative--this game takes a very long time to play.  Just working through each turn can take a very long time and the game can easily go up to 5 hours.  That is why the VP mechanic and the relatively low scoring victory point total are necessary--to make sure the game ends in a reasonable amount of time.  However, the VP kind of undercuts the epicness of the game by making it end at the point when "its just starting to get good".  It's a hard thing to balance, I mean you want the game to end in a reasonable amount of time (and 5 hours is reasonable) but at the same time you don't want it to just cut out in the middle of the action.  Finally, the game needs enough players to make it interesting (3 player is not much fun).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Stunning, epic, space conquest!  It is the kind of game that becomes an event unlike anything else.  You plan for the block of time and the players knowing it is going to be an memorable experience.  This is simply an amazing work of game design.  It has such an immersive narrative that develops throughout that can only happen in a game of this size, length, and scope.  It does have a learning curve, but 90% can be grasped rather quickly if you have played games with similar mechanics before.  Just an awesome way to spend a Saturday afternoon with a group of friends with no distractions.  Can;t wait until I can play this again!

Includes: Shattered Empire and Shards of the Throne expansions

RATING: 1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Twilight Imperium is quite an interesting game. It feels very much like Axis & Allies in space, but with several other modules running the show and a Puerto Rico-like actions selection mechanic that I like. I think what is most impressive about TI3 is the ease of play. I don't think I had to look in the rules more than twice once starting, and this is a long and at times heavy game.  Everything feels balanced, wonderfully thematic and chromed-out.  But i realized about 5 hours into it that TI3 isn't a game for me.  I just don't think I have the stamina to take on a 6-8 hour game.  As well, I don't find the game deep enough to really justify the time.  There is a lot to do to build forces and plan your attacks, but it all feels a little repetitive in the end.  Maybe it's because the game is so long?  Also, I'm guessing that the "fun" comes from building a force (while your opponent does the same) and then crashing into either player's sector and rolling dice forever until someone reigns supreme.  This happened in my game.  I literally spent two hours building up a force and planning an attack on Mecatol Rex.  I admit that it can be an attractive property, and our forces were somewhat balanced so it was worth a try.  But here we go, I roll a lot of bad rolls and my opponent rolls a lot of good ones.  I am wiped out and she stands alone at the end.  But considering that was my plan for the last 2 hours, did I just waste my time?  Should I have planned other contingencies?  Was it possible to do so, considering the public goals and my private goal which required Mecatol?  These are questions that I could answer if I spent more time with the game.  But I have SO much fun with other games that are also battle games and I can get it done in a few hours.  For me, 6 hours of TI3 didn't feel twice as epic as any 3 hour game, only twice as long.  I will reserve too much judgement on what is clearly a very loved, multi-faceted game, only considering that I have played once.  Whether my feelings about TI3 are just, I do know that this is not the experience I am looking for in a game.  Too long, too stuffy, too sprawling.

1 uncompleted game: Wow. Such an amazing game. I love it! too bad I'll probably be able to play it only once or twice a year. Rating would be 10 if the game was shorter... Much shorter.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pros:
- so many different paths to victory
- each race feels very different. Good balance between all of them.
- I personally had great fun playing this game, with a quite epic race for victory towards the end.

Cons:
- I was hoping this game would please both types of players who enjoy aggression and those who don't but surprisingly, it wasn't that well received by both. The issue is that players who want to play a bit of a fight end up frustrated by the amount of mechanics that is blocking them (diplomacy, action cards, etc) and non- aggressive players still feel under the threat of their neighbour building a huge army and willing to test it.
- One of the strategy cards (Imperial) is not very fun. It breaks a little bit the game, by basically deciding the first 2 strategy cards that will be picked and makes the game poorer. Also, it feels like a design flaw and a weird way to earn 2 victory points.
- Looking at the time investment, the group felt the game didn't deliver up to expectations, which could be because it was the first time we were playing, we'll see.
- the game pace is very exponential, very slow to start with and quite epic towards the end. Some people might like something more nervous.
- with four players, the distance between each player is such that it is possible to mind your own business during the first 3 or 4 turns, limiting player interaction.
- The art of the components is just ok - by today's standards, they are not holding up against competition - Star Wars: Rebellion for the miniatures or Archipelago for the tiles.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Expansion is a must
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Or a technology tree player where players would just sign which technologies they've acomplished.

RATING: 8

Requires 3+ players (6+ is preferred) and many hours of play, but worth the investment if you have the patience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Rating dropped from 8 to 5 as my preferences have changed and new games (especially Runewars) have been published that scratch the same itch, but in much more streamlined package.

Ultimately an ambitious game that seems intriguing to play every once in a while - there is exploration, politics, warfare and scientific research. The problem is that the game tends to take a very long time (6-7 hours) and move slowly, so even there is a lot of good things in here, they get dragged out. I also dislike the way the PDS units bog things down by being able to control large areas of the board too effectively.

Definitely recommend using the new strategy cards from the Shattered Sun expansion.

RATING: 9
This game is absolutely fantastic, but only if you enjoy long games. If you are looking for a quick in and out game that is simple to learn, you are barking up the wrong tree. The game plays best with six players and someone should have a very firm grasp of the rules so they can direct play, otherwise things will bog down and kill the fun. The game is big, long, expensive, and complicated. These aren't knocks on the game, it's simply what it is. What you are rewarded with is an epic gaming experience that combines diplomacy, technological development, warfare, intrigue, and space exploration. If you have the time to properly devote to learning and playing the game, this is the best of its kind.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
I finally got to play this epic game after hearing so much about it. It didn't disappoint but it is a bit different than I thought it would be. Very excited to get this one out again.

Several plays later. The game has two main problems. A lack of a robust political system and some of the strategy cards have awkward abilities that are rarely used or easily "gamed" by the players. I still enjoy the game but I am not as excited by it. I think they need to move away from the strategy cards and create more flexibility in board position and a more robust political system in future editions if they ever release another one.

I own all three editions of this game, so there's some nostalgia in this rating. I really enjoy the combat which is heavier than risk but not as heavy as a hex/counter game, love the player interaction, love the new roles, the technology tree, which was innovative when it first came out, has been streamlined effectively, and the components wow'd me!  Loses 1/2 point for still allowing for some turtling. Those who rated this a 1 should go back and see what a 1 rating is supposed to reflect.

RATING: 8

RATING: 9
[b]Twilight Imperium III[/b] [i]Cristian Petersen 2005[/i] 
What an epic game Twilight Imperium 3 is! Im not a fan of space games but I must admit that this one combines almost flawlessly (it has some minor issues though) many of the best features of other games. Superb plastic bits, beautiful systems, a ton of cards... Fantastic game that has also a lot of an euro system in its core rules since combat is not enough by itself to achieve victory.  Of course, diplomacy and resources management also count a lot. Both expansions fix the issues and make this game better. Original design deserves an eight but this rating is improved to an almost perfect ten with the two excellent expansions.
110€

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Twilight Imperium (3rd Ed.) is a fine game for players who like deep, complex games that take days to complete. I've played three or four times for several hours and have yet to see a game fully completed. The closest we came was acknowledging that one player would have won in the next go-around. It's great to have such depth of play, but you just have to be willing to invest several hours in a game, and this one goes on just a tad too long for my tastes. If you like strategic complexity on a high level, then you'll likely love Twilight Imperium. If you're looking for a game you can actually complete in less than half a day, you might want to look elsewhere.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I captures everything I love about pc games like MOO or Glactic Civ, but I get to play it with my mates in person, which is just so much more fun.  A bit complex at first, but once you learn it, it's well worth the time spent.

That said I think this game can be very rewarding and exciting, and it can easily be accomplished in 4-6 hours of consistent play.

RATING: 9.5
A space epic with large amounts of care put into it. I've spent a solid 2 or 3 hours reading all the race sheets and cards (with descriptions/quotes) alone, the world that FFG has crafted is spectacular. The game play is top notch as well with dozens of options per turn and a terrific combat system. I only have a couple of quibbles with the game, 1st, I don't like the fact that you can turtle your way to victory with Imperial. Secondly, that you can only apply for one public objective per phase. Though with the application of the Shattered Empire expansion and a house rule or two, the game became an absolute hit.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Another Space Game...go figure.  This game has massive replay-ability, but be warned it takes no less than 4 hours to play. 

The "bits" to this game are excellent, very well done.  There are lots of them.  I went out to Walmart and bought myself one of those sorting tool boxes to keep all the pieces separate.  The box is massive enough to hold this tool box so all is well.

This game is best played with 4 or more players.  I think this is a great game for the handful of times I have played it.

The 44 page manual seems a little daunting at first but with the help of other players we managed to figure it out on the first play.  

(Whoever at Fantasy Flight Games said lets put the manual online so everyone can read the rules had a great Idea)  The easiest way to play a game is to send an email to your friends saying ...on game night we are going play this new game I bought, go to this link to read the rule book.  "AWESOME"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Favorite galactic civ/empire type game I've played.  It has nice components, trade, combat, resource Mgmt, etc.  Worm holes and command points help prevent some of the "turtle" defense build up tactics that plague other conquest games.  Evenso, this isn't primarily a heavy conflict game at it's core, merely part of the game.  I think that's why I like it so much.  There is much more going on than a typical sweep the board conquest game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Seems far too long and convoluted for my tastes. VPs are very difficult to come by and so taking the Imperial Card is almost compulsory. If I want a space exploration/combat type game I'll probably play Nexus Ops. If I want a civ/combat type game I'll probably play Antike. Both much shorter.

Edit: I decided to give this another go but this second game took even longer and we didn't even finish (6 rounds played in 8-9 hours). The game isn't bad as such, it just takes so long that if I'm going to be playing games for that length of time I'd much rather play several other excellent games than this one. I also think that the hidden objectives and the turn order will basically decide the winner, i.e. someone who is able to complete the hidden objective and who is early in the turn order to pick up the Imperial card for a second time will almost certainly win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Don't be fooled. This is THE ultimate space opera simulator. RATING: 6
Seems long time-wise, but is fun if you have time to burn.  I would prefer a dice-less(or at least smaller variance than d10) combat system, but I like the way that hit points are dealt with to keep from bogging down combat. I also prefer a smaller pool of random draw cards in a game that is driven by player interaction.  Large amounts of different cards are more necessary in games with less interaction.  

Also, I have to say I only played 4 player and would love to see the bonus counters in action.  Hopefully, we will play 5-6 player next time.

RATING: 7
How I setup the game:

Strategy Cards
1 - Leadership
2 - Diplomacy II
3 - Assembly
4 - Production
5 - Trade III
6 - Warfare II
7 - Technology II
8 - Bureaucracy

Base Options
The Long War = No
Age of Empire = 50/50
Distant Suns = No
Leaders = 50/50
Sabotage Runs = No

Shattered Empire Options
Imperial II = 50/50
Strategy Cards = Yes
Objectives = Yes
Race-Specific Tech = Yes
Artifacts = No
Shock Troops = 50/50
Space Mines = No
Wormhole Nexus = Yes
Facilities = No
Tactical Retreats = 50/50
Custodians of Mecatol Rex = Yes
Voice of the Council = No
Simulated Early Turns = No

Shards of the Throne Options
Preliminary Objectives = Yes
Flagships = 50/50
Mechanized Units = 50/50
Mercenaries = Yes
Political Intrigue = No NO NOOOO!
Fall of Empire = 50/50

The Embers of Muatt = ok
The Nekro Virus = ok
The Ghosts of Creuss = lame
The Mentak Coalition = lame
Federation of Sol = ok
The Emirates of Hacan = lame
The Clan of Saar = ok
The Barony of Letnev = ok
The Winnu = lame
The Yssaril Tribes = ok
The Lazax = --
The Yin Brotherhood = ok
The Arborec = ok
Universities of Jol-Nar = ok
The L1Z1X Mindnet = ok
The Naalu Collective = ok
The Xxcha Kingdom = lame
Sardakk N'Orr = ok

--------------------------------------------------------

ah, once a '10', falling due to expansion creep and bad play.  Now, a '7' is the best it can be because I will only play it under certain circumstances.

The rules under which TI3 will be played again:

1.  No colluding players; way too much of players deciding before they game that they won't be attacking each other.

2.  Players must understand how VP scoring works.  Turtles and attacking/screwing for no VP 'because I can' need not apply.

3.  The long war (14VP); no.  longer does not equate to better.

4.  Distant suns; no:  added game time and luck for no real benefit.  Good luck versus bad luck here can be a real balance swinger.

5.  Leaders; okay

6.  Sabotage runs; not worth the mental overhead

7.  Shock troops; okay

8.  Space mines; no.

9.  wormhole nexus; okay

10.  tactical retreats; okay

11.  custodians of Mecatol Rex; yes!

12.  Voice of the Council:  50/50.

13.  preliminary objectives:  50/50.

14.  race-specific tech:  yes

15.  Flaghips:  50/50.

16.  final frontier:  no!  another balance-altering luck factor that adds to game time.

17:  Mech Units;  50/50; the ambiguity and BS rulings about when these are Ground Forces and when they are not makes me want to not play with them anymore.

18:  Mercenaries;  yes, adds a cool element.

19:  Political Intrigue (i.e. Political II or Assembly II); never again.  added game-time and the nonsense of 'I assasinate you because I can' take-that.  Promissory Notes are similar that it adds time and except for game-throwing I Support the Throne, a waste of time.

Includes Shattered Empire, Shards of the Throne, fleet bases, and painted miniatures.

RATING: 2
Setting aside the fact that it encourages turtling, setting aside the fact that the rules are a poorly-worded affront to usability, setting aside the grotesquely unbalanced everything (cards, chits, powers, etc. etc.) that have a huge effect on the game state, setting aside the fact that the victory conditions are at best stale and at worst utterly broken, setting aside the fact that the components themselves are some of the least user-friendly I've seen... RATING: 8
Good: Strategic - Sience Fiction - Medium 

Should be played with the expansion.

-Awsome theme, beautiful script
-Simply unsurpassed compomemts
-A tiny price for what you get. Best value game I have ever bought.
-Playable. Not complicated at all and best if someone already played it to show how it works.

The ultimate game that is playable and incorporates military, economy, trade and politics into one game. Simply the most brilliant game ever invented that works, is accessible and fun to play.
Yes it is long but it is long FUN!!

My only tiny quibles:
-Fighters are slightly too strong compared to the price you pay for them
-A war Sun or destroyer both count to 1 ship against your Fleet Supply and this feels a bit odd. 

This is the ultimate gaming experience is really difficult but if you have mastered all factors: enough time, the right players, repeated sessions, you probably had one of the ultimate gaming experiences one can have in life.

If this would only be a game about nowadays politics on planet earth...
Please print Reins of Power!!

Update: recently played a 6 player game with expansion. I was the Nekro Virus and this race ROCKS! The Nekro Virus can only obtain technological advances by stealing them from neighbours.
If their mother ship is distroyed, it destroys all other ships in that space as well.
One of the political representatives can blow himself up and kill all other representatives.
We had a great time and the changes throught the expansion are worth it.



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A well intentioned game, I guess. And well crafted, too. But there's three things that make me doubt I'll ever play it again:
First, it's design is driving your actions less by giving you lots of things you can do and letting you decide what you want to do most and more by stripping you of possibilities and letting you decide between everything that remains. Not really my cup of tea.
Second, it doesn't feel like the guy who wins was the best at building and maintaining a space empire. It feels more like the guy who wins did the right arbitrary (and sometimes even unthematic) stuff at the right moment and cashed in the most points.
Third and most important, it's just not worth the time you have to invest in it. I can get the fix of everything this does in a shorter time with a game that's more fun. Maybe not everything at the same time, but individually.

RATING: N/A
# of Players 3 − 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Huge space opera game! This one has it all: Politics, research, exploration, expansion, ground and space forces, different classes of ships, and tons more. Quite good mechanics, too, with variable turn orders.

Politics, notably, denote "table politics" more than "ingame politics cards" - the ingame ones might be able to change the game's rules, change what's an act of war and what isn't, or change how much income people get or what they can research at what cost, but don't really influence alliances between players directly (though of course, getting friends to help you push the agenda you really want is always a good thing).

What's really great about this game is the scope it has, and the depth that comes with it. It's not just a really long game, but a really engaging one as well.

Also works very well (but takes a very long time) in PBeM form. And I still feel bad about the PBeM games I abandoned :(
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is epic - there really isn't any other way to describe it. There's politics, economy, negotiation, exploration, battle, logistics, and more. Granted, to do all of these things almost immediately requires a whole slew of rules but here, it's more of a guiding framework which is broken/reinforced by rules and unique cards. So there really isn't anything you can't do, so long as you have the cards that allow you to do so, which makes for a lot of clever surprises throughout. Furthermore, because the game creates something not akin to a rubber band, but rather a molasses of point acquisition, it is difficult for a leader to emerge - however, once a leader does emerge it is difficult to stop them without some collusion and collaboration. This is a nice feature as it means that there is an ongoing and necessary checking of power between players, shifting alliances and crafty collusions. Accordingly, as a necessary feature, the game has a first to 10 points (space objectives which can not be undone), or most points when the "game end" card appears such that there is always movement towards an inevitable end. While this game is certainly longer than what I tend to play, it doesn't feel as long as it does and, as you would hope, there are big game changing moments which feel epic (great/devastating depending on which side of the equation you are on). I won't say it is elegant, clean, or pure, but it is certainly a well-designed game whose mechanical structure (or framework) allows for a rich, thematic inter-player flow of events to occur.  


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The ultimate strategy/civilization/conflict/ area control game - it really has it all. If you can find enough players dedicated to set aside the time needed to play this game, it is a fantastic experience. Rules can be somewhat overwhelming for some players, although I find this much easier to grasp and more intuitive than some other games in my colletion (e.g Arkham Horror). At least one of the players have to know the rules before playing for the first time - it is not a game where you can look up everything as you go along.

Replayability is close to endless with the different races and the variable starting universe. The Shattered Empire expansion is recommended.

I just wish I had more time available to play this and that I knew a few more players willing to play such a long game.

RATING: 6
I can see why this game is so highly revered. It is a good game, but a real investment in both time and effort from the players. I would almost say that I think that this game is a hobby all of its own. To fully inhale this game, you got to know everything about the strategic tiles you can choose, know the special abilities of all the races in play, know what the diffrent leaders do, and finally know the possible action cards that could come in to play.

For me, this is just a little bit to much of a game. I can play this game a couple times per year, but that's about it, it is just so heavy. There is simply just too much to keep track of in this game. I really understand that the real strategy-game lovers appriciate this one, but I'm just not the target audience...

Wonderful production when it comes to the ships and board, really good looking!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Wew!

A massive game that takes some studying to get to grips with, but that rewards you handsomely for doing so.

All I can say is that if you can gather a few players that have the stamina to learn the rules of this game and set aside a huge chunk of time exploring it, you'll be rewarded. If.

The time component always gets brought up, and for good reason.  This game can easily last 60-90 minutes per player!  And with 6 or more players, you'd need to include another 90 minutes lunch or dinner break.  That's half a weekend's commitment!

On the positive side, you'll not feel as if that much time has passed, since this game has a good narrative feel to it, and players feel involved most of the time.

Another plus point is the game's affinity for modification.  Optional and house rules are worthwhile investigating, and some more recommended than others.  Finding a good, working set for your group is half the fun of exploring this behemoth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Good game. But I think Eclipse offers more for less. The economy seems to have more dimensions in Eclipse, the technologies are more straightforward in eclipse... and in Eclipse I've never seen a player eliminated.

The danger as I see it of playing this game with new players is that they see the purpose of the game as being to fight each other and control territory. Planets are key to gaining resources but you should NEVER lose focus of the goal which is to collect victory points.

Petty border squabbles over meaningless planets that do nothing to get you points do neither player ANY favours. If a less experienced gamer spends his whole game doing this at your expense then it can suck the fun out of this thing in a big bad way. Unfortunately I've now been in that position. I've been in said position in other games and it can be 30 minutes of boredom then playing something else but with this particular beast it is unfortunately up to 6 hours of utterly relentless boredom.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Epic in every dimension.  And, despite all the ISC brouhaha, it plays just fine right  out of the box.

UPDATE:  This is still a great game, the experience growing more rich and nuanced as we become more familiar with it.  This is definitely one of those games that requires repeat plays—difficult for most, I know, as the first couple of plays can be excruciatingly long and fraught with error.  All I can say is stick with it; like the monster games of old the wonders in this box are only revealed through familiarity.

[b]ISC and other tweaking:[/b]

The best version of this game is played with the Age of Empire & The Ancient Throne variants.  AoE, found in the rulebook, lays all the public objectives out in a row and allows for long-range strategic planning.  AT, an official variant found on Fantasy Flight's website, changes the ISC to 1VP if you control Mecatol Rex—in addition, it allows you to earn as many VP objectives as you qualify for, all at once.*  It makes for a longer game (with no 2VP clock counting it down) but with far more interaction, with emphasis on the ACTION!!!

[size=7]*This is also now the Imperial II Strategy Card found in [thing=22821]Shattered Empire[/thing].[/size]

[b]Board setup for more interaction:[/b]

Take the best double systems and place them randomly around Mecatol Rex (so the first ring is made up of resource- and influence-rich gems of the Empire).  Then build the other rings as normal.  This prevents the usual layout of the galaxy—with players each residing in their own premium "turtle pockets" that are bordered with crap while the throneworld of Mecatol Rex languishes in a backwater ghetto.  Surrounding it with double systems forces players to move fleets up the ladder and into sweaty proximity around Mecatol Rex for a turn (or so) of hard stares and eye-twitching until someone pulls the trigger on the Last War and makes the jump for Mecatol.  With everyone having a fleet one hex out, the game becomes a Rolling Storm of Woe mitigated only by political shenannigans and shady trading...

UP-UPDATE:  Aw, hell... who am I kidding?  With the advent of the [thing=22821]Shattered Empire[/thing] expansion, this is a rock-solid 10.  Slathered miles-deep in theme, diplomacy & intrigue, massive space fleet engagements & ground combat—there's nothing else like it.  Nothing even comes close.

For more info, try my award-winning (!) session report:

[thread=354414][b]In Which the Peoples of the Galaxy, Wowed by Boobs, Willingly Place Their Necks Beneath a New Boot[/b][/thread]

RATING: 9.5
This is my favorite board game of all time, I don't care that it takes all day to play, I don't care that it requires two and a half acres of table space, I don't care that it's so hard for new players to get to grips with. I will ALWAYS make time to play TI3 :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This, the archetypal American big box game is yet another multi-player conflict affair in which the best strategy is to 'turtle'. There's certainly no shortage of ambition in the design. This is an empire building game which incorporates conflict, trade, diplomatic and technological elements. You'd hardly expect a game this big to be balanced, fair or free from chaos and sure enough it isn't. The random setup can give far more opportunities to some as the tiles are not equally valuable, similarly the strategy choices will see the Imperial and Initiative tiles taken first with the rest a mediocre option. It also has the usual arbitrary player attacks, luck of cards and dice and the possibility of kingmaking.
In spite of all the above, there's still a good chance of having fun. Nothing is too 'thinky' so you can relax and chuckle at others' misfortune during the inevitable downtime. Although the game takes 6+ hours, time will pass quickly. In the end though you'll find it strange that more of the problems haven't been ironed out over three editions and realise that Tempus is the same game (even down to similar problems) in a quarter, or less, of the playing time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Just too long. If that is no problem... go ahead! :)

RATING: 7
An OK game with plastic figures that are too big for the hexes they have to occupy.  There are so many official variants now that there's bound to be a version to suit all players.

Build up your fleets, send them out to conquer, hope for no counter-attacks during the one turn your planets are exposed.

Remarkably, you can win this game without fighting a single battle.  Try the conflict oriented variations to make the game come alive - otherwise it can seem like 4 hours of accountancy.

RATING: 9

One caveat: you MUST buy the first expansion.

RATING: 5
The role cards (card 8) are totally determining the outcome of the game (if someone strays from the forced path another semi-random player will win the game). =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Part of me wants to love this game. So much about it appeals to me. It was my first foray into the explore, expand, exploit, exterminate genre. With tons of rich content, terrific art, customizable tech trees, specialized races, and a variety of ever changing rules and objectives, there's a lot to love about TI3. Unfortunately, it is a terribly long and drawn out game, often taking upwards of 4 hours to play. This for me is a major drawback, because so few people are willing to invest that much time into one sitting. And if a player gets screwed early the remaining hours of play can be pretty unenjoyable.  We also found  the role card which awards 2 VP just for choosing it to be terribly unbalanced in a game where racing to get points is the whole idea. One person can't be allowed to pick it each time or they win by default, which means players are constantly forced to take it if just to prevent others doing so, but this really sucks fun out rather than adding anything worthwhile. We chose to play without this role, or downgrade it to 1VP, and this balanced things. TI3 is fun, but for a lot of casual, beginner, or just busy gamers it's a little too galactic in scope. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
If you have the patience and if you have some friends who share this trait, this is still the best thing to spend 8+ hours around. I played it numerous times during last few years, I remember games that reached conclusion in 2,5 hrs and I remember one particular match that took a little more than 13 hrs. But this is the peculiar thing - I remember pretty much every TI game I played in details. This is a kind of impression that no other game left on me. Of course arranging a game of TI is a nightmare. Explaining rules to newbies takes hours, and game itself rarely ends on the date it started. Scales down badly - anything less than 4 players feels flat and basic due to limited player interactions.

update -- aug 14, 2011

Just played my first game. In. Credible.

update -- nov 13, 2011

I've played a couple more games now. My first (referenced above on aug 14) was 6 player without any expansions. I've now added a 7-player and then a 3-player, each with both expansions. I took the rating down from 10 to 9 after my second game, and now I've dropped it from 9 to 7. I like the game, but I don't I love it. As the complaint often goes, the length is a bit of a killer. I'd usually like a little more variation in an entire afternoon and/or evening of gaming. I think TI3 will be a great couple times a year thing for me.

--feb 6, 2013--
Maybe I don't like the game quiiiiite as much as I thought? Every opportunity I've had to play since my last game I've turned down. For a game several hours long, I usually tend to crave something like Starcraft or Dominant Species. Hmm. . .

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First off, this is an awesome game.  It's huge, theme-laiden, rich, bit-heavy, and epic.  I really like how you feel connected to your race while you slowly expand your empire.  The chit system is great and trading, politics, technologies, etc. are a nice added touch.  However, the role system (which is a fantastic idea ala Citadels or Puerto Rico) is implemented rather awkwardly and often results in some out of balance trade-offs.  This would be OK in a cooperative game like LotR, but in a competitve setting like this with limits as to what you can accomplish turn-to-turn, it ends up tasting a bit foul.  If this problem were addressed and fixed I would easily volunteer the time necessary to play this mammoth game much more readily.  Still a solid 8 as is.

RATING: 7
Totally understand the appeal.  Great theme, lots of variability in starting races.  And I'd play it agin . . . however, the game suffers from what I would refer to as  "Munchkin Syndrome."  It's a multi-player game . . . eventually, one player makes a move, several other players pounce on that player to keep them from winning . . . and the guy way across the board who neither gets pounded on by other players, nor has to commit any resources to keeping anyone in check, is the one who wins.

RATING: 9.7
Epic Space-Opera from a 4X game where you should have bunch of free time to play but still it worth that. I think TI3 had done everything better than most of mega strategy games. 

It has political struggle, trading, diplomacy, warfare, logistical planning, everything a mega 4x strategy game needs. Then with the late game appears, Twilight Imperium  evolves to a different game, where has so much tension, clashes of long-term strategies and even in the pitiest situation, a player has always chance to win. 

It is fantastic, gameplay offers many options and totally satisfying, delivers unforgettable game sessions.

RATING: N/A
both expansions in the base box, only will sell/trade all together.  base game was received in a trade and the box itself is in fairly rough shape.  Inside, the base game components show a little bit of wear, which I covered by sleeving all the action cards, political cards, and planet cards.  Have the galaxy frame to keep a 6 player map together, all ships, tokens, and dice (have extra dice as well) are kept sorted in two plano boxes.  The expansions have seen one play session, look brand new, but I didn't keep the expansion boxes as the one box will hold everything.  No pieces missing.  Buying the fourth edition.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Strategy can be very deep on this one.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
One of the most famous cosmos backgound games. Twilight Imperium has successfully expressed the great space war among various species in the universe. The game, however, also has a few weak points. First, the game too many rule details so that the game has a high barrier to new participator of the game. For example, the game contains hundreds types of cards. Players cannot get used to those special cards in couple of games. At least more than 5 times matches, users can gradually understand how to use appropriate cards and make a proper strategic decision. Second, the game is not really influenced by players' tactical choices, but the better upgrade situation. A diplomatic approaches, strategies, and dice luck is not really working in this game. The aspect of game is mainly affected by the upgrade level. The higher, the better chance to win. If a player has higher upgrade level, the player has more winning conditions. Therefore, it is hard to catch up technological gaps among players. Because of all of these notorious accessibility and hard rule details, I couldn't give a good grade on the game. Besides these weaknesses, Twilight Imperium is still the one of the best space war games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ideal Players: 6

Description: An extremely complex roll-and-conquer type game that uses some euro-game mechanics like role selection. Research technology, build infrastructure, and conquer the galaxy!

Pro: Technology, politics, and trade all add unusual dimensions for a roll-and-conquer game. Because victory is by Victory Points rather than territory, conflicts are encouraged to be over some meaningful objective. The strategic depth in an 8-hour game is enormous, especially with experienced players.

Con: It requires an 8 to 10 hour time investment, six skilled players, and the most table space of any game I know. Despite all that strategy, random dice can spell victory or defeat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
OWNED SINCE 2011
I love this game. Although it can be long, every one at my house enjoys it and it gets played regularly. My smaller kids, ages 7 and up, enjoy building an army and exploring the map or attacking other players (When I play with the younger kids, I have them share a veteran player's "tech sheet"). My older children, 10 and up, really get involved with the game. When playing with our kids, we usually start the game in the evening after dinner, take a break, and finish the next morning once we wake up. It is easy to handicap the better players on this game, so that  everyone can play at their best and not dominate. We also take out some of the victory objects that require a longer game. Players are usually close in "victory points" regardless of the size of their army. Bottom line, it is designed to customize and can fit everyones taste. People I have board gamed with, who do not find the science fiction theme appealing, have enjoyed this game. When we feel like getting involved in a game, this is one of our favorites. I must say that we never use the little "tech" cards that came with the game. I printed out one of the tech trees found at BGG, player made, and we use that to track our technology advances. I also printed out a technology advancement tracker, also player made from BGG, and we use that to keep track of ship upgrades and such. I print them both out on one piece of paper, using both sides of the paper,and we just use a pen to mark what we have. This frees up a lot of cards from the table and makes it easier to remember what you have. IMO, a must have for the game.  
 UPDATED 2014
This game is called complicated. I have also heard it called long. Well, It is not Complicated. In fact, it is one of the few games that I can pick-up after a few months and play without reviewing the rules or player aids. IMO, Mage Knight (which I love) is more complicated (lots more) and just as long (with 3 and more players). I think people have a stereotype of this game that is untrue and prevents them from trying a great game.

RATING: 8.5
It's basically Master of Orion the board game.  If you like 4X turn-based computer games, odds are you'll enjoy this game.  It has less exploring than those games have, but quite a bit more political avenues as well.  The pieces to this game are very high quality and so is the art and rule book.  It is really hard to say anything bad about this game and it has borrowed nicely from Puerto Rico in terms of taking on a "role" each turn.  The only draw back is setup time and game length (6+ hours).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Initial rating 1 play with expansion

Totally overblown but epic game. With the expansion AND a few tweaks, probably close to the best AT game available (my  rating is 8.5 with exp) along with Dune and it reminds me a little of that game with the variable power bonanza, lots of theme, tons of bits, long gametime, a few too many rules but overall a great game of space exploration and civilization.  Typical FF, not completely playtested, ISC is stupid as 2 VP’s (should be 1) plus other little things, some political cards etc, 20 pages of variants tells the story, expansion helps a lot at least but why cant these guys get it right the first time, more outside playtesting damn it!   

First game is a little rough with all the rules/options but it does start to flow nicely once going and I could see my rating going up with more play and a house rule or two (ISC at the least). You can get lucky with the VP chits, not as much of an issue in a full 10VP game but that is one long game, the house rule of 7 or 8 VP's is more to my taste I think, 4 hours is long enough for a multiplayer game.  That is another thing I noticed, it takes some time to ramp up which slows it all down, a faster start would mean a quicker game with more action. Not that much of a wargame again because of slow development, by the time people expand enough the game is winding down, although the full 10 VP game would probably have some more good fights before its done. War should probably be more rewarded too to discourage turtling, like 1 VP for taking over an opponents planet. Reducing some luck with public objectives open at the beginning might help also add some strategy.  

A good strategic game. For me a quicker ramp up and a shorter game that is more balanced (you can say this about almost ALL FF games) would have been a perfect game, maybe some year FF will figure out how to perfect their games.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.4
I've played this four times now, all with the expansion and many of the expansion variants.  Our first game was very long, 9.5 hours for a 4 player game that ended in a tie. It's still a game that I had to fight to get to the table, we like it but no one loves it. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fundamentally a incredible sci-fi game.  Epic, complex, but rewarding. The theme is gripping and the game is beautiful. 

PROS:

- Nice mechanic elements and very good game even though all aspects of the game are stolen:
# map: stolen from settlers of catan, the scenaries change in each game.
# roles: stolen from puerto rico, even on choosing a role with primary and secondary actions on each of eight different roles.
# war rules: stolen from axis & alies, but d10 is very randomize, i prefer d6. 

- Fun increases exponentially with number of players.

- Spectacular and excellent components. 


CONTRA:

However there is only 4 major, unforgivable flaws, that makes the game only a rating 7 for me.

1- Too long. Schedule 8 hours to play. 
2- Hard to teach to new players (has too many erratas, requires official faq 1.2 - http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/PDF/ti3FAQ.pdf)
3- It is not a warlike game, to fight does not serve as much. He is better to stay defensive.
4- The imperial strategy card. 


OVERALL:

With some homerules to fix #4 (read http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/PDF/ti3variant.pdf), consider this game a 7.5 for me!

RATING: 8.3

Playing at 2 to 5 players is great, personally I think 3 players is very good the game is not too long.

I have played more then 15 games playing with different races, provide a very different gaming experience.
impressive work

The opposite of what FFG is now doing past 2008, mostly games created "on-demand", with very limited deepness and immersive aspect

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Grand epic space opera.  Build fleet.  Explore worlds.  Conquer them.  Research tech.  All about getting victory points by meeting objectives on objective cards (like get into a battle or own certain kinds of worlds).  I feel like I should like it more than I do.  Very complex and long.  There is a certain amount of luck in the battles rolling dice and there is a lot of luck in the planet draws.  Can very easily be unbalanced with luck of initial and neighboring planets.  Can be ameliorated a bit if you make sure to balance people's starting allotment of space hexes.  Most tech not terribly important but death star type ships horribly powerful, so not a lot of satisfaction with tech achievements.  Each turn choose a role a la Puerto Rico, which makes for interesting plays.

RATING: 8.5
2-1. It's long, and I like that.  I do like fiddling with the rules to either make it more confrontational or varying the victory conditions, since that is the mechanic I think needs it (N-1).  The turn order mechanics, movement, and resource tracking are are elegant.  Your choices for technology, diplomacy, and trade are wonderful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Amazing game of galactic conquest with war, politics, and plenty of backstabbing. Variants give this game so many options to build the game you want to play.

Play length is obviously a bit long but you get into it and after a while you forget how much time has passed as you're too busy worrying whether your neighbor is going to betray you or not.

2010-07-05

Initial Rating: 9.5 (June 2010)

I LOVE this game. It’s a complex game with many options each turn but thanks to this each game is epic. Also the space theme is awesome. The long play time can be a problem for some people but I like long games. Overall this game is in my top 3.

Current Rating: 9.5
[hr]
2014-04-28

TI was one of the first games I purchased and I continue to love it. However, to be honest, if I played the game today I probably would like it a lot less. Still as one of my first loves, it has a special place in my heart but I’m downgrading its rating :D.

It doesn’t have any complex rule per se, but it has many rules. Also the game time is very long, due to this TI is a medium-heavy game for me. You have many interesting options each turn. TI is one of the few games I don’t notice the passage of time, it has lots of down time (the worst sin a game can commit IMO) BUT I don’t feel it as I’m immersed deep into the game, trash talking the current player and trying to influence him :devil:.

I’m aware that the Imperial card has a minor flaw, but that has never stopped us from enjoying the game, besides if you fix the flaw (adding the Imperial card from the expansion) you also add a couple of hours at minimum! For me, the game is very playable right out of the box. 

Best if played with 6 players (but 5 is also very fun). With less than 5 players, the game can be longer because each player now have to take 2 strategy cards. It comes with many cards and races guaranteeing a big replayability factor. Great art and components.

TI was in my Top Ten Favorite Games of all Time, I had to drop it (along with Arkham Horror) to make space for Mage Wars and Netrunner, still I love it, from the theme, to the epicness of the game. It has intrigue, betrayal, politics, trade, war, technology race, alien races and much more. For now my favorite space themed game (Eclipse is a good eurogame but it doesn’t come near TI for me).

I won’t ever sell my copy and I plan to buy the (expensive) expansions. I won’t ever say no to a game of TI.

Current Rating: 8.5
[hr]
2015-09-15

Twilight Imperium 3rd Edition is back in my list of Top Ten favorite games :D. It is an epic game that features my favorite theme (space opera).

Current Rating: 8.5
[hr]
2016-08-09

Twilight Imperium is a beast of a game and one I won’t ever sell, however I have to be honest with myself. My desire to play it again has been diminishing slowly over time. It continues to be the best 4X game for me, but I’m downgrading its rating once again. With this new rating Twilight Imperium 3rd edition is out of my Top Ten favorite games again.

Current Rating: 7.0

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The game benefits from being an epic event game spanning 10+ hours with immersive roles and swings of power AND playable by 3-4 in a weeknight.  A great design of mixed military, economic, civ-building, & diplomatic games.  The biggest flaw is that the time scales so poorly.  A 3 player game honestly takes 1/2 the time of a 6 player game.  Of course, a six player game is better in every other regard except time.  An irreplaceable part of the collection that plays differently each time.

Edit - Let's change that time commitment to 6.5 hrs for an experienced 8 player game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Dropped rating from 6 to 3. Play time is simply too long:
1 hour setup, 1.5 hours to explain the rules. Then 1h per game turn (for a total of 7 hours), and another 0.5 hours to put everything back in the box.

That's a whopping 10 hours. Totally not worth it. It would take a lot of convincing to ever make me play this again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Loads of fun, and fills the civ-building niche nicely.  Has flaws, but enough fun to overshadow the flaws.  Implements PR-style role selection in a dramatically different game, emphasizing the versatility of that mechanism.  Does tend to drag on a little long, with lots of downtime during other players' Tactical Actions.  Combat is extremely devastating to lose, which encourages turtling.  (I'm a turtle by nature, but it's boring if everyone does that.)

Personal note:  Play at least once with the expansion.  From all the comments I've seen, expansion would likely raise this game to a 10.

Every one of the memorable Political phases will be an unique experience in my whole life due to the rich of agendas included.

RATING: 3
Every major area of this design is mediocre. The systems combine to make it a logistical pain in the ass to accomplish even simple things. That overhead saps energy from the interesting things one would like to accomplish during the game. It uses a Puerto Rico- or Citadels-like role choice mechanism, yet imbalances the strength of the roles such that many players don't really have a choice. The unit types don't mesh together to encourage any sort of combined-arms approach. It's clear that the designers knew what good, elegant game mechanics were and tried to include some in the game. They failed to do so.

RATING: 9
I originally bought a used copy of TI3 without seriously expecting it to get much play; I thought I'd end up soon selling it off myself. Nonetheless, TI3 is a genre-defining game with which any serious hobbyist should be able to profess familiarity, so I essentially dared myself to buy and learn it. I'm a sucker for space opera, which definitely helped.

Most people in my gaming circles hadn't really played anything approximating the scale and duration of an average TI3 session. However, after gathering a group of open-minded and eager individuals for our first game, I realized I had underestimated its appeal. Close to twelve hours (with breaks) flew by and everybody involved came out of the game jonesing for another session.

(to be continued)

RATING: 6
At first I was very dubious on the whole Command Counter system, and now I really like it.  My biggest complaint with TI3 is the turtle-syndrome.  Planetary Defense Systems make a lot of players very timid...a house rule making them cost more or allowing players to buy fewer might fix this issue.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
After initially being drawn in by the glitz, glam, and lore of TI3, the allure wore off for me after a handful of plays. On the surface, this game appears to have it all: ships, minis, planets, races, technology, combat, politics, trade, etc.; and this is true at some level. However, beneath this glossy exterior is a design that results in disjointed, unthematic gameplay. My issues with TI3 range from the minor (the fact that all techs cost the same, the fact that planets can't be use for both production and influence) to the more serious: the wild variance in the cards (including a huge amount of "whack the leader"), the fact that the way points are scored often force you to play against your race's strengths, and that even when you do complete an objective, it often feels completely devoid of theme or purpose (e.g., "I now spend 10 trade goods;" Why? To whom?). Some of these issues would be fine in a 1-2 hour affair, but when you invest an entire day in a game, they just aren't acceptable for me. Despite having some memorable moments with TI3, I no longer feel it is worth the time and energy.

(I'm giving this rating mainly for nostalgia. I did have some good times with this, but I'm moving on.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Good systems, a true tech tree (one of the few around) and an epic scope mostly overcomes the downtime and typical wargame issues.  The action cards and the political stuff adds a bunch of flavour but you could play without them to reduce play time - especially the political stuff which is a bit pop-gun amongst the heavy-duty space opera.  It seems to me that the epic space war game could not be designed much better than this - the problems are inherent to the genre.  The downtime is there but its not oppressive - its actually the most bearable of the 4+ hour games I have tried (and better than many 2-3 hour games as well!).  Remember the game is in the end a Victory Point race and that should be the focus of strategy, but it can result in an underwhelming end, where (for example) someone wins the game by "spending 6 trade goods".  Do NOT buy the expansion unless you are planning on playing with more than 6 people!  It is a total waste of money for what you actually need, which is the extra objectives and the Imperial II card.  Make copies of these off a friend or the internet.
-----------------------------------------------------
Current house rules:  
(1) leave out all of the technology related objectives.
(2) leave out all of the targeted action cards UNLESS you are playing with agents
(3) play Age of Empires
(4) when playing with less than 6 players, keep the ratio of total resources per player the same as with 6 players.
-----------------------------------------------------
Three point strategy 
(1) try to claim a VP every turn
(2) you will probably not win unless you get your Secret Objective
(3) if you claim your Secret Objective too early you will be attacked and won't win, so try to claim your secret objective on the turn you win, claiming a 2-VP objective as well, to go from 6 to 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I'll be honest; my first play of Twilight Imperium 3rd Edition was marked by tedium more than anything else. Off hand, I'd say it's like Puerto Rico in space with a handful of dice-driven battles at twice the price and quadruple the length. And somehow, there are fewer decisions to be made. Still, it was my first time through, and we were playing a six-player game, which meant lots of downtime. One of the players pointed out that you could use that downtime to thumb through all the tech cards, read the flavor text for your race, etc., but in the early game I didn't want to miss anything other players were doing, and in the later game I looked through that stuff in about 10 minutes, a mere fraction of the game's overall downtime. I have no objections to the game's lavish production; in fact, the hour-long set-up and rules explanation were more impressive and engaging than the actual game. As for the much-vaunted theme, the science fiction universe of this game is shamelessly derivative. L1Z1X Mindnet = Borg. War Sun = Death Star. Etc. Etc. Not a turn-off per se, but not a big attraction either. Perhaps the theme is meant to affirm the genre and not expand it; in that sense, it could be a place for enthusiasts to congregate, instead of one that draws a new set of enthusiasts. Ultimately I think I would like this game if my decisions arrived several minutes sooner. I'm told it's quite good with four-players, so maybe my six-hour investment will be worth something, after all.

I did not see much to love during my first play. I'd be quite curious to try a 3-4 player session of this to firm up an opinion. 

[b]Update:[/b] So, three years after my first play of TI3, we're given the thunderous arrival of Eclipse. Quite simply, if you have not played either game, you owe it to yourself to play Eclipse first. Far better pacing, far better game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
TI3 is a huge sprawling monster of a game. It's the Hummer of boardgaming. More is better, no questions asked. A big boy's toy, no attempt at decency or elegance, only blunt power. For a change of style, it even mixes Eurogame VP collection in which will give the gut/experience players a hard time winning. The challenge is to stay focussed on the goals and not getting lost in the myriad of possibilities (this Warsun looks kinky, let me work toward it). It's highly variable with lots of optional rules, individualized player factions and variable setup. But its gamekit nature is a double-edged thing. While it's the guarantee that each play will be a unique experience, it sets the field for disappointments as well. My first and so far only play was 8 players, took 8 hours and had enough incoherencies for three other games together (potentially due to 8 players):
- Strategy card selection was almost the same each round. First was Logistics (take 4 command counters), second initiative, last player always got Politics. A huge disappointment for such a central mechanism.
- Political phase didn't matter much. Almost never anyone bothered to try to bribe other players to decide for them as it is close to impossible to steer a majority of 7 other players your way.
- Trade phase was boring due to Hacan dominating and reducing the degrees of freedom for all others.
- Luck of discoveries skewed the end result, admittedly to my favour.
Considering all these grave issues in an 8 hour game with lots of down time I would be surprised about TI3 rated as high as it is. But I'm aware that the majority of voters values the experience the most and is able to ignore mediocre mechanisms, downtime issues and disastrous luck to playtime ratio. I would give it another try but only with 6 players. To put things into perspective: I won this game, so this is no sore loser TI3 bashing.
6/10 as a set with the expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Thought it lived up to the hype.  I'd play again without any hesitation.  EDIT 8/19/07:  Added an extra point after playing with Shattered Empires.  If you are looking for a massive, immersive, multifaceted gaming experience, look no further.  Long, but them's the breaks if you truly want epic.  EDIT 12/20/09:  I think I've now played nine times, and it's a 10, as it was in the beginning, is now, and ever shall be.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Interactive strategy tiles so players may play when it's not their turn. Lots of facets to the game besides building and conquering. Well designed and was always a game to look forward to playing.

Major drawback is that it's not for light gamers: [b]lots of rules and long playing time.[/b] So it's hard to get a game going with friends.

Okay, I haven't played this game in over a year. I was craving to play, but realized that I too have transitioned my gaming experience. TI3 is [b]really slow especially with the expansion rules[/b]. Never realized how important the ISC card is in the game. Victory points simply take way to long to obtain. Even when you decimate an entire army, there is no points rewarded, in fact most of the time you'll get ganged up on by 2 or more players and fall into last place.

Strategy is limited by the swarms of units. Really comes down to luck rolls. Political cards and tactic cards have minimal impact on the game. And of course, objectives are either far too difficult to obtain or far too easy that everyone gets them.

Although this was my favorite war game ever, I've grown to realize how [b]monotonous and belaboring[/b] each turn is, especially if you are most certainly out of the running. All you can do is prolong the game or prevent someone you don't like from winning, while you hand the victory to someone else. 

Truly disappointing experience, especially with seeing a sneak peak of how the new Strategy cards work. Shows me the direction in which the game is progressing, apparently the opposite direction I am going.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Excellent space exploration game. I'm not sure about the epic feel that gamers talk about when referring to this game, but there are many ways to develop your alien race and many ways to achieve victory.

If you try to learn the game with some Axis and Allies and Puerto Rico experience, its quite simple. And once players learn the strategy cards, the game moves quicker and is less prone to downtime.

RATING: 5
played the basic game, but found it an underwhelming experience. The rules are epic but it shows that Euro mechanics do not a Eurogame make. The many added levels of complexity do not necessarily influence the game that much. The problem is structurally the same as in Risk. Grab land and build up your forces. Nothing in the game arranges player interaction. 

Although the strategies' mechanic is borrowed from Puerto Rico (and others) it is fundamentally different. Each role in PR resolves one of the steps in the production proces and therefore the order of play of the cards is crucial. However, the roles/strategies in TI mostly set the order of expansion, while production is largely independent of the   strategy. I will elaborate at some point when I've worked this out more fully. Feel free to send a message.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
I only have one play of this game, so take this initial review with a grain of salt. A lot of good choices to be made, and definitely epic in scope, but I can scratch the same itch with a fourth of the time investment. Additionally, the absolute necessity of selecting the 8th strategy card (and the 1st the turn before it) is a huge problem for me. I realize it drives the game toward 10 victory points, but it's completely artificial and provides far too great a benefit in the long run for the player that selects the first role on the first turn of the game.

RATING: 4
Based on 3  plays.  The many virtues of the game are offset by the imbalances, tendency to turtle, and unseemly duration.  The Secret Objective cards in particular are a crap-shoot, yet can often be decisive.  There are too few encouragements to combat, which tends to be an ugly internecine affair.  The downtime, though not egregious, still isn't pleasant.  Despite the beautiful and strategic trappings, it essentially plays like a suped-up version of Nexus Ops.  It has grandeur, yes, but afterwards I don't feel particularly awed or satisfied - just exhausted.

RATING: 8
Huge epic space game. Mix of Puerto Rico (choosing ability each round and getting the primary for your choice and everyone else gets to do the secondary action), Settlers (modular hex board is setup differently every time and resource gathering and building) and some type of war game with dice combat. Very long game, but also very fun through out. Endless replay value since there are so many different races with different powers and the galaxy (modular board) is setup different every time and the card stacks are huge, you won't see all the cards in one game, not even close. 
Very long game, with 6 players it could take about 8 hours to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
The marriage of trash with recycled trash.  Take the most common elements of Euro games, i.e. role selection, resource management and slow development on a hex map and balance them poorly with some dicey trash stuff, then add some pretty generic looking plastic bits and make it last for five anticlimactic hours.  I've been told that this game makes one feel like a power player in some convoluted intergalactic novel, but to me it's the greatest example of a Sisyphus experience in gaming that I have ever been a part of.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
In a multiplayer game of this length, I need to be convinced that the experience is worth it.  The game needs to be balanced, and any major luck-based elements need generally to even out somewhat over the course of the game.  This game screams imbalance to me, and so it is hard for me to commit the time.  I'd rather play three shorter, better games.  For a game of this length that works, I suggest Dune.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Big, dumb fun. 
The good:  great value for the money, lots of eye candy, nice mix of other games (PR/SJ for strategy phase, tolerable roll-to-hit mechanism, some Cosmic Encounter-like rule adjustments for races and political events), and the biggy -- lots of randomness without much luck involved.  The bad:  overlong unless you have a fast-playing group, requires many players willing to invest a considerable amount of time, doesn't require much deep thinking, for all that's here there is no discovery aspect to the game board, interplayer negotiations are limited (especially compared to the likes of Struggle of Empires), and one of the races we used seemed particularly ineffectual (The Emirates of Hacan) and another overly strong (Universities of Jol-Nar).  Like others have said, our game ended just as it was getting interesting.  A fun experience, but one unlikely to occur often, if ever again.  If this design had been a computer game, it would have gone straight to the discount bin.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
I'll always remember the time a gaming friend of mine insisted on including every expansion and optional rule in a first game for 8 players and we proceeded to only get through 2 1/2 turns in an entire day.  Henceforth it was really hard to get anyone to ever play again.  But I simply do not know of a better 4x game and I've tried most all of them.  This one really gives the best feel all around of epic scope, multiple paths to victory, and so on.  You simply need to be careful how new people are introduced to the game and it can still be finished in 3-4 hrs just like the box states.  I don't own the game any longer because it was never my copy anyone chose to play with but I'd look forward to any opportunity to join someone else's game of this anytime.  At this point I haven't played the game in at least 3 years though.

[b]Players considerations[/b]: 
Of course 5-6 or 8 (with expansion) is best, but hard to find enough time, can drag. Requires fast moving players. Even plays well with 3, except for the lack of trade agreement importance. Board to is too large with 4.

[b]My thoughts[/b]: 
Best with a slight tweaking. There is one flaw to this game, the Imperial card, and that's about it. The expansion strategy really fixes this problem. Two words: War Sun. But, seriously awesome bits and cards and player race sheets. Would probably give up my entire collection and keep this if I had only one choice. So much variety and tension.
