=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played Twilight Imperium for the first time with 5 players using both expansions and a bunch of house rules.  I am a huge fan of Game of Thrones 2nd Edition (Christian Petersen design) so I had high hopes for TI3--I even held the expectation that this could become my new favorite game.  We played for about 7 hours and then called it when the only experienced player at the table clearly had the win.  Afterwards, I was spent and felt like my brain had been hit repeatedly with a 2 by 4.  

This is the most over-designed game I have ever played.  Tons of rules, tons of exceptions to those rules, tons of complexity tacked on to complexity with little thought to whether the additions pay for themselves by adding game fun.  Coming in as a new player I was simply overwhelmed, couldn't keep track of everything and gave up trying.

The guts of the game, the combat mechanic, is decades old Axis & Allies:  roll 1 die per unit and score your number based on unit type to inflict 1 casualty on the enemy.  Dreadnoughts and WarSuns absorb 1 free hit before dying just like battleships in A&A.  Planet invasions are like amphiphious assaults, etc...(*yawn*)

Reviewers have said playing TI3 gives them the feeling of having experienced an epic space story.  I felt nothing except brain burn.  TI3 is like the first draft of a thousand page novel published as is but in need of a five good rounds of editing.  There is possibly a good game trapped inside this sprawling behemoth, but until some of the overwhelming detail is stripped away, I won't see it.

I'm not a big fan of the objectives system either.  Conquest is undervalued with victory points awarded for arbitrary accomplishments.  

Okay, maybe I'm being too harsh.  After all, it was only my first play.  I definitely think my rating would go up with additional plays.  I suspect there is a huge learning curve with the game and until you master the crushing detail, it will be difficult to implement a well-informed strategy (which is a great chunk of a game's fun for strategy geeks).  I will not write off TI3 just yet.....

RATING: 4
Let's face it: The game is just not as good as you want it to be. It takes forever, has clunky mechanisms, the expansions are almost mandatory. 

I get some enjoyment out of the game when playing with the "Shattered Ascension" fan rules (check those out, if you are remotely interested into the game). But the negatives (long playtime, overly complicated, slow moving), far outweigh the positives (epic feeling, cool negotiations/political metagame). 

I hear people talking about great games of Twilight Imperium with a great story that unfolds while you play. Stories that you can talk about years later. 

Unfortunately, this never happened to me, even though I really wanted to like this game and I've tried it multiple times. Quite frankly, all I remember is having incredibly cumbersome TI games where nothing really happened after six hours of play and moments of excitement were pretty rare.

So, farewell Twilight Imperium.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
If you ask me what 4X has the best depth:length ratio, I'll answer TI:3. While definitely long, its length can be one hour per player if once all are familiar with it. There are both longer and shorter games, true, and while I do enjoy those too, I always end up comparing them with this one. Shorter games usually fall behind in at least a couple departments, while longer games are almost impossible to organize.

TI:3 features the expected 4 X's: expand, explore, exploit and exterminate. But what makes it great is that it also has diplomacy and trade in spades. All departments have a very nice compromise in between depth and fiddliness. Deep enough to be both thematic and substantial without turning to be nor unwieldy nor unintuitive.

The game also features several core mechanisms which resemble those from euro games. In particular, the drafting of the strategy cards, as well as the action draught imposed by the command counters, are two intuitive and streamlined mechanisms which add a lot of depth to the game.

Sadly, its main flaw relies in one of its main pillars: the strategy cards. In a very specific strategy card, now that we are at it: the Imperial card, which grants two victory points, no questions asked. This makes the drafting more mechanical, as two cards will always be picked whenever possible: the imperial, for the victory points, and the initiative, which determines who will pick strategy cards first on the next turn. This provokes the Imperial card keeps rotating throughout the whole game, which has the side effect of granting a considerable advantage the starting player, as well as to those seated to his left. Thankfully, the first expansion, Shattered Empire, fixes this by introducing alternative strategy cards.

So, is TI:3 good? Provided you can schedule day long sessions, yes, it's good. And if you do own the expansion and address the strategy card issue, it's bloody excellent! Play it, play it, play it!

[i]Rating:[/i] :star::star::star::star::nostar:
[i]Number of players:[/i]
:thumbsup:6
:thumbsdown:3~4

[i]To have more information on how I rate games, [geekurl=/user/Kodeir]go to my profile[/geekurl][/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Epic empire-building wargame, which truely takes a rather long time to play (first session with 3 players required some 7 or 8 hours of actual playing time). The selection of the strategy cards is too scripted (first initiative card and next round imperial card, which gives you 2 victory points [on a total of 10, this is a lot!]). Initial set-up of the galaxy is crucial, get some interesting planets next to your home system and drop the rubbish close to the other players. Don't forget to play towards the objective cards (public and secret - although some of the secret objectives are very hard to accomplish), because only victory points matter (not the complete domination of the galaxy or most planets or most warships or whatever else). **** First session (3 player - vanilla) played (and won) with the Universities of Jol-Nar. **** Recommended to play with the expansion Shattered Empire. The strategy cards are much better and fix the higher mentioned issue! **** Second session (5 player with Shattered Empire) played (and won) with the Naalu Collective. Taking and keeping Mecatol Rex is great! **** Third session (3 player with Shattered Empire) played (and second) with L1z1x Mindnet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Great theme, epic experience !
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
(3 plays)In my opinion, this game owns its genre. To me, I just can't compare this game to others. Even though I never actually finished a game of this, I feel as though this game obliterates all other war games. Not only that, but the game handles large numbers of people fantastically and everyone is constantly thinking for the entirety (10-14 hours usually)of the game. I love to play this game, it's really more of an experience than a game, an all day event that you invite all your friends to come early in the morning and finish late at night. The reason this is not a 10 is because, even with the game (and the first expansion) the game still has some problems. The war mechanic works, but in my opinion could be redone, the amount of time it takes to play this, I think is perfect, and, this may sound a little silly, but people tend to do what is right in the game and not try to get victory points. People will role play. This is the reason the games can can on for so long (IMO). Recently, I've started to tell people before we platy that they should just think about VPs and not what is right, this can take from gameplay a little. All in all, this is a fantastic and beautiful game that fully lives up to its title.

I just wish I could play it more often and that it wasn't so damn hard to get enough people to play it... :(

RATING: 8
Best empire building and space exploration / conquering game I ever played. Got better with every version of the game and I'm a fan of it since the first edition. But TI3 has problems too - one has been the problem with the imperial card and its two instant victory points that can be a pain in a game towards 10 victorypoints. But with the new cards inside the expansions this has changed and now TI3 is really a blast. Only thing that made me rate this game "8" instead of "10": The complexity. It is really cool to have a game where you can fight, trade, negociate, act with political agendas, use leaders, use mercenaries, action cards, laying mines, building up planet defences etc. etc. ... but at some point you have a game that is so complex that you can't overwiew all the possibilities anymore. TI3 is very near to that point or perhaps has already passed it. By making the game better and more complex from version to version TI3 has now reached a level where you can't play the game within a normal "time slot". That means: If you plan to play TI3 you must have MUCH time - about eight hours or much more with unexperienced players. It's a pity - I love this game but I have a gaming group that likes to rotate the game on the agenda each time. With 12 really good games within this rotation TI3 doesn't show up very often. And if... well, often we decide to play something else. Why this? Well, we don't have enough time, are less than five players (TI3 is better with many players, 5 and more  ), have to many unexperienced players who are not interested in such an epic "monster game"... and YES, TI3 IS a monster game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
I've really tried to like this game. The theme is great. I love the theory of an epic space game with all these different races and space ships and what not. The rules even sound good in theory. But in practice it's tedious, frustrating, broken and fat with subsystems and mechanics that add no value.

Every time I play this game I end up feeling robbed. Robbed because despite taking up to 8 hours very little actually happened in the game and I barely had any control of what little did happen. In a typical 6 player game you will only have the opportunity to play maybe 20% of the board and will not be able to interact at all with 2-3 of the other players. It is a serious design flaw for an 8 hour game if another player can win without you having any opportunity to prevent it. 

I feel this game is also far more random than people give it credit for. Again this is a serious design flaw in a game that takes 8 hours. A huge amount of the victory points in the game are allocated by pure chance. So many of the objectives are either extremely easy or extremely difficult for certain players depending on how the board happens to be set up. The secret objectives are even worse, again they are hugely dependant on board layout but due to their secrecy you cannot prevent other players from achieving them. It really feels like secret objectives just randomly assign 2 extra points to certain players. I know that in the games I have played there has never been any correlation between the end scores and the quality of play, which is extremely frustrating. I don't want to play a game for 8 hours only to realise at the end (or worse, at the beginning) that I never really had a chance to win.

And that brings me to the huge amount of rules in this game that are either broken or add no value or add more tedium than value. The ISC is obviously broken, proponents of this game like to claim it isn't but the best argument they can offer to support it is that you need to meta game out the imbalance. It was really embarrassing when FFG stated that the card was working as intended. Everyone uses the expansion fixes for this. 

Fighters are a big problem. I accept that they aren't broken since everyone can build them but they detract from the game for so many reasons. They are so much more powerful than any other ship that any otherwise interesting decision making when building fleets is reduced. Worse still they are so numerous that they clog the board to a ridiculous degree and increase the length of every battle by 100%+. What exactly is the point of them? Everyone needs to build them yet they negate each other, the net effect is only to increase tedium. Couldn't they have just found some way to factor fighters into the inherent firepower of carriers?

The political sub system is a complete waste of time. It will only have an effect maybe once in every three games and even then it will usually be minor. This is the most obvious bit of fat that should have been trimmed from the design long before release. The action cards are almost as bad (and even more random) but I can live with them.

The command counter allocation sub system, whilst interesting in theory, is also a waste of time as it never really has an impact that outweighs the complexity and time it adds to the game. Fleet supply is mostly irrelevant due to fighters (and in fact makes the fighter problem even worse). Strategic and tactical actions are usually always plentiful enough to do almost everything you would want. I'm not saying the system is entirely worthless but in the end it just isn't worth it, I'd rather just predefined action and stacking limits at the benefit of speeding the game up maybe 10%.

I have many other small problems with the game but I think these are the most major ones. I really don't think it would be extremely difficult to design a game with this theme that plays twice as fast yet feels more rewarding. I'm keen to see a 4th edition of this game but I'm not holding my breath seeing as how far away they are from a good game by the 3rd edition.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Everything you've heard is true. Very long game (8-12 hours easy), complex rules (not difficult to grasp once you know them, but there are a LOT to know), mentally involving. BUT I would say although the game gets you to think you have to focus on battle, you actually don't--I played two games w/o fighting and won one of them, so it's possible. I really have to emphasize that comfort and space are needed for this game. We had to play on the floor (didn't have a table big enough) and after 9.5 hours on the ground, my back was killing me. I'd recommend a table big enough to fit about six Monopoly boards, and wear your pajamas or sweatpants and a t-shirt. Get ready to take breaks every two or so hours, as well.

RATING: 3
Long, very long.

Alright game - in theory - but it's a very long, complex game that still simply comes down to everyone shouting "attack him! he's winning!!"

I'm suprised people don't put more effort into the design of these games to stop that being the deciding factor....

Played twice now an unlikely to play again. The first game was with the feeling of "this is dull but would be better once i've got a feel for it"

However, it was even more boring the second play. Simply nothing happens! Where is the fun? The 'political' angle consists of people trying to convince each other that someone else is winning. The battles are utterly dull, the way combat happens just seems to be so boring i never felt involved - just throwing dice and see what i get...

The game looks great and the concept is right up my street but the actually game play is dull. 

Drop the 'role selection', clean up the techs & make the whole thing more dynamic and it may be playable. Moving into 5 regions and fighting with 2 other people a total of 4 times over the space of 8 hours is not my idea of an 'epic space opera'. In the end it feels like one of the most boring 'euro' games i've played.

RATING: 8
The ultimate civilization game. It just has everything: tech research, warfare, lots of figures, trade, sabotage, ... And most importantly, the politics! Betrayal, promises, intrigues, bribes and blackmailing that pop-up in this game are more than just a cherry on top of the cake. We've had some spectacular game swings due to some well-timed betrayals or hastely forged alliances.
Yes, it takes a long time to play, but it's very much worth it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This is one of the most over-hyped games out there.  The theme is fun (albeit generic), and the different races create a sort of lore that draws you in...and once you're on the hook, like an unscrupulous bait and switch appliance salesman, the game delivers something very different.  Honestly, TI3 is a wounded, lumbering behemoth, staggering about blindly.  

My experiences with this game involve sitting and waiting and waiting.  If ever there was a game where an AP player could hold your weekend hostage, it was TI3.  And as a bonus, after waiting for some slow player to optimize his turn, you get to wait through a different player's filibuster around the voting.  I've made dinner, cleaned, ironed, and played 2 games of iOS summoner wars between turns - no exaggeration.  I have played the game several times because I heard such great things, but honestly, TI3 not only takes your whole weekend, it makes you angry and frustrated and provides no fun in exchange.  

The winner of the game is the player who throws his hands up in despair and fakes a date as an excuse to leave the table.  Add to that a dense set of rules in a poorly organized rulebook (which you have to reference all the time), a setup that is too big for ANY table, and an enormous box with no attempt made to provide a sorting solution, and you have a game that is so bloated that it feels like a 400 pound man squeezing into his daughter's tutu.  

Don't believe the hype, this game is awful.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I finally had a chance to play to the 3rd edition after 2 years of waiting. OK where to start, let start with the good points.

Compared to the previous editions, there were some improvements. For example the planet cards prevente to used money token in order to produce stuff. This is nice and it is much more convenient to play. The hexes are biggers than he 1st edition so more space to place stuff. that's about it.

Now with the bad points. There is probably so much that I could not list them all since I'll forget a few. I'll try to start with the differences with the old editions.

TI add a lot of ressource management to the game which create the syndrome of "do something to do something to do what you want to do" instead of just doing it. It slow down the game and it distance more the fun stuff "invading, researching, negotiating" from the main stuff "ressource management".

Compared to the previous version, the turn order is totally screwed up. There is a lot of inspirations from eurogames in TI3 by using a role system like puerto rico. the problem is that it makes the game last forever. I can take 1 hour in a 4 player games just to explore and conquer the nearby EMPTY systems. Imagine when the real battle will start.

The objective based victory is also a problem to me that I first realised in nexus ops. It creates the syndrome of "everybody to their things and somebody wins". It almost feel solitaire multiplayer. The reason is because the game force you to do stuff to get VP. So all the players focus on that and the presence of other players sometimes have no importance to complete these objectives.

Now, let get into the stuff that really annoy which sometimes date from the first TI.

Ship movement: Of course which can move at different speed in space. But to move from a system to a system, you FTL drives (faster than light) which are totally different from manuver drives. In other word, during interstellar travel, ships should move at the same speed. Else you would not be able to make fleets.

Technology: Technology gives you bonus modifiers to almost any aspect of the game. Bonus which ost of the time are easily forgotten.

Fleet Supply: I understand the concept of fleet supply. But actually, it should restrict the number of fleets you have not the number of ships per fleet. Because the way you play now, you could have 20 fleets of 3 ships with 3 fleet supply which would be in my point of view much harder to manage than 1 fleet of 60 ships. Limiting the number of fleet would have promoted the effect of not being able to be everywhere at the same time.

Imperial: Of course there is the imperial card bug, which was so obvious just the first time I read the rules. I never played to actually realise it.

Diplomacy: I would loved to have a good diplomatic tension in the game to make sure you can win other ways than war. Bu there is not a good diplomatic system in TI3. It very limited what you can do or negotiate.

Initial Planet conquest: I hate some much the idea at the beginning of the game that you do not need infantry to actually control a planet. So you drop your unit, "this planet is ours" you take it back and move to the other planet. Wow!, I did not thought the people would have stayed that much loyal.

Starship armor padded with fighters: I just find it TOTALLY STUPID that fighters are there to actually takes the hit that ships should have taken. First, fighters should not be on the board. It removes the situation where you have many empty carriers. Second, there should be a capital ship rule: If you have more capital ship than normal ship, the next hit must be taken on the capital ship. In this case, it force the players to have balanced fleets.

So in general, the ideas are there (If I compare with the master of orion 2 video game) but they are just badly implemented. It also promotes on of the fantasy flight's new idea of make the people think about not fun things for no actual logical reason just to add strategy in the game (like in some euro games). That's something that happens in starcraft with the reverse order stack resolution.

--------------------------------------
Comments from 1 of my friend that summarize it all:

1st game played: He attacked other players and end up not winning the game be he had fun.

2nd game played: He did everything possible to win the game. He strictly focused on the objective. In the end he won but he had the most boring game ever.

Result: Twilight Imperium reward the players for doing things which are not fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
[u]Comment:[/u]
To be honest I am not really this games target audience. I am not a big fan of epic games. I appreciate the ones that I play, but sitting down to a 6-9 hour game just isn't my thing. Maybe it is because I have OCD, who knows? Anyway, what this game does it does particularly well. I especially enjoyed seeing how some of these mechanics were the seeds that laid the foundation for A Game of Thrones: The Board Game. The choices are interesting, and the VP winning condition makes the game seem much more open and variable strategies much more open to consideration. The components are top notch, as expected from FFG, and the graphic design is acceptable. The game is just over the top with the amount of stuff that you must manage during the game. There are fifteen different little decks of cards that you are using, there are at least 8 different types of miniatures that can control. Everything is just so much. The tech tree is interesting, and I think it was implemented in a pretty clever way. The races seem all different and have their plusses to them. All in all it was an enjoyable experience playing this game, but due to its epicness I would probably only play once every year or so. Just too much game for me in the end.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This is a very difficult game for me to rate as I feel that it is filled with a large number of good ideas but also exhibits major flaws.  The space exploration/warfare theme is excellent and the variety of options allows for a truely immersive experience.  In terms of game balance, however, it has some major flaws.  Early turn order is a massive advantage as the Imperial Strategy is overwhelmingly powerful.  The various abilities of the races are, in my opinion, not only asymmetrical but also unequal and some secret objectives are incredibly easier to achieve than others. Further the rewards of combat don't seem to measure up to the risks and perhaps the most enjoyable aspect of the game is therefore significantly underutilized.  Ultimately, it's too long for a game that involves such serious issues of balance and includes as much chaos as it does.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
played and would like to say wow. everything I thought it would be. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Complex, multiplayer grand strategic si-fi game.  There must be something in this si-fi game as a number of my geekbuddies recommend this game highly.  However, I find it quite difficult to get start with, especially with the planet activation system, whereas you place your activation marker to the destination planet instead of from the planet where the units came from.  There are also quite a number of new terms and gaming concepts, like production system, technology cards and units' capabilities for the players to absorb first.  On the other hand, combat is a matter of fighting to the last man, with combat die-roll of equal or greater than the units' combat rating.  It is fairly straightforward and bloody.  One of the strongest game feature is the randomness of this game, from the creation of the universe to the selection of public objectives, to the political and action cards with varying demands on the players.  So no two games would be the same or predictable.  The interaction among players and the races they represent is also intense and fun.  Many special race capabilities have a subtle impacts on the development strategy for the race.  You can always opt for a different strategy not in the race-specific fashion though, depending on the public objectives on the table.

RATING: 10
Played one game with six people right after I bought it at a convention.  All of us were enthralled for the next 6.5 hours (as we learned the rules, too).  Mechanics are not too complex, but there are choices and tasks for each player on every player's turn.  There is construction, planetary occupation, politics, trade, research, fleet management, combat... this game has it all.  If you stop to think about it, you can tell a lot of thought went into these rules to make things work well together, to reward choices and tone down others.  The components are lush.  This is the best big-box game I have ever played, and I would be hard pressed to think of a more immersive, fun game of any sort for a group of people.  This one gets a 10 right off the bat until I find reasons to degrade the score.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
way to long for what it is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Yes, it lasted 17 hours, but it was worth every minute, and I would play it again in a heartbeat (or at least decide to. Playing it would take thousands of heartbeats)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Extremely fun game play. Interesting turn sequence system that leans toward the Euro style, and away from the typical "you take a turn, I take a turn" western game style. Although the turns can be long, everyone is heavily involved in each turn, making the game far more exicting for everyone. 

Plan to invest a few hours in working out the game setup and turn/phase/round sequences the first time or two that you play. Its not too complex to play once you get over the learning curve. But there definately is a learning curve. Loads of variety. The potential for variety in this game is such that it should never become boring, IMO.

At first glace, the game looks like 'Risk' on a 'Settlers of Catan' style hex grid map. But the game is far more multi-dimensional than Risk. The variety of race advantages/disadvantages, and technologies really makes for a wide variation in play strategies. 

One of the real game play issues with Twighlight Imperium is 'balance'. The races are not ideally balanced, IMO. For instance, I've noticed a slight imbalance in the way the game rules and combat system handle larger ships vs fighters, and this seems to give a clear military advantage to some of the races whose bonus revolve around the fighters.

Another game play issue is the huge variety of rules that are options. In one way, options are good. But it can also create a bit of havoc when trying to determine which are in play, and which are not. Also, with so many options, the game is a bit of a 'patchwork' of rules, that can really be confusing and lead to issues with game balance. I'd suggest developing a list of the rules that work well for your game group, and stick to them. Once you find a combo of rules that works well, the game should be more straightforward.

This game is definately in my top ten 'favorite games to play' list. It is however, not a game that you can play in an evening. Great for 3-4 players who have the better part of a day to commit to the game. I'm still giving it a '9.5' though, because its just that damn fun when you do get a game going.

It's an interesting theme with interesting mechanics, but just too many options.

RATING: 10
A long deep game, my favorite of all times (even when I've only played it a few times)

The tree of what you can do expands into almost infinity (and there's an expansion! Oh my god!)

This game is not for the faint of heart, the 5+ hours that you will spend playing it will be full of heartbeat-raising decisions.

Every small matter, from watching every little bit of your opponents to lure your friends to vote against a law you don't want passed, to the nail-biting combat, will make this the game of your life.

It is all: the combat of the MB games of old, the elegant design and stability of Eurogames, the decisions and strategy of a very complicated abstract and the fun of a pinball machine!

Edit: I've managed to translate, print, paste, and cut all of the cards (including Strategic) and race sheets in the game. It seemed this was my friends' cue to tell me they don't want to play the game anymore.  I guess I need a new game group

[Mostly played with: 4]

It is essentially broken due to that reason.

RATING: 8
Played it at 4 players, 6 players and 2 player variant. 

4 players was alright, but allow people to stay in their corner and build their own thing and still win the game.

At 6 players, the game shines best and it was a lot of fun. We used Imperial 2 strategy card instead of the one from the base game. It changes the dynamics of the game. 

Both 4 and 6 player lasted 8 hours. Although they were all first time players. It is about 1 hour per player.

Below is not part of the official rule:
We wanted to get the game on the table more often, so looked up on the 2 player variant.
It is excellent. The political play is a lot of fun. this variant.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Hard to find 4 to 6 willing peeps for a full day.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Easily in my top two games ever played - especially with both expansions (the other one is Descent (1st Edition) with expansions). The Centerpieces of this Game are not the really well combinated mechanisms or the great artwork or the nicely balanced races (at least after two expansions). It is much more the extreme amount of communication, negotiation and the nearly unlimited possibilities to interact with each others (or better with other civilizations) that make this game really special. This game makes you actually be an individual of a foreign race and lets you act like so. 

Playing time is dependend on the options you play with and of course the strategy and objective cards you chose. 
This is the single game that players still talk about weeks after a match. Just a class of its own - outstanding.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The strategy cards (same as the roles in Puerto Rico) need a lot more synergy between them to work.  The political card is a particular disappointment.  Unfortunately (due to the IP card) I have players in my group that have stated they will never play this again.  Unfortunately for T3, Nexus Ops moved it's cheese quite a bit and what's more, I feel Second Edition is superior.  I have no clue why this is ranked so high. Nice plastic pieces that obfuscate a rather tedious version (much like Axis and Allies)?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.19
Comments entered on 13 Dec 2010:

This is the third iteration of the Twilight Imperium board game. The first two were variations on the American style board games with an I-go/you-go turn mechanic. The third edition borrows the role selection mechanic and involves a threaded turn structure and makes this game significantly different and far more interactive.

I purchased the first edition of this game when living in Moorhead in about 1997/1998 and never played it. I purchased the second edition of this game while also living in Moorhead and never played it. In January of 2005 while working at Paradox in Fargo, I bought the third edition and then ran several events at the store of the game. This was FFG's first "big box" game and is still one of my very favorite games.

I have the base game and the Shattered Empires expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A lot of work is required to prepare this monster.

The play time can go long or short. To go short, get into the theme. To go long, try to win; I'll be hoping you get some hoser card along the way.


B&N sale.

RATING: 10
Very long but huge fun.  Exceeded my expectations, which were pretty high.

I was very surprised how well the game held everyone's interest for an extended 12-hour marathon first game (for all 3 of us)!  2nd game (with 2 newbies and two of us on our 2nd game) lasted 8 hours (until one player reached 8VP, but we kept playing) and an additional 4 hours (until that same player reached 10VP, with the rest close behind).

Reminds me of Sword of the Stars, one of my favorite computer games.  I especially liked the many opportunities the game gives for deal-making among the players, sparks lots of interesting conversation and trash-talking :-) 

We've played over a dozen games since.  Average game (5 players) now takes us about 6 hours, plus an hour for setup and getting organized, and including a meal break.  Still my favorite game.  Have a core set of players who enjoy this so much that we are getting together about once/month just to play this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The game is a battle between very different factions in a space setting.  It is big, complex and a sprawling 4x game.  It takes more than 1-2 hours to teach.    

I found the game to be far too long.   At larger player counts you are taking forever for your turn.  Depending on player numbers and expansions, you are looking at a 6-16 hour game.  I don't mind 6 but I don't want to go much longer than that.  It really is not that great for 12 hour investment.  

I really would recommend that most people don't buy this.  You are going to have a tough time finding people to play.  If you have a game group that likes event games where someone serves meals while you play, it may be ok.  Just not for me.

On the whole, I'm not likely to play it again even though I like the genre and concept.

RATING: 6.1
It took a while for me to figure this one out. Very heavy compared to my normal fare. I enjoyed the game and would play again though. It's very easy to be forced out of contention by the layout of the board and the objective cards you are given. However sometimes you can claw your way back out of such a situation. This is an event game, plan the date for this title well in advance and make sure everyone understands the length. It helps to make a rules document and see that everyone has a copy before the game day. Plays differ from one to another dramatically. Sometimes it'll be a tight race sometimes it'll be a blowout but for me it's always worth the effort to play if I've prepared to play it. Note: with the Shattered Empires expansion nearly all the points that make me waffle on this title evaporate. This is an excellent event game with the expansion.

RATING: 9.5
Gameplay:
+ very complex, but well designed mechanics
+ exploration and expansion
+ very tactical
+ competitive, but does not force aggressive play
+ many optional game variants
+ a lot of interesting and thematic mechanics
+ high player interaction; consequently little down time

- very, very long (but worth it imo)
- some mechanics seem a little forced upon the game to make it thematically work

Components:
+ top-notch, high quality components in a BIG BOX
+ space ships and units look awesome!
+ A LOT of stuff
+ great artwork; the game looks very good overall

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
TI (plus the first expansion) is an amazing, epic, experience. The races are not balanced, and you can get hit by bad luck early, but the game is so much fun to play one tends not to mind too much. Where you'd have had more fun spending those 12 hours playing 3 other games is a moot point; these days I play Eclipse much more often than TI just because of available time. Where it really scores over the likes of Eclipse is with the variety and theme added by the Galactic Assembly, where players can effectively vote to change the rules as the game progresses. You do need that first expansion to address some rules issues.

RATING: 4
The good: a rich 4x space experience

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What can I say? I like deep involved "social" games with lots of things to do... TI is the epitome of this gaming style. It is defined as "dynamic" and "big picture" -- it is indeed, all of that and more. The lower rating is because of game length and the number of random surprises. It takes a long time to play -- we used to play 2-3 times per year, but now we're lucky to get in one game in two years. It's well worth the effort if you can find enough players. Six players is the ideal number, though the game is good with four. This game is all about player interaction, but the time factor estimate of 1 hour per person only works if everyone knows the game and stays on topic. After six hours, this game tends to get tiresome. The Shattered Empires expansion is a must. The Shards expansion isn't, but it's not bad.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Set aside the whole day for it but prepare to have some serious fun. One of the best 4Xish games I've played on a table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
rating after 1 play, epic, last very long

RATING: 10
The ultimate game, but for me, ONLY with the Shattered Ascension house rule set from PsiComa (only the base game without expansions I'd probably rate a 4). I'd like to spend most of my waking hours playing this game or talking about it.

Every game is an epic struggle, inspiring great war stories and "what if" scenarios. The game is massive both in scope and playing time, but those are not negatives for me.

The biggest thing I can say is that although I always play to win, in this game "the journey really is more important than the goal". Even if I lose badly, I still have a lot of fun and memorable moments.

RATING: N/A
Twilight Imperium Third Edition is an epic empire-building game of interstellar conflict, trade, and struggle for power. Players take the roles of ancient galactic civilizations, each seeking to seize the imperial throne via warfare, diplomacy, and technological progression. With geomorphic board tiles, exquisite plastic miniatures, hundreds of cards, and introducing a rich set of strategic dimensions that allows each player to refocus their game-plan, the original designer Christian T. Petersen has seamlessly incorporated the better qualities of other recently popular games to improve on the game-play of the original TI, making it at once perfectly well-rounded and pleasantly familiar to experienced gamers.

RATING: 10
Ti3 as a game with out the Shattered Empires expansion if a flawed experience. (i would rate it about a 7) The 10 reflects the fact that I never play this with out the SE expansion. With the new Rules and objectives this is truly the best space expansion game available today. Sure it is long, but if you are worried about time then go play something else. If you are looking to play an excellent game of science fiction empire building then clear out a Saturday and invite over some friends. 

the game plays well with 3 - 8, 3 and 4 player games take about 1 hour per person once everyone know the rules (I would say by the 3rd play). 8 hour games are going to take you from 8 - 10 hours depending on how fast the group plays.  To really enjoy this game you need to have the flexibility of not setting a time limit, but on those occasions that you can do this it is time very well spent.

RATING: 9.8
A gift from my 2012 Dice Tower Secret Santa!

I have played a 6 player game once with my gaming group with the Leaders mini expansion, which adds a lot of theme to the game.

Out of my 5 friends, 4 were total noobs and 1 had played before, but needed to be refreshed a bit.

I started explaining the rules to everyone at 11 am, finished at something like 12h15 and we went to lunch.

After lunch, we started playing at about 2h45 pm and the game ended at 11h45 pm, about 9 hours from its beginning.

Despite of its gargantuan lengh, we all had a blast, loved this game and are all looking forward to playing it again.

Some of my friends suffer from AP, and the game's tactical decisions seemed to worsen it. If it didn't happen, the game would probably have lasted for "only" 8 hours or so.

This is the most complete game I have ever played, and I would easily give it a 10 if it were shorter.

Update: I have integrated both the expansions to the base game and, OMG, it seems its rate will skyrocket! I'm just waiting to play it to give the feedback. Will it be my first solid 10 on BGG?

Update: the game is much, much better with the expansions, but there's a lot more going on now, and it causes some players in my group to have even more SERIOUS AP issues. This has caused us to be dragged to a game which started at 12:30 and finished at 23:00. 10 hours and a half of play time.

In spite of being unable to give it a 10, it has become my favourite game so far. It is absolutely great and will always be my first choice if I have time and quorum to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Everything I need for an epic game! Development - Exploration - Battles - Conquest - Politics tied with the excellent "Puerto Rico" mechanism and great components by FFG. My favorite and probably this will never change. 

THEME - I love 4X games on PC like Master Of Orion 2 and this could be its tabletop version. 10/10 

COMPONENTS / ARTWORK - No other company has the quality of FFG 10/10 

RULEBOOK - As always, FFG has detailed rules and examples. Plus you get a lot of flavor both in rulebook and race sheets. 10/10 

FUN - In this game, I don't care about to win. I like to see my civilization being developed. 10/10

ORIGINALITY - Strange but there aren't many space empire building games out there. 9/10

MECHANICS - The blend of euro, war and ameritrash games as good as it gets! 10/10

DURATION - The cost you have to pay in order to enjoy such an epic game! I think 5 or 6 hours for such an epic game are normal. 9/10 

REPLAYABILITY - What? With random setup, 14 races (using expansion), technology trees, laws, variants etc. are you worry about replayability? 10/10 
  

Also own Shattered Empires expansion
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
11-20-08
8.0 Rating

Rating is from first game. I really had fun with this. The game is changed fundamentally in a few ways and I'm not sure if i'd say it was better or not than the original(s). I loved the new aspects of the game (the Strategic Command Choices, reduced costs, new units, Varied Victory Points, ect...) but there is a tradeoff in scope. No longer do you have to worry about an opponent launching a full scale invasion in one turn before you can do anything to stop him. He can launch 'part' of one, and then you'll get the chance to react. He may then continue his assault on successive rounds with you responding inbetween each. There is a certain 'telegraphing' of moves that changes the feel of the game overall. "Oh great, N'Orr has chosen the Warfare Strategy". You then use a Tactical move to build new ships to deter him before he can attack (provided you have the lower initiative Strategy). Although 'streamlined for less downtime', the game is not really any shorter. I'm going to rate this an 8 for now. Great game, but I won't be selling off my 1st Edition copy.

12-11-11 
8.5 Rating

Rating has gone up .5 as I now have my own copy and expect to be playing this edition more.

RATING: 1
I originally gave this game a 5 just because I have some friends who love it and I thought I'd throw them a bone.  Then I dropped it to a 4 because, well let's face it, I don't care that much.  After thinking more on it I decided to give it a 1.

This game SUCKS!  It is 95% down time waiting for some other chode to make his move.  Everyone talks about the awesome political intrigue the game has to offer.  BS!  There is as much political intrigue as a middle school student council vote.

After 8 hours we weren't even close to finishing the game.  I found myself on my phone all day waiting for my next move.

DO NOT BOTHER WITH THIS GAME.  SERIOUSLY!  Save your time and energy.  I just got my wisdom teeth pulled about 5 days ago.  I would gladly have the surgeon put them all back in and re-remove them before playing this crap again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The game is a huge collection of pretty standard things seen in 4x but does them quite well.  The problem for me is just that the whole thing is way too convoluted and doesn't actually lead to that much fun play. The point scoring mechanism is a bit dull and feels stupid. The laws are potentially interesting but played out incredibly dull with no impactful law ever making it through. The diplomacy aspects in general provide awful ways to just gang up on the leader and bicker for hours about tedious stuff like how many trade goods to give to for allowing others to make a trade deal which often doesn't even do anything.  

Overall it's just so convoluted. A 9 hour game where you do like 9 turns and too much time is lost on petty diplomacy,  trading and what not instead of the fun bits. 

It is better than most 4x? In many systems yes,  but overall i rather just play 4 medium games than one of this.

Must play at least once or twice in 2013 - Have I finally found the holy grail of epic boardgaming goodness?  More play will confirm the initial impression after 6 games.  Surprisingly MORE simple to play than I expected, and it seems more consistent than my beloved Starcraft.  Some random elements can be slightly frustrating but it seems good players can plan accordingly and rise to the top.  I would NEVER turn down a game of this.  It's main problem is that it is a 3+ player game, so you need many dedicated gamer friends to make this work, wich is not my case.  I rarely have the occasion to play this, while I can play Starcraft with 2.  I noted that our 3 player game could last around 2.5 hours wich is perfect, but lack a little diplomacy that would be present with more players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
*NOTE* To be worth eight, you need to play with the official Imperial II variant, which you can download from the FFGwebsite. With the Shattered Empires expansion, this is worth a solid nine.

Although not much can match this game for sheer epic scale, be prepared for a long sit in with this one. The unapologetic mishmash of chrome and Euro-style strategy rules results in a game of quite astonishing tactical variety where the path to victory is never obvious. The circular nature of the board, political and trade mechanics and objectives system combine brilliantly to ensure that this is a game which rewards negotiation without allowing it to dominate. See my review for more details: http://fortressat.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=330

I'd rather pay a number of shorter games than Twilight Imperium.

There also seems to be a significant luck factor in the secret objective cards drawn, as to how achievable they are.  On first play it seems to be unacceptably so, given the length of the game.  Or perhaps I just completed my preliminary objective card too late to be able to adjust my strategy :)

Played with expansion in.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This is an interesting game brought down by playing time and sheer weight of upkeep.  The mechanics are interesting and satisfying.  I played my first game last night, and the first two hours had me hooked.  The third hour started to drag a bit.  Hours four through six mostly stopped being fun.  And in common with the other Fantasy Flight big box games I've played, the longer you play (and the more production ramps up), the more time you spend on upkeep, and the longer the downtime between turns.  It makes for a downward spiral into boredom.  Don't even ask about set-up and tear-down time.

It's a shame, really, because the next day I was still thinking about the game and what might have been if only the Winnu hadn't taken out one of my carriers. There's the kernel of a great game buried somewhere under all the plastic bits and exceptions to the rules.

As a computer game, where upkeep is out of the players' hands, Twilight Imperium would be awesome.  As a board game, it's too long and too fiddly.  I would play it again, but I'd bring along a book to read between turns, or some quick-playing filler games for the same purpose.

I wouldn't be the one to suggest playing it, since there are so many other games that can provide similar weight and player engagement in a fraction of the time.

-----

UPDATE: Rating falls from 5 to 3 on the threat of another game.  A coworker suggested we get a group together to play this on an upcoming holiday, and I turned it down because I don't want to waste a day off playing Twilight Imperium.  I realized that not only does TI feel more like work than a game, it's less fun than my actual job.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Our houserules:

Print and laminate research guide & player aid (with variant rules).

Star by Star variant (homeworlds can be placed anywhere, each player is given an even distribution of planets/hazards)
(star by star: 36 hexes not including M.Rex. Each gets 2 obstacles/wormholes). Wormholes MUST be at least 2 sectors apart. No hope's end or mirage (+ figher or + troops planets). Muatt must start in the outer ring.

Show Secret Objectives FIRST. 

Show Age of Empire objects also. 

Custodians of Mecatol Rex.

Can choose best of 2races as well as 2 secret objectives.
Age of Empires w/ custom beurocracy 2
(6 stage 1, 4 stage 2 objectives. all initially locked)
Secret and Public Objectives revealed before setup (so you can strategize).
2 dice dreadnoughts. (only 2 dice for regular combat, 1 dice for all other)

FLEE: same as retreat, but your units don't counter attack. Instead, choose to ignore half of the hits (rounded down). Must flee to previously activated system OR place new command counter in sector that you retreat to.

Retreats are still an option for attacker (must declare before combat round).

Option: Trade Primary Ability REDONE: at the end of the trade phase, you can give AND receive ONE unused command counter to a trade partner to boost a card's trade value. Trade values can be boosted up to double their initial value.

Bonus counters give TWO trade goods (not one)

Use 3 Artifacts (use all dummies) (consider using 4 artifacts)
All homeworlds are worth 1VP (so each race starts with 1 vp). Similar to artifacts.

Play to 10VP.

Play with no Naalu and Saar

Race Balancing:
    * Give Sardakk another Carrier
    * Give Xxcha another Carrier
    * Change Winnu's race tech to 'At any time'
    * Let Mentak do the stealing right after Trade is played
    * Yssaril must pay 1 resource (or trade good) each time they pass

 * Dreadnoughts get +1 dice for regular combat (not bombardments)
    * Dreadnoughts and Warsuns lose 1 dice per hp of damage

Most rules borrowed from Shattered Ascension.

Speeding up the game:
Time limit per turn (5m). Also, please try to tell the next person to go if you are producing. (produce on the side, then tell everyone what you made and what you tapped)

Team Variant:
2 teams - random (AFTER the game is setup). 
Secret objectives are completed IF a teammate qualifies also? (think about this)

After part of the game (either after X rounds OR after someone reaches X points), there is an alliance change.

Everyone gets 2 cards - a loyal card or a traitor card. If you get 2 traitor cards, you switch teams with the other traitor. If the other team does not have a traitor, you switch with the person who is in the same rank as you (1st, 2nd, or 3rd on team).

Team rank is based off a formula (points? planets? influence?)




=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm not sure there's much point to writing a review on Twilight Imperium 3rd edition. This game is a sprawling mess, too large in scope, too long, too complex, too easy to lose in the first hour (after which there will be six to eight hours remaining - depending on the group). Or you could say the game is epic, it's a sandbox (spacebox?), a great toy that you can play with your friends all day 'til everyone is near exhaustion and are either sitting at the cusp of victory or barely eeking out a pitiful existence in some irrelevant corner of the galaxy.

When you are done, the new emperor crowned and gloating and everyone else sulking at having spent 8 hours just to lose in the end (or long before that point if they were so unfortunate), was it worth it? Yes, yes it was. The game does epic, and does it well. It is large enough to encompass all styles of play - from the min/max competitive, to the storyteller, to the guy/girl who just wants revenge for that time you did that thing, all without falling apart or feeling less because of it. And when you're done you've basically spent a day with your friends, playing, talking, drinking & eating (I certainly hope so, for your own sakes) - so it's all good!

Then you can all spent hours discussing the story that unfolded, or the strategies that worked and didn't and how you plan to do better next time (for there will be one, maybe in a year, maybe?). You don't get this investment in shorter, less epic games, and for that it's worth the ridiculous expense (mentally and monetarily) and time it takes!

My verdict: Needs to be planned in advance, but a good game, or maybe not, actually it's rather possible that this is a rather poor "game", but it's great nonetheless!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Epic game with lots of player interaction. Clear your schedule for the day because this is a lenghty game. Enjoyed it very much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
No rating until I play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I think this game was a big step back from the earlier versions.  I don't know why it is rated so high.  It does have wonderful components, but the play is much more complex.  Adding the offices with primary and secondary roles SLOOOWWWSSS the game down so much.  Every time someone tried to attack someone else, it was stopped dead by those wonderful action cards.  It can be frustrating to build a dominating fleet to have it stopped dead by one of the many cards someone else has in their hand.  The secret victory point goals are random so you have a pacifist race with a war monger goal or vice versa.  A six player game took 1 hour per turn…ouch!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Game in a Nutshell: Explore the galaxy, build fleets, research technologies, and battle it out to gain points through different hidden and open objectives.

Played as: 6 player

Played With: Shattered Empire only

Pros: Ambitious project with many different elements of interest. Extensive technology advances and an assortment of different races with their own abilities makes for an impressive amount of potential re-playability.

Cons: The play length hurts the game because while you may still be mathematically in it for the first half (which may take the recommended 4 hour playtime on its own), if through chance, your own stupid mistake, or a combination of both, you all of a sudden are virtually out of the game, you may have to sit around for another several hours humoring yourself and others with decisions of no consequence. This creates the most painful downtime experience I've ever sat through, one of which my head was aching. I don't like the tremendous amount of things to remember at once. 

Other: Take the cons with a grain of salt because if it wasn't for the games extended play length, it'd be an undeniable masterpiece. I've rated it where I have not because I don't have a desire to try again, but the likeliness that I'll feel like spending the time for another run.

Best Use: Perfect game for a weekend at the cabin when you have lots of time to come and go.

RATING: 7
1 play.  I totally forgot about victory points the entire game and wasn't really clear on the 8 possible roles (the winner used the "trade 6 trade goods for 2 VP's" role over and over again).  Managed to get a space nipple...er...death star...er...whatever they're called on the board but the game ended before I could begin annihilating the galaxy.  Fun, reminded me of Axis & Allies a bit, except there aren't any alliances and VP's seemed to all be based on technologies or planet types owned.  I thought the VP's seemed pretty strange, it's supposed to give variety but it ended up feeling arbitrary and chaotic. I also wish the political votes and stuff had come into play more in our game, 'cause that seems like it might be pretty neat.  Also, I have to say...there are way too many racial special powers.  It seemed like everyonee had 3 or 4.  Even if you are very familiar with the game, it still has to be hard to wrap your head around to try and plan around.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.75
My rating on this one has slowly deteriorated over the years to the point I want to trade it off. I was sucked into gaming by Risk and Axis and Allies so when I saw this game years ago filled with hundreds of plastic ships and planets to conquer I got real excited. But after repeated plays over the years, I frankly find this game to be very boring. You spent literally HOURS playing this game but when you look back at the experience you find that almost nothing really happened. It is completely bogged down in minutiae and fiddly bits that just drag the game out. I used to love Fantasy Flight games because they seemed to be the standard bearer for Ameritrash games with very high production value and great themes. But I find that many of their games are in serious need of streamlining. Many of their games simply last at least an hour or two longer than they really need to for the gameplay you actually get, and Twilight Imperium is a glaring example.

----------

Feb. 2011 I traded it off for Horus Heresy. Let's hope that one holds my interest more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A very impressive game, but difficult to get in to. Lots of niggly little rules that are difficult to keep up with as you're waiting a long time between your turns when playing with rookies. Once you have the rules down though, this is a quality game, let down only perhaps by some slight imbalances that can lead to victory points for particular races that are able to exploit the varying objectives more than others. This is a good game, but I'd prefer a 2 player war game over this if the option was there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Take strategical actions, move space ships and roll combat dice to expand your space empire to be able to build more space ships etc, for most points.

Plays: 1.
Type: Faux wargame = a game where you move military forces on a map, but where victory isn't intrinsically about conquest or destruction of enemies.
Complexity: Heavy.
# of players: See BGG.
Playing time: See BGG.
Player interaction: Conflict and Diplomacy.
Randomness: High – dice and card draw with high impact and little control.

Replayability: Average. Those that enjoy the epic space opera theme will probably want to explore the strategies of the different races. The board is modular, so every game is very different. It’s an extremely long and very random game though. Sitting through several hours of no chance because you drew the wrong race and objectives does not inspire you to play again.
Fun: Average. Building a space empire is fun. Rolling lots of dice in space battles is fun. The interminable playing time and endless downtime between your turns is not fun. The downtime is quite remarkable considering that most strategy actions allows all players to do something. 
Memorability: High. This creates a story about space empires.

Thematic integration: Good. This is designed theme first. The victory conditions feel decoupled from the gameplay though.
Components: Not as good as one would expect. I would like better looking bits for my epic space opera game. This goes for everything – the ships are bland, the cards are tiny and the board tiles are uninspiring.

Who will like this: Ameritrash fanboys.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Epic Event Game. Length can be a problem, otherwise a great space opera.

RATING: 1

RATING: 7

Fantasy Flight rules:  Explain one concept in contradictory ways among several non-consecutive pages, and among these pages leave out necessary instructions on how the rule operates correctly...put that part of the rule in with the pictured example example, but leave it out of the rule explanation completely.

RATING: 1
There must be a game similar to this in terms of mechanics, but simplified.  I only played it once, but it seemed like 90% of the game was "setting it up" and me asking about 1000 questions about the myriad of rules, turn orders, etc (it was my first game).  I think this is as close to a 4X computer game as a board game can get...but to be honest, this game would work better as a computer game.  WAY too much tedious handling of bits, rules, turn orders details just killed the "epicness" of the game for me.  And even the epic space battles broke down to whoever had more ships, and got luckier on the dice rolls.  Way too much turtling then a mad dash for as many victory points as you can.  I really wanted to like it more than I did, but the length of game and the lack of immersion really killed it for me.  I would play this again if asked and people really needed another, but it would be far from my first choice.  Would NOT recommend to a casual gamer since people will most likely get pissed off at you for being confused and you would get bored/frustrated at the barrage of rules and administration.  I can see it can be a "brilliant game" if everyone knew all the rules to the minutia and were efficient about the chits administration but it just wasn't for me.  Not to say I didn't enjoy the game, but based on the way the ratings are worded, I'm forced to give it a 1.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
After the first play or two, this game almost ended up on ebay.  After successfully pushing for another game however (who wants to take the time to sell something on ebay) we started to realize that there was actually a large amount of depth to the game, in addition to all the moving parts and fancy components.  
The game has a lot going on, so much so that its sort of hard to keep track of what everyone else is up - which to me is a good thing.  Due to its variable playing area, huge variety of victory conditions (objectives), distinct races, huge tech tree, dozens of Action and Poltical cards, and especially the Strategy cards, the game offers a rare mix of diplomacy, resource management and expansion, tactics, and strategy, and is guaranteed to never play the same. It is not meant to be a risk-like player elimination wargame, its far from it.  And if played as intended is a fun, immersive, and fairly deep game.  The game does need a little help though with the political aspects, but there are some really good posted variants for this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Second game with 4 players actually took much longer and we agreed to end early when 1am rolled around. Played until 7 victory points instead of 10. This game rocks! I may even like it better than Tide Of Iron. (note: I believe we were using 1 or 2 rules from the expansion)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The definition of epic. Can easily take over 6 hours for a game with a full complement of players.
I love the depth of this game; tech tree, politics, trading - it's got it all.

I have heard a lot of people saying the game 'requires' the expansion to work properly, but I must say I have thoroughly enjoyed playing the base game alone. The only change we have made from the expansion was using the Imperial II strategy card text to remove the restrictive, frustrating 'game clock' mechanic imposed by the original Imperial strategy card.

I can see the game clock being useful if you really want to play the game in a shorter timespan, but the single occasion we played with it I found it simply narrows your choice for two turns in a row (or you will fall behind in the victory point league) as Initiative and Imperial make their way around the table.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Two plays, and that was more than enough.  What are all these hardcore gamers and BGG veterans thinking, rating this a 9 and 10?  Is this game the equivalent of a souped-up car?  I think it is.  This could have been a great game, and I feel as if all the good reviews are wishing that it were, rather than dealing with what's actually behind the big box and pretty bits.  No game that has to be so extensively patched and then still takes hours uponb hours to play with little fun to be had should possibly be rated so highly.  In a year, I predict this game will sit on the shelf, largely unplayed.  Petersen has some great ideas, he just can't implement them well, and playtests them not at all.

UPDATE:  Bumped up a point and a half, as I'm reacting more to the BGG TI3 fantatics than to the game itself, which I would play again under some very severe conditions.

RATING: 7
Provisional rating after just a single play and I have to say right up front that I found the whole experience very enjoyable indeed.  

Sure it was a looooooonnnnngggg session, particularly being the first game for most of the players - in fact the most "experienced" had only played it once about 9 months ago!  But, what an immense, immersive, enthralling system.  There are layers and layers of subtleties and interactions, never quite enough command counters and a true sense of the universe not quite being big enough for all the races.  

The biggest compliment I can give this game is that after a single marathon session I'm dying to play it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The classic big space opera game from Fantasy Flight from the days where they made coffin sized boxes and blew gamers away (to be fair they are still pretty damned good). 

This game has it, tech development, combat, player interaction and race based abilities. The minis are cool and it used a hybrid design to introduce Euro elements to a dudes on a map game. 

Problem is, for many people there was too much in the design and games can take a long time to play out. This is perhaps unfair on the design as it is the players that can drag out a game by 'turtling' and playing defensive when they need to be more aggressive. 

I wanted to love this but my play group was not right for it. TI needs a group that understands it well and knows how to play it (a bit like Titan) to keep the play time manageable.

RATING: 5
The 2nd edition had a lot or problems. A 3rd edition was a good opportunity to solve those problems and maintain what is good in the previous versions. That was my hope. Unfortunately the designer went a step further. He wanted to incorporate the influence from the flood of euro games. I simply don't like the result because the various mechanism don't work together and seem too artificial. Also the problem of the long duration has not been solved as the options provided for a shorter game seem unsatisfactory to me. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
If you never had the chance to play it, but already think Eclipse or Exodus are epic - wait till you actually see this FFG Magnum Opus in action. While it absolutely is too long for a normal gaming-session, consider bringing it out as an event on a rainy saturday afternoon. You almost can't escape jumping into the role of the race you picked, it just happens because the game supports it with every rule and game mechanic. Awesome!

RATING: 6
My god, what a box!  So far I've played 3 games (a 5 player game that took almost 7 hours, a 5 hour 4-player game and a 7h 6player game) and boy it was fun, epic and a struggle.  The rules are actually very easy (given that it has a 44 page rulebook) and gameplay is elegant.  The pieces are just gorgeous.  Waw, this is a great game.  Epic Space Opera is the perfect description, and it deserves a high rating, but the demand on time is just too high for our group to play this... That's why I've bought Eclipse, and that seems to scratch the TI3 itch just fine... :-)

RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
TI3 is a game unlike most others I've played. It literally boggles the mind with the amount of strategic options players have at their disposals each turn, and it's easily one of the best and most brilliantly designed games I've played. I can see myself playing TI3 for years to come, and right now my goal is to play one game with each of the 10 races to get a handle on each of their special abilities and gaming styles. 

After playing the game quite a lot since it came out, I'm lowering it to a mere "9". The reason for this is mostly because there are a few more or less broken elements that, though very minor, detract from making this a prefect game. However, I feel the expansion adresses all this and more, and I give TI with the expansion a full 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ameritrash heaven. Beautiful production, excellently written rulebook. The game has lots of rules, but it is surprisingly easy to teach, although some AP occurs due to the myriad of options.

Nice mix of strategy, tactics, luck, diplomacy and trade. Use some houserules for map setup though to prevent screwage.

Playtime is a killer though. It can go on for 1 hour per player. Depending on the playergroup the game can tend to bog down on a turtling deathmatch.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Two plays in, I've downgraded from a 10 to a 7. It is a fun game, but it can be quite slow in the first few turns, though this might just be beacuse I've played both times with complete newbies. The roles can seem forced- Speaker is dumb if he doesn't take Imperial, 2nd chooser is dumb if he doesn't take Initiative, etc. The 1pt ISC might make this less bothersome, but the roles still seem unbalanced, in terms of what they allow and what they give the other players a chance to do.

Might upgrade again with another play, although I am no longer convinced this is the perfect game, and I no longer want to spend $80 on it, whereas before I was ready to sell organs to get a copy.

RATING: 6.5

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Very Good. Nice boards and bits. The rules can't be more fiddly, because the game would be unplayable. I was very disappointed after my first play, perhaps knowing a little bit more about the rules, the game would give our gaming group more fun. What a relief I didn't buy the Shattered Empire Expansion.
Out first play took about 8 hours between explanation to 4 of the 6 players, a lot of discussion about some game rules, and two VERY SLOW players on the table. I don't see this game hitting the table soon again.

Excellent: 2007/02/27: WOW... three player game, three hours. Now, you can feel how the game works. The rules are not that fiddly as I thought after the first game. Clearly, your first game after punching the bits should be a three player, get familiar with the rules, feel the game flowing, and get ready for the six player epic battle.
There's also, another important thing about this game... don't talk too much outside the game. My group talks and jokes a lot, but playing this game, requires focus on the board and gameflow to prevent the 9 hours sessions. 

2007/04/20: I hate this game when it gets played with the wrong people. You need fast decision makers on this one. I WON'T ever again play this game for 7 hours. It can be played within 4 or 5 hours and the playing group needs to be chosen properly.  With the right group, this game I still consider it awesome, but with the wrong group, I barely enjoy it. I'm not going to take this down to 8, because I still want to try the Epic Battle with fast players, no chat taking the game into LONGER sessions, and even if I prefer games in which you can make jokes or something, for certain, TI3 CAN NOT afford that.

2007/07/13: The more I play this game, the more I dislike it. Someday I will have to try the Shattered Empire expansion and see if it improves the gaming experience. This game really needs the expansion.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I really enjoy this game - there's that part of me that loves that epic space game thing, and this game comes closer to the mark than anything else I've seen.

There are a few problems. I'm usually against using house-rules in games, but in this case I was happy to mess with the victory conditions - I think these actually improved the game a lot. I especially recommend these victory conditions that this 'mendosa' guy came up with (Update: he's now working for FFG on the expansion, so maybe we'll see these in the official game before too long...):

http://www.boardgamegeek.com/fileinfo.php?fileid=15918
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/fileinfo.php?fileid=15919

Unfortunately you're in for a 6+ hour game, much of which you will spend pretty much hatching your own plans and pushing your pieces around. It looks like player interaction, but actually it's more like a convention of bond villains. Everyone sits around, rubbing their hands together and plotting their little plots.  There's not much actual action, just a lot of anticipation of action... until everyone goes crazy in the last couple of turns and someone ends up on top. That being said, it's been totally engrossing everytime I've played it, and we've always ended up hashing out the gameplay afterwards, which is always a good sign. I would probably play this baby a lot more if it wasn't for the playing time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A game for crazy people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
First play was an epic 14 hours.  The time went by fast and I never felt bored.  I love this game.  I am sure we will get the time down, half the table was new.  I'm not crazy about player elimination, I will have to read up on some house rules to see how to maybe avoid that, but it happened around the 10th hour so the player that got eliminated was happy to go home.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Definetly the most epic game on the market. I wont rate it a 10 because you need to keep playing fast (else it could take up to 12 hours instead of 6). You should also explain the game on a different day than the one you play. Even a first round can be played in 6hours. Good rounds manage it to play it in 1hour per player.

Increased the rating to 10. Currently my favorite game. Play it whenever possible (which is not that often with a game that long)

Update 2016: Reduced 10->9 simply because it is too long and I can't get it to the table.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Note: This rating is based on my limited experience, I've only ever played once. I played a 6-player game in which 2 friends had played multiple times, 1 had played just once, and 3 of us had never played. A 30-min how-to video was played beforehand, but I took little from it and felt about to fail a test. 
This game is fun, but not my favorite. It's not only a very long game (ours took 9 hours after set up), there's a lot of downtime between your turns even once everybody has a decent understanding of their options. No other complaints though, I think it's a very well thought out game and I disagree about it being biased against people who've not played it before. Despite being uncertain what I was doing more than half the time and making several small mistakes, I won the first time I played. My only reason to not want to play is that it is sooo long so that a day must be set aside for a single play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
There are at least a dozen very cool mechanics or design elements of this game, and I enjoyed many different aspects of it the three games I played. My only complaint was that its almost too much. There's so many facets and strategic and tactical paths that ultimately my choices seemed a bit arbitrary. I'm a high level game player, I'm not afraid of rigorous strategic thought. I've ogt a rack of chess trophy's and have invested hours upon hours into numerous TCG's, and long and complex board games like Civilizaton and I.C.E.'s Lord of the Rings. But somehow the trade off between the effort I needed to put in to T.E. vs. the return on that effort, divided by the number of hours required to play didn't yeild an 8,9 or 10. I think a slightly less complex version might yeild a better play experience.

That said, I would (and will) play again and perhaps I'll change my rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

Some of the cards, however, get pretty close to breaking the game, as they may destroy someone's carefully planned - and even safe-guarded - strategy in one move. In any case, just for the experience and for the variety - of races and strategies - it gets a 10 for now.

Edit: And it's a 9. Some cards are definitely too much.
