RATING: 7
A truly epic game that lasts a bit too long for it's welcome.  I have only played one game of this so far, but it brought up a few things that I did not enjoy.  

1. We played with the objectives available for us to look at for this particular game and they were greatly bent towards technology, which I had less of.  

2. My secret mission seemed quite a bit harder than the other secret missions out there.  

3. After 9 hours of gaming the person that waits the longest to attack gets a hearty bonus (fresh army), and on top of this ultimately the game ending decision came to the players that were not even in contention to win, i.e. if we selected these actions he wins, if we DONT select these actions the other guy wins.

Even after all is said and done this game was STILL a blast to play and I would love to play again while drastically changing my approach.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Holy cats, talk about a game living up to expectations.  This "game" is the equivalent of a 80-pound Lego set: Elements of lots of other games (special racial abilities, primary/secondary role choices, political voting, the obvious Risk and Diplomacy parallels) and every sci-fi work either written or created for your computer are packed together in one messy, glorious jam, with tons of optional rules to keep things fresh (or more closely parallel your favorite universe).  In fact, you'll NEED to adapt this game to your group's tastes: Do you prefer your objectives known at the top of the game, or slowly revealed?  Do you want to make fighting a more attractive option, or do you prefer a cold war?  Do you want to make the ISC a little less powerful, or more so?  Every turn provides tons of options, all of them difficult to make with your limited resources -- you'll want to do everything, and you'll have to focus on the true objectives of the game.  Plenty of politicking and a little bit of kingmaking at the end if you're not careful.

Are none of these options attractive, and you'd prefer to play out a game based on your favorite sci-fi universe?  Look online.  Star Wars, Star Trek, Star Trek: TNG, Bab5, Dune, Stargate... print them out and go crazy.  Folks are making their own planetary systems, their own strategy cards, religious systems, deeper trade systems, and tons of other options on a nearly daily basis.

TI3 is an true epic, averaging about an hour per player and an hour of explanation.  And it's worth every second and every dollar.  I suggest playing with the base rules once, deciding what looks good in the Lego box, and seasoning to taste.

RATING: 5
Lowered from a 9 to a 5. The game is totally broken. Depending on setup, certain races can be worse than a race with no special abilities. Certain secret objectives can actually be impossible. Its too easy for the person who knows the game the most to take advantage of new players. I've played it three times and all three games ended unexpectedly when one person who had an easy secret objective suddenly claims 5+ points in a single turn. I think the worst part is the game holds so much promise and then is always epicly disappointing in its resolution. Basically, the "game" is just a secret handing out of "I win" cards, and then we all perform a really complicated series of pointless maneuvers until the person plays their "I win" card. I can imagine that in theory this "I win" card might not be dealt and the game could be amazingly balanced and a ton of fun. In practice, this happens rarely if ever. And its LOOONG.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
It has some posible balance issues with planet tiles placement, first players, and so on, but even if some players might get an "unfair" advantage, that does not make them winners automatically.

The game is fun, enjoyable, not deep, but it's very long, and we always spend an undecent part of that time navigating through the rules, somthing you can't avoid unless you play it very often. That's way too many time for the entertaing value I get from the game. 

There are some other issues, like being forced to chose the Imperium/Initiative card, or the the first players get an unfair advantage, being able to use it more times than their opponents. Some of this issues could be houseruled, but this is someething I don't like to do in games, unless I play them very often (something that never happens with any game).

The game components are very good. I can only complain about some units being too similar to others.

Overall, it's a nice experience, but one that I'm not willing to repeat often, because of its excesive lenght.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I love the concept and style of the game - it's stacked with variable set ups, factions and technologies to explore, plus numerous extra bits to customise each game. Everything points to a big box of fun - which it is, if you have plenty of time and like minded opponents. However, despite the array of components the gameplay isn't especially varied. Yes, you have different styles of play depending on your faction and events can change some rules, but I feel the game has a script where it builds up slowly to a flashpoint where suddenly one player attacks and the others jump on the remains (or the leader)... or not, because as the board doesn't really relate to the collecting of victory points you don't need to confront the other players (except over Mecatol Rex) and the game can become very static. 

Also the victory conditions don't allow the players to specialise and attain victory through conquest, politics or economic domination. Warfare isn't essential, despite the massive (defensive) build up that occur, and economics and politics given very minor roles, which seems a waste in a "game of epic galactic trade, politics and conquest". The game has these elements but they are all a sideshow to the main event which is the collection of technology, resources, influence and maybe a grab at the centre planet. 

Overall, Twilight Imperium 3 has too much chrome, downtime and small frustrating rules and not enough substance to make a great space epic, which is a shame as there is very little on the market that comes close... I'll just have to play it some more until there is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Colossal. Vast. Legendary. Heroic. Homeric. Epic.

One of the best games ever designed, TI3 is all of the above and more.  No two games will ever play out the same way due to its vast and grand scale. Negotiation, backstabbing, political intrigue, double crossing, kidnapping and murder; with spaceships, wormholes and lasers.

Can't play this game enough due literally to its daunting length and the time commitment that must be made.  I get to play it about twice a year due to the difficulty of scheduling out the six to ten hour game length and finding the friends that are willing to commit to seeing it through.  Wife out of town?  Time to schedule a game.  Two weeks vacation? Lets carve out a day; come over at noon.  

I will be teaching/playing this game with five teenagers (aged 15 to 17) this summer at a camp.  I have scheduled five consecutive days each consisting of two hour sessions. Will it be enough?  I think not since they have not played before.  But they will get a good taste of what this Wagnerian  epic has to offer.  Sam Healy, where are you? 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
Very good epic empire building game.  Colonizing planets, developing new technology, waging war, producing combat units, conducting trade and engaging in diplomacy.  Rules are fairly detailed, lots of player choices and options.  Plenty of sci-fi colour/theme.  The voting and trade mechanics provide for plenty of diplomacy.  Components are very nice and the game is very pretty to look at.

I have put about 7 hours into this game (two different games, not nearly to completion).  Downtime seems reasonable but the full game is probably quite long (a good 6 hours or more with 4 players?)  The game should have lots of replay value, due to the variable set-up, different races and other cards.  Certainly a lot of luck involved, especially the action cards which can completely surprise you.  Probably some balance issues with the races as well, but couldn't detect anything too serious.

All in all a fun game, though probably too long and too much downtime for some people's tastes.

RATING: N/A
This is more of a "Civilization in space" game than a wargame. Played as a wargame instead of a civilization/evolution game, a couple of hours of gaming time is added to an otherwise long game. 

The game is really about victory points and not about what happens on the gaming board. You have to be able to accept this fact and play for victory points instead of concentrating too much on the board, or you might be disappointed.

The game suffers from long down-time and runaway leader tendencies.

Initial setup can can decide who wins the game before it starts, which is a terrible thing in a game as long as this (4   hours). Too unbalanced for its game length.

RATING: 9
If played with the right people this is a great game.  If played with the wrong people it can be strangely unsatisfying.

Edit: This is a game that gets much better as you get more familiar with all the intricate rules.

Edit: This is clearly a game you've got to put a lot of effort into playing, but the more you play it the better it seems to get.  I've got no hesitation in saying it's one of my favourite games of all time now.  Back when it first came out I wrote a review for the game but I should have waited a couple of years - my paltry review doesn't do the game justice.

Edit: dropped a point off my mark.  My last couple of games of this fell really flat.  When this game works it's one of the best gaming experiences ever.  When it doesn't, it's very unsatisfying.

RATING: 8
Impressions after one play of the "Shattered Ascention" community mod (includes both expansions, but no optional rules, many many tweaked rules).

Okay, now that's one of those games that I had a dream of the night after the first play. There aren't many games out there that got me so far. Lot's of things I totally love about board games, but I can also see why some people really dislike it. Because It's messy. because it's very much a typical FFG release with too much play time and an awful amount of fiddliness. Causes frustrations in the vein of "Conquer the world" Risk and Diplomacy. Because, like all 4x games with a really long play time, I expect it to be a fun killer for all players who drop out of the race. 

Still, TI3 is a game I'd always want to play NOW.

In all honesty, the way TI3 comes out of the box, I don't know if I wanted to rather just abstain and rate it a 3 or 4. With all the fixes etc., well yeah, more like a 9.

RATING: 8
Great game for those days you want it to be complex, massive and full of intrigue.
This game has several rule systems for different parts [politics, exploration, scientific development, war] which all combine under the umbrella of having to chose your main strategy every turn [through the use of specific cards].
The only bad thing about the game, is its length. It can easily run into a 12 hour game [from the moment you open the box till someone wins] if 4 people play it [4 make for the most interesting game, IMHO], though 6 to 8 hours is much more of the norm.

RATING: 5
I know I rate this game lower than it's average, but that's just the way it goes.  I love SciFi games and war games.  This just doesn't hook me.

I find TI:3 too fiddly.  It's a cross between Puerto Rico and Throneworld in my mind, and just takes too long for what it is.  In the base game, there's little "need" for combat and holdings on the map rarely translate much into actual victory or defeat.

The idea of the roles in the game is OK, but I find the execution lacking.  It just makes the game really long and more involved for me.

Too fiddly, too little drive to fight, too little gain for eating your opponent's lunch.

My real problem with this game is the difficulty in finding the time, space and 4-5 opponents required to play it properly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
1 play - First play was 3rd addition (during which time 4th edition was available for pre-order). Wow was I blown away with this game, which I just expected to be an epic version of other battle games. Its the VP scoring from objectives that truly make this game great, as the focus really becomes on negotiating deals to obtain objectives (NOT total dominance). These means that alliances formed by players are NOT ultimately undermined by the knowledge that one player will need to destroy the others in the end (which is generally true in a lot of war games like it). In fact, many objectives are not even battle related!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Era dai tempi di Buck Rogers che non giocavo a un balocco con ambientazione spaziale classica, e ci voleva proprio. Il setting è azzeccatissimo, ed è bello che sia regole (tante) che lunghezza del gioco (per niente breve) contribuiscano a caratterizzare l'ambientazione (dopotutto una space opera è lunga e complessa... un gioco che vi si ispira può essere breve e semplice?). Un po' di considerazioni sparse: 

1) il gioco è una festa per gli occhi: i soldatini, la grafica delle carte, gli splendidi esagononi. solo a vederlo ti fa star bene e ringrazi di essere un geek. 
2) nel gioco non stai mai fermo. Non conosco la vecchia edizione, ma tutti lamentano una certa staticità che adesso è fortunatamente sparita. 
3) mi sono piaciute le carte strategia alla Puerto Rico. 
4) anche se all'inizio è frustrante, la presenza di innumerevoli colli di bottiglia (numero contato di mosse, numero contato di navi costruibili da una stazione, numero contato di navi che possono coesistere nello stesso sistema, ecc.) aiuta a rendere il gioco più equilibrato: a che serve avere mille unità produttive se puoi costruire solo quattro cose per volta? 
5) la parte politica mi ha lasciato piuttosto freddo. leggendo le regole, speravo in qualcosa di più decisivo come in Warrior Knights, dove le vittorie passano dall'Assemblea. 
6) chi in "World of Warcraft - il gioco da tavolo" si faceva le pippe guardando gli oggetti e i poteri, qui se le fa col tech tree. è davvero enorme e sfaccettato ma, mi chiedo, non sarà un po' troppo grande e un po' sopravvalutato per la vittoria finale? 
Concludendo, un gran gioco: non breve, non semplice ma ottimo e da rigiocare all'infinito: peccato che la sua durata sia veramente scoraggiante.

4/13 traded for Eclipse

You can tell at the time I was in the middle of my "crazy" period, where I was buying $100 of games a month, and was playing all of them. Now its down to about $300/year or so, a lot more on iOS. And today I am a fan of cleaner, simpler, more elegant designs. And more playable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
CC-COA
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's a sprawling space opera that has not been replicated in any other game. It can be quite long depending on how well versed the players are and the variants being used, but with experience, the play time is ~60 minutes per player. The races feel unique, the techs are fun and the game isn't about military strength most of the time. The political phase is by far my favorite part of the game. Passing laws can leave some very memorable moments. The first expansion, while not 100% necessary, does fix the issue with the Imperium tile. Turn order basically passed every single turn as getting a free point is WAY too good to pass up. It can literally be 10-20% of your score by doing absolutely nothing each turn.

Extras: FFG Sleeves - Mini Yellow and 4 d10's in each player color.

[b]Variants Used Each Time:[/b] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0AkoE5l_7R84NdHhVSDJhRFFQalB4VE5jYlRfWGhqc0E&usp=sharing#gid=0
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played a three player game once ...just WOW! Update December 2016 - played our first 6 player game, all new players. Game took 8 hours ending with epic battles for Mecatol Rex and smaller 'other' wars at the edges of the galaxy. All players enjoyed it so much we didn't really want it to end. Only disappointment seemed to be with the political cards which rarely applied to anything relevant but everything else was engrossing at almost every point!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really wanted to like this game.
And the 2 times we have played it it has been a blast... for 2-3 hours.
You build your fleets and build more and have fun and then when you would like to use them the game is over.
Or you have already played for 4-5 hours and start to get really bored already.
Too slow pace in the game.
You build starport, wait till next turn to build a fleet, wait again till next turn and then you move the fleet.
3 turns to get an attack going!
Anyone has time to react to that!!
Faster pace and better objectives really needed to save this game.

I just read the new rules for the expansion.
Seems that the expansion corrects(!) a lot of the mistakes with the original.
Better strategy cards, more aggresive Objectives, quick start rules to get it going, faster colonization of empty planets (via a strategy card), cheaper technology,  etc.
It's a shame that the expansion costs 50 (!) Euro since it makes the game become more like what the original should have been!
The rating would be much higher also if the playing time was shorter. Now it never gets played because it takes so long time.

We have now played twice with the expansion. Fantastic game! Just a shame about the playing time. We can never finish a full game of this. But it was fun both times anyway!

RATING: 7
I wasn’t sure if I would ever actually play this, or if I would like it if I did. It turns out, I was pleasantly surprised. There are more euro-y resource management elements than I expected, and they dovetailed nicely with the pure Ameritrash of huge fleets of plastic spaceships and handfuls of dice. We played a 3 player game in about 5 hours. The trade and negotiation elements of them game were not prominent, and the experienced player reported that comes from the low player count. I’m not sure I’d ever want to go above 4 players due to the length of the game, but we’re already planning another session soon.

RATING: 9
After getting through the complex and endless rules, we really liked this game.  It took some time to get the hang of it though.

I like all of the different aspects of the game and the various tactics and methods available to achieve victory points.

My negative thought was the luck factor in battles.  While you may heavily outgun your opponent, you can still lose solely to bad luck.  That is a shame.

I think that it is highly replayable if you allow a really long time to play.  Very much worth devoting the time to do so though.  Can't wait to try it again.

The more that I play this game, the more that I really like it!

RATING: 9

I played this with a good amount of people I've never met before and it was still a blast playing.  I would recommend this highly for anyone that doesn't mind a game that will honestly take an entire day for them to play.  Out of all of the long games I've played this is by far my favorite, and the best part about it is that there are so many modules and ways to play that I will probably never get to experience them all (as opposed to other long games).

If one was ambitious it could probably be modified to be a great game, but at 5-6 hours a game you would really have to love this game.

RATING: N/A
-

There are too many issues with this game.  Way, way too long for a light Axis & Allies or Risk 2210 type of game.  It has serious balance issues. You can practically lose the game during the initial setup, even before the play has begun! Very fiddly and messy with a huge number of components. In fact, so many components that make it difficult to play the game on any normal or even large size table.  Gets frustratingly slow and boring as hell due to long down time and time spent on logistics that have no impact on the game results.
Perhaps enjoyable to hardcore space/si-fi fans, but as for me, I would rather play Axis & Allies or Risk 2210 than TI.
 (Based on a single play 05/14/05).

RATING: 9
Update: after collecting dust on the shelf for several years, this game finally got to the table for a real play. And it's everything it should be, and more. This game is an event game, to be sure, only pulled out once in a blue moon. However, if you're into epic gameplay, and have the right group (an ABSOLUTE NECESSITY!), you will treasure this title.

Older: Love what I've experienced of this game. My game group is not very receptive to complex, long games. This game is both of those...very complex, and very long. One needs to have a group of like-minded players in order to get this to the table.

However, even based on the sporadic experiences I've had with this game, with relatively unwilling players, it was still always a great game session (at least for me). I suppose what I'm trying to say is that this game is aimed at a very specific type of player. If you are that type, and are willing to hunt around for others, than this game will reward you for your efforts.

RATING: 6
[b]Comment:[/b] Epic area control game where you compete with other players for both public and secret goals for points. Takes 8-11 hours to play with max players, even when everyone knows all the rules. 

Despite it being a highly strategic game, it uses dice for combat. The game also pretty much requires expansions to be playable thanks to the final job card being too powerful in the base.

No game so far has come along and replaced this as our epic space game, but that's not to say this behemoth couldn't still use some streamlining. In particular, the technology deck is difficult to understand, as the way some techs need other techs first means you really need to know the deck well and decide what you will work to before the game begins.

:star: Art and components
:star: Innovative mechanics
:star: Handles 5 or more players
:nostar: Good with min or max players
:star: Low time between turns
:nostar: Comfortable complexity
:star: Re-playability
:star::nostar::nostar: Enjoyment

RATING: 10
ITS A CLASSIC NIGGA
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
It is a good game, and sometimes I consider buying it when a good opportunity arrives, but there are some things that annoy me to no end in this game.

The implementation of the theme in this version (third edition) is somewhat faulty. So, the council has decided... so what? What if I'm a rogue nation? What if I don't like all that dialogue and feel I can just keep fighting to conquer all until there is but one people standing? That's the thing you SHOULD be doing in this game, only you're not. The game seems to stay forever on the edge of action - and in the end very little of significance really happens.

It doesn't have enough conflict to please the grognard in me, it's not strategic enough to please my inner eurogamer and it has too many flaws in the narrative it creates to make me completely immerse in its theme.

Let's take this out of the way: Politics in this game is just a card game where one player tries to block the other in ways that far too often make no thematic sense whatsoever. It's politics as if every country in our World just blindly obeyed the United Nations on matters like technology research... Many things that may make you win the game make very little sense on a second analysis.

I feel that to fully enjoy this game you must make an effort to convince yourself that the logic behind the way the game works is not gamey but thematic instead (this would be ok if the game played in, like, 3-4 hours... it doesn't).

It's not everyday that I'm in the mood to do that for such a long period of time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEPIC!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I have an OCD desire to see if the 'poorly rated' wargames are really that bad, so....

1 4-p game (wuth SE expansion)that went almost 9 hours with at least a couple of more to go. I was the only person not to have played before but there were so many rule uncertainties and errors, and combined with having never seen the Action or Political Card decks (nor the Objective decks) the play was glacial and pure chaos. It felt like the leaders would be beaten back in succession so the VPs would be gained at about equal rates until someone made a shot for the big Secret Objective points for the win (somewhat like Catan). So it felt as pointless as Risk until the endgame was reached but it took far far too long to get there. I will avoid playing this game again at almost all costs.

Note: With more experience the game would flow better but still would not go above a 5 in my book.

RATING: 8
An epic - meaning LONG - empire building game. Definitely for the Sci-Fi fan in you. 
This is a hard game to rate. 
Certainly a beautiful game with outstanding components. Does a good job of capturing the feel of its theme. 
An outstanding game? No too many game issues including - the length, random factors, problems with balance reigning the leaders, catching up when you are behind hamper it. 
A poor game? No there is a lot of options for your turn and the game has a lot of likable mechanics for example the strategy card and the command counter mechanics to limit your actions. 
Feel the variants with Age of Empire (revealed objects) help focus people on what is necessary for the game. With out it you must have a list of the public objectives so you can be aware of what is coming. At the very least a new player needs a list of all the possible public objectives. 
Not as convinced about the alternative SC8. While the base version limits some selection of roles it acts a nice timer. However, all players have to remember to work against the players who gets the sc8 twice. It does throw an advantage to players 1 and 2.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've been wanting to play this game for 15 years. I finally had my first chance on 06/03/16. I initially scored this a 9, but downgraded it to an 8 after my second play (see below). The first time was a fantastic experience, but two issues stood out for me as problematic:

1) It's not really a 4X game. It's a point collection game. I learned this the hard way towards the end of the game. You often need to do things that are counter-intuitive for a 4X type experience to get the points. I will be better prepared for future plays, but it does take something away from the storytelling and epic nature of what a true 4X should be. Attacking a player to get a point, the other player being ok with that, and avoiding a more protracted war, is more of a Euro-style mechanic, which irks me a bit, and was not what I would have expected from this game.

2) I was given an preliminary objective card at the start of the game that was fairly opposed to my racial bonuses and goals. I had to go off and focus on something that didn't make a lot of sense so I could turn in the preliminary objective card to get my secret objective card. This wasted a lot of time. In future games, I will ask for a house rule where you can get two preliminary objective cards (and secret objective cards) and pick one of them. This seems less punitive.

My first game was 7-8 hours of play with five players. I love this game and want to play it again soon. Here's the thing, though – if I had 7-8 hours to play a five-person space 4X game, and the 4x experience was what I was craving, I would prefer to play Stellaris by Paradox Interactive, a true 4X space computer game, with four of my friends around a table with laptops. And, I'm much more of a board gamer than I am a video gamer. Twilight Imperium III is not a shining example of 4x, but it's a shining example of board games.

I played my second game on 10/16/16. It ended up as a 10-hour long game for four players. If I am going to dedicate 10 hours to game, it needs to have the epic game payoff and I don't think that's possible for me with just four players. There's not enough dynamic activity with just four. Add to that, when you are playing this game with four players, you use all eight strategy cards, which means a four player game is actually longer than a five and perhaps six player game. This second experience downgraded the game from a 9 to an 8 for me. I don't think I will want to play this game again with just four players. Either give me a big, epic, multi-dimensional game with lots of activity or give me a shorter game with less players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Shards of the Throne

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
My favorite game. At first I was reluctant to get this since it is hard to find a group committed to play it through the end, but even in our unfinished games we had TONS of fun (and the time just flew).

I recommend this to any heavy gamer with a mature group. The mechanics are very clean and streamlined. The amount of decision making and politics involved on this game is enormous, but the mechanics works so well that you never fell overwhelmed.

Also, there is very little downtime. The actions takes little time to complete, and you usually want to pay attention to the actions of your opponents while planning your next action.

The base game comes with some balance issues that does become obvious after some plays. The first expansion fixes that entirely.

RATING: 8
Very fun in depth game.  Good for hardcore players only, very rule heavy.  Playtime is insanely long.  Would rate higher but playtime is just too long.

Had a group that used to meet in Madison to play this game all day long once a month for about 6 months.  We had some really good times playing it.  Due to the game's political nature, you can really enjoy jumping into your role with either friends or people you don't know.  By the end, you'll all be at each other's throats either way (hopefully the people you play with won't remain this way after the game ha).

Definitely recommend randomized seating for any group where you don't know the individuals involved.  The political nature of the game can grant advantages to those willing to team up for part of the game, and friends tend to do this irrationally.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
There are a lot of great things about TI. Combat is simple, yet involving. The tech tree is well thought out (even though it requires a bit of work to navigate/organize it), and the game strongly encourages a proper amount of teamwork and betrayal.

All of that being said, sometimes I feel the winning conditions of the game don't line up with the awesome mechanics. Combat seems unnecessary until you need more influence due to the random (often imbalanced) victory point conditions. The game practically rewards turtling.

Variants exist to make these issues more manageable. Just make sure you have them figured out before sitting down for your 6 to 10 hour long game.

As good as it is, it's even better with the Shattered Empire expansion.

RATING: 5
Complex, engaging, politically challenging... for the first hour or two, then let the chaos begin! =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
>>>Note how ratings drop as I got to know the game better.
First play: Rated a 9.
3rd play: Rated a 7.5.
5th play: Rated a 6.0.
~9th play: Rated a 4.0

Fighters are overpowered (and destroyers are underpowered) and why in the world have they put in all these event cards to make big ships even more useless?  

Random victory conditions mean that you are likely to be hosed for entire duration of the game.  (e.g. a peaceful race with no combat bonuses gets military victory conditions.)

Voting on laws sounds like a cool idea, but rarely does it matter.  B5 game has votes that are more important which works better.

Played a couple more games, and both times a player was totally out of the game from inappropriate victory conditions.  This is very bad for a game this long.

Many people have mentioned how early players have a huge advantage over those in later positions.  This is a race game to 10 VP.  But rules are set up so players get 20% of their VP each time they start the round.  So player in 1st position has gained 4/10 of victory (with free victory points) when he starts 2nd round.  If 1st player doesn't win on his turn, second player is at 4/10 of victory on next turn.  Rarely in a 4 or 5 player game, does 3rd player get a chance to get to 4/10 of victory (with these free points) as the game is usually won by then.  I've never seen a player in 4th or 5th position win this game.  Why would they want to play a 5 - 6 hour game when they are walking dead the whole game?

Have stopped using game rules, when we play we use Owll's rules.  Feels to me like this game was never blind tested by FFG.  For $100 I expect a game to be tested and obvious problems fixed.  Don't feel I should have to buy an expansion to fix gaping problems in base game.  (Their "Game of Thrones 1st edition" boardgame was the same way.)  Last Fantasy Flight Game I will buy.

Game rewards turtling far more often than aggressive play.  None of my friends want to play anymore.  I'm going to sell my copy.

Played "Eclipse".  Now I am sure I'm going to sell my copy.

RATING: 8.5
I played half a game of this back in 2008, and within 6 months I bought my own copy. Such is the nature of the beast that it took me until May 2012 to actually play my copy - and when I did it got played two weekends in a row.

The bad points? Play time is crippling - unless everyone knows what they're doing you're looking at upwards of 1.5 hours per player. It's ridiculously unbalanced at times - not so much from the dice but the overpowering nature of some of the cards. 

But for all that - it feels right. It feels big, and epic, and how taking over the galaxy should feel.

RATING: 9
I love this game.  It isn't perfect, but I love the theme.  Probably more than anything else for me, is the theme.  I love building an empire, I love researching technologies, I love big space ships, I love space battles, I love conquering planets.

It has numerous downsides (time needed to play, no self-balancing mechanics where the current loser gets helped and the current winner gets hindered), but at the same time, I think it helps with the theme of "You're building an empire...in space!", rather than playing a game about building an empire in space.

I play this anytime I can get at least 2 other hardcore gamers together for 6 hours or more.

RATING: 3

RATING: 5.65
I've only given it two goes but I have to admit to being disappointed (games that involve this amount of time that do not reward you in two playings have a flaw). Many aspects of the game are cobbled togethor from other sources in a way that doesn't quite work, bits from Eurogames being shoved in (such as the inbuilt timer which attracts so much criticism) without real consideration for how it will affect everything. There is a good game underneath it all and it could probably be brought out if the chrome were radically stripped back (remove trade completely and lose most of the politics, then push it back to a series of military objectives). There is a lot in here but the reality is that the game does everything it is trying to do worse than a game like Buck Rogers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is certainly an experience.  After 1 complete play, there is plenty to keep track of in this game.  Additional player aides for ships etc is a must I think.  Really enjoyed the experience, however, the objective cards with which to score VP's are completely random.  Some of these being completely impossible to achieve, others relatively easy.  It would make more sense these being race specific in the first place rather than pot luck.
I would like to see more trade & diplomacy next time to see if this raises the gamed beyond what essentially turned into a combat centric game.
It promises a lot, with different strategy cards, but whether due to our groups style of gaming, it certainly seemed some of them were less viable to win with.
Coming more from a Euro background, the element of luck vs strategy is greater than I would have anticipated for such a lengthy game.

last played 29.11.14. 3 player game. preliminary objectives vary greatly and meant player secret objectives were hard to get.

Why this is in my collection
Its a space epic, its occasion, played for the experience.  From the games we've played, I would suggest its more prone to luck than strategy.  Happy that we play this, even if its just once a year.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
--------------------- TI3 -----------------------

Such a huge game deserves a huge entry in my collection.

With two sets of expansions we can play with up to 10 players. (but alas the flagships and some tech from Shards of the Throne would be missing from that).
3-8(-10) players

=================
Timing
=================

It takes around 3 hours to learn (teach) the rules, at least an hour for the setup (much longer if you haven't yet optimized your storage solution).

Presuming this is done before playing, it takes 6 hours to play by default, eight for "the long war", plus one hour per person above four, plus around another couple of hours if you use the promissory notes from the expansion, for a total of 14 hours if you have all the rules and 8 experienced players.

It needs a total play area around 3m x 2m, plus extra satellite areas for pieces.

=================
For the Newbies
=================

Rules and FAQ are available from:
http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/edge_minisite_sec.asp?eidm=21&esem=4

Walkthru for a simple 3-player game:
http://www.preeminent.org/steve/games/ti3/ti3demo/

Advice about who should and should not play this game...:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=dFex4FGzKjA#t=868s

Video tutorial online:
http://bookshelfgames.com/permalink/ep014.html

Full 3-hour tutorial made by ME :)
http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLbyS7S9QGqlKtpUQ4PfmAGE7eJ5UiwQV4

This game can get a little bitchy. Since it is a long game usually we invoke certain "nice" rules.
http://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/69752/cern-house-rules

And in the case that the specific incentives to playing nice are required we turn to:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/filepage/69899/variant-honour-amongst-thieves

Reasons to do that include this nice summary from Dice Tower:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dFex4FGzKjA&feature=youtu.be&t=14m13s

We use multi-galaxy setups:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/filepage/69916/wormholes-and-3-galaxy-variant-maps

=======================
For other owners:
=======================

Nice board-surround available from:

http://www.boardgamegeek.com/filepage/27117

Better tech tree from:
http://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/69058

Recommend printing page two of:
http://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/21615/
onto the back, with the leader/domain counter info.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
:) Nice components

:) Some interesting mechanics: activating space tiles, colonizing planets, voting system, primary and secondary actions on action cards, ...

:soblue: Despite some cool mechanics, the game horribly fails by the introduction of random overpowered action cards which rain down on players from all sides and which fully randomize a game which holds the false promise of being a tactical/strategic game.

:soblue: The game outstays its welcome: it's way too long for a game with such high randomness/luck factor and downtime is massive. When a big battle occurs two players will be rolling dice for over 5 minutes.

:soblue: The game is filled with small cards and tiny text. The complete lack of iconography makes it impossible to keep track of your opponents abilities and technologies

:soblue: the end game and victory conditions are mostly random too, I guess that suits a casino-style game?

Twilight Imperium is one of the worst game experiences I have had in my gaming carreer. It is an overly long and complex, chaotic and random luck-based game desguised as a tactical strategy game and so one of the biggest hoaxes in the boardgame universe. I never want to play it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Truly epic. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Moderately complex rules would be fine, but the game then the game goes on to add, tweak, modify and just downright break that core set of rules with all the races, diplomacy and other elements in the game.

Fun to play if you can find others who love extreme, sometimes overbearing, levels of complexity and have a couple days to kill with extreme prejudice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
One of those games I was really excited about on paper but that never seemed to deliver the gaming experience I was hoping.  

I only played the 3rd Edition base set, but the game seemed to have a lot of problems (namely with the Imperial card and the "I go first, so I'll win in X turns" problem), which I think was addressed in a later expansion.  Perhaps it's a much better game now.

Either way, if you've got a group that likes really deep games, space empires, and doesn't mind learning a relatively complex set of rules, I'd imagine you'd really enjoy this one.  Wonderful components and look.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is great! a little over the top componets wise, but great!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A long game with many moving parts, though it is not as complex as an uninitiated onlooker might assume. 

I like the idea of having a different set of objectives each game, but the objectives in the one game I played all seemed too similar to one another. They either involved destroying certain types of units, controlling a certain number or type of planets, or winning battles. A fourth edition might streamline this system by removing the randomized objectives and establishing permanent objectives that are slightly more generalized.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I don't think this game is as monstrous as everyone else says... but it's definitely a big game. The basic rules are very simple and easy to learn, and while there's a fair amount of exceptions based on the ships, that's not too bad. It would have been nice to get a ship reference card with the original box.

Lots of stuff to do and think about, and lots of negotiation. The expansion forces more warfare, which is always a good thing.

I think the base set is fine -- I had fun with that and didn't think it was too constrained, but the expansion does make it feel a little more wide open. The game will take longer, though, so be careful. I feel like the game moves very smoothly, but if people get locked up in thought, then it will drag.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A grand strategy, 4x type game - it's not really to my taste - for someone who likes 4x and very strategic games, this would be a 7-9 rating at least.
It takes a very long time to play! So if you are going to, might be a good idea to set aside an afternoon for it!

I give it a 9 because the game can be won while effectively playing in a bubble with no or little player interaction which in my opinion removes the best part of the game. There should be some civ building victory points, but not so many that you can ignore everything else happening at the table.

RATING: 10
29-05-2014. Rating after about 6 games of TI:3, using various modules from the expansions.

Great, great, space 4X game. Yes, you conquer, explore, exploit and exterminate. The game is LONG, easily goes up to 8 hours + with 6 players. I've been in some 12 hour games. The 12 hours are no problem for me as the game is so complex and you're able to do so much different stuff that it remains challenging and interesting till the end.

After another play I've come to the conclusion that if this game wasn't so long it would hit the table more. It's perfect, except for the time it takes to play. Only thing keeping it from being a 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Very ambitious. A bit overwhelming, and probably not appropriate for newbies.  Game rules are thorough, but their structuring is quirky.  Need some clarification as to acquisition of VP's, overview of turn mechanic, function of PDS systems, limitations and requirements of activating systems, and use of control markers, etc. (most of these are implied and clear enough to veterans; to us, these points were somewhat elusive).  For such an epic game, however, these are minor gripes.  TONS of bits, quailty board tiles, and a quality production overall.  Plastic bits are a bit ornery coming out of the sprues (which were warped), and the "storage tray" is laughable.  Otherwise a very good job (and excellent artwork) top to bottom.  One major gripe (and hardly a unique one with FFG) is that of the inner box--for such a tremendously unabashed box size, with soooooo many pieces, sheesh...where am I to put them all?  The box is actually too big for the game when punched, either due to planned expansions or cost cutting on production (it's cheaper to ship a game unpunched, no doubt).  Kinda reminds me of Dark Tower--once you remove the cardboard that stabilizes the pieces for shipping, and take the pieces off their sprues, I guess you're expected to either dump all 12,0000 bits into the box and spend time sorting it out before every game, or to go out and spend *more* money on some type of storage solution.  That's a bit unforgiveable at this somewhat questionable price range.  This thing doesn't even fit in a suitcase for Pete's sake!!  And the cards--of which there are many--there's not way you can just toss them in the poor excuse for a card holder and assume they'll stay there.  Plan on spending some dough on addressing these issues *after* buying the game.  For all our fits and starts, though, I think with some rules fine-tuning and experience, it will grow to be one of my favorites.  Criticism based upon "it takes too many people" or "it's too long" are baseless with me--you don't go to a movie house if you don't like to sit in the dark.  Don't play galactic conquest games if you only have enough players for chess, enough  time for Uno, and only enough ambition for checkers.  Or buy a PC and play a sim.  If you want something watered down and short--this ain't it and is not trying to be.  I also was confused by knocks because luck may effect whether or not you get "cool" planets near your home system at the beginning of the game and that it could have a bearing on your game expereicce.  These aspects do not overhwelm or destroy the game AT ALL.  Well...yah.  You might get a junk hand dealt to you (just figurativley speaking, I don't mean in the gameplay itself).  That's how it works--but great care was taken to inject balance and options into the game.  You can think you're three moves from losing and end up winning in 2.  Or vice versa.  The phrase "Play it as it lies" comes to mind--and you don't win this game based upon the cool planets near your system (though for some strategies, that could help).  All in all, balanced, colorful, efficient, engrossing, involving, detailed and articulated.  Quite an adept and polished achievement, and one of the best games I've played--could have been a 10 if not for the storage compartment issue.  (There must be expansions coming becuase I think think that there is a TON of air inside the box when it's all packed in well).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I can't help but feel that this game is somewhat clumsy. For one thing, too many of its mechanisms are augmented/eliminated/added by the cards that spill out of every orifice of TI3. Action cards, tech cards, race-specific cards, political cards, and all of them entirely text-based! This game becomes an exercise in double-checking, which just drags the experience to a halt at times.

Despite that, this game can be loads of fun. Its epic scale coupled with a great theme and largely solid mechanisms make for an engaging (if LOOONNNNG) game. I especially enjoy the political maneuvering encouraged by almost every aspect of the game. The constant threatening and pleading really cement players in the experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3

That has made it less than enjoyable for me and wishing it was just a little simplier.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Seems to have slim and balanced rules, with huge gaming potential. Research, warfare, colonization, politics and all in one game - not the least an epic space atmosphere.

Very close to a 9, for me, even though I find that I don't _always_ want to play (mainly due to time restrictions). There are so many ways to win, so much to do, and politicking seems more or less like a necessity (which is a good thing, love making deals and fighting propaganda wars). There's a lot of downtime with 6+ players if you don't plan ahead, so please do that and you'll shrink playing time from at least 12 hrs (with the expansion) to perhaps 10 or so.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have played TI3 many times since it came out. I believe that this [i]can[/i] be a pretty solid game, if you use some variants. I have been using the Age Of Empires variant, along with the ISC being only 1 VP. Those are the only variants I use, and neither of them really change the way the game works, just the way the planning and strategy is used. Being able to see all the goals, and activley pursue them, is what makes the Age Of Empires such a good addition to the gameplay. The Command Counters are a good aspect, limiting what your able to do, and having to make some long term plans.  All actions are neatly tied into the planet that was activated with the Command Counter, so there is no confusing what everybody else is doing, and where. Simple Combat, powerful Action cards, Political cards that get voted on, and different abilites each round via the Strategy cards, all making this an interesting experience that will be different each time.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Great game and very epic with lots of drama and politics.  The different alien races are great as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
The best Amerithrashy conquest game I have played. Best with 4,6 or 8 players. It's a long game but that's how it should be. This game has everything; exploration, conquest, epic combat, technology, politics, trade, forming alliances, backstabbing, hidden objectives, different races that play vastly different. 
Stop comparing Eclipse to TI3. Totally different experiences. This is a game that tells a story and that you talk about what happened in the game days after you played it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
SHORT SUMMARY: A regular group has been coming to my house to play games. Every single time TI3 has been the requested game for the main event. This game has its flaws (lots of them), but its fun to play and so far ahead of the competition in its category that no other game is considered. Thats less a comment on TI3's particular traits, and more a comment on the general quality of boardgames of this type. We just don't really have a viable alternative.

I haven't made my mind up on this game yet. On one hand I always want to play it (hence the 9 rating), but thats because its my newest and shiniest game. On the other hand, I have some doubts about the game. If these doubts become substantiated the score is going to plummet like my War of the Ring rating. I won't go into my doubts here until I've played more games, but anyone who has played Rommel in the Desert must be able to make comparisons with this game about movement rules.

After a few more plays this game actually flows a lot better than I thought it would, and the main game scales really well from 4 upwards. Not sure about with just 3 yet. Still waiting for someone to distill it all down to 2 hours.

I played one 6-player game and didn't have much fun as the L1Z1K. Then I played a 4-player game as the Yssaril Tribes the week after and had a blast. I don't know if it was because of the group, because I was having more fun roleplaying the Yssaril or what.
What I do know is that Twilight Imperium is a collection of pretty crap mechanics that don't add up to much, but that the interplay between the players at the table creates the fun. I think it all comes down to the players as to whether the fun of that interplay outweighs the bad aspects of the game, which are primarily its mediocre mechanics, its lack of any real weighty strategic or tactical content, over long playing time, and general fiddlyness of rules and playing pieces (clearing up after 6 players by yourself can take a LONG time).
I've just picked up the expansion and I'm actually getting emails from my gaming group saying how excited they are to be playing a game of TI3 with all the extra stuff. I've never seen that reaction before. My group at least is getting a lot of fun out of this game.
If you're considering getting this game though, be honest with yourself about whether you will actually be able to regularly get the players together to play it. If not, stick to something that requires less players.

You absolutely must play this game using Age of Empires. Without it the game totally drags.

Think I'm getting my science fiction fix playing Battlestar Galactica now though. Its got the epic space feel and wonderful theme of TI3, but is so much more fun to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

My girl surprised me with this Christmas morning.  I read through the rules a couple of times in anticipation of our first play (which was amazing), and now I can't wait to play it again!

RATING: 6
[i]Twilight Imperium[/i] has everything that you ever dreamed in an epic space empire building game: Tech tree, different races, development, exploration, expansion, production, trading, secret and public objectives, warfare, diplomacy, politics... There are also tons of plastic miniatures, cards, reference sheets, counters and dice rolls, and a huge modular board made of big hexagons. Nevertheless, even when it has it all to be the greatest space gaming experience, it loses in the cost-benefit ratio, cause it takes so long to play that the game can become weary after a while. Even beauty itself can tire people out. Still it worths the effort to pull this monster out from time to time.

RATING: 9

Unfortunately it can be difficult to find 3 - 6 players who can set aside an entire evening (6 hours ish) to setup and play. There is a direct conflict between players and backstabbing is common.  This can be wonderful with a great group of players, or challenging with people who take things personal.

The rules are exteremely complex and deep.  New players are at an extreme disadvantage, but an experienced group will have a smooth play and a fantastic story to tell at the end.

RATING: 3
We started this game at 4:30, setup and learning took us close to an hour, and then we needed to start packing up just after 9:30; so, all told, we played for about 4 hours and were about 2/3rds of the way to being finished. We'd have needed at least another two hours, probably more. As the game progresses you get more and more ships and more and more resources so you have more and more options and more and more little things to take care of. We were also finally starting to get into conflicts - I was the only one who hadn't. I almost regret choosing the Diplomacy card to avoid starting a conflict - that at least might have been interesting - but, at that point, fighting wasn't going to earn any victory points, it was only going to lose them. Anyway, now that the fighting had started, the turns were going to take even longer as the bigger and bigger fleets rolled into one another and the amount of dice required to resolve combat grew in direct proportion. Which would be fine, if combat had any effect on the score, or helped in anyway to bring the game closer to its conclusion. As it was, fighting was just a dice-rolling interlude, with little meaning to anyone outside the combatants. I admit there was some meaning for other players, but by that point I didn't really care. I just wanted it to be over. I'd sat in a corner for 4 hours, building a fleet of pretty toys, barely doing anything, and, incredulously, and this is the worst part, I was one of the leaders in scoring! Bleh. I could have pushed my fleet out into a scrap, to finally make the game more interesting, and I was about to do that on the next turn, but the scoring system of the game provided no incentive to do so; in fact, just the opposite, as I mentioned earlier. Essentially, I had to get to the point where I just didn't care about the game anymore to finally start doing something active and let winning be damned. That's not good. It would be better if the game's scoring system drove me to act, rather than my acting because the scoring system drove me to sleep....

RATING: 6
Finally had the opportunity to play this epic game. One of the few "epic" games I had yet to try. Perhaps it is because I've played the likes of Dune, Rex, Adv Civ, and other long games, that while I enjoyed myself, the game itself did not strike me as being "amazing." There are lots of layers and lots of levers, but ultimately is was plastic dudes on a map, fighting for VPs. Certainly, there is a lot of replayability with even just the base game. Add in the expansions and a group could explore options for years without ever playing the same game twice. Perhaps after a decade, a newer, somewhat streamlined version with all the same options to vary the play experience is due. I feel like something like Blood Rage provides much of the same experience with lots of variety, in a much shorter time frame.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I have mounted the beast! I wasn't sure when I got into gaming if I ever wanted to learn TI3, but BSG and Eclipse both got me interested in space/sci-fi (when I've always preferred fantasy), and it was then preserving myself, and making sure every condition was right when I'd lose my TI virginity (a.k.a. not at a con against 7 other experienced players with every single optional rule).

It's long, but it doesn't feel like it since you're constantly plotting and thinking about out-of-turn secondary abilities. And the game length is justified with the diplomacy, trade and political elements, making it a much richer experience than your regular build-'em-up-and-slam-into-opponent.

Rules overhead was surprisingly low too, with complexity coming from card interactions. Worth a try just to pay homage to all the influences this game took in and spawned. And it's not just the usual suspects. This is the original hybrid; always surprising for the uninitiated to discover that the modern grandaddy of Ameritrash is half-Euro. An engine of Puerto Rico + Axis & Allies, decked out in tons of trimmings.

[b]Puerto Rico[/b] - Freely acknowledged by the designer. Puerto Rico's leeching system is overlaid cleverly onto the action system, with the timing of when you use the Strategic Action being crucial, as you can use Tactical Actions and Action Cards to put off using the Strategic Action if need be (e.g. Tech-ing late if possible). Leeching also isn't free, with the need to prepare Strategy Allocation counters beforehand. The Strategy Cards are also authored very thoughtfully.

[b]Runewars[/b] - Exact same system in moving units around and activating them, though the way of visualizing the retreat in TI3 is pretty cute. Similar map setup rules (also the Distant Suns variant), plus Secret Objective. Pacing in getting VPs is also very similar.

[b]StarCraft[/b] - Planets provide either resource or influence, and you exhaust them to use. Build space dock/factory, then build units.

[b]Axis & Allies[/b] - Exact 1:1 correspondence of units between A&A and TI3 (with only Bombers and Artillery that are missing), making it easier to get into the language. Also, I've been looking for a good, more involved island-hopping game than A&A for a long time, and didn't realize I should be looking in [i]space[/i].

[b]Eclipse[/b] - Trade Contracts are similar to Diplomatic Relations, though of course they're more involved in the granddaddy. Didn't make too good use of TCs and think much of them my first game though; seems a lot more free-form, which I don't like as much. I'm not one for bribes and promises in games. Too many people seem to hold "You promised me 5 turns ago!!!" in as high rigidity as "We need to draw our cards in turn order!!!" and "He's defending, he HAS to roll it; you shouldn't roll for him!!!"

[b]Cosmic Encounter[/b] - So many races and thick card decks!

A more unique element is the voting on codes of laws that change the rules, and other game effects from Political Cards via 'Yea' or 'Nay' on the combined influence (delegates) of your planets.

VPs are earned only at the end of each round, and you can usually only claim 1 objective regardless of how many you achieved, unless you took Imperial II. Or you could play with Bureacracy, which has a more deliberate, keep-your-options-open feel. This is how it should be, clawing your way to 10 VPs, with your options steadily narrowing as low-hanging fruit are cleaned out early (but you steadily grow power), and being really behind if you miss out on a VP. Not like all those Euro games that give you VPs for scratching your ass, with final scores in the 200s. Big on timing if you use Imperial II, getting 1 VP every turn and not falling off the pace, then sprinting to the finish like every marathon you've seen on TV. You'd better have enough juice to reach the finish line because if you don't, you're inviting a 4-front (maybe more) war against yourself.

The forerunner of having a variable number of actions per round is also here. You have to optimize command tokens each round between 3 pools: Command Pool (to make Tactical Actions), Strategy Allocation (to leech off Strategy Cards, and trigger some other tertiary abilities on cards/races) and Fleet Supply (to support more ships on each system). Tough decisions here, based on what you think is going to happen next round with both Strategic and Tactical Actions. And getting only 2 Command tokens each round also means you will be vulnerable after a major offensive push. 

Public objectives help with reducing turtling, incentivizing conflicts in the center, and also uprooting everything in 1 system to get involved in battles, especially after you've already exhausted the corresponding planets (which you can't hoard the resources from). Play boldly, since nothing's irreplaceable except losing your home system.

No game plays the same way. Many games make this boast, but not like this one, where the map is set up differently, there are so many races, the action card and political card decks are thick, the objectives are different, the tech tree lets you adapt, and there are multiple rich avenues of interaction and conflict (attack/diplomacy, trade, political, strategy card drafting/leeching). You rarely need an excuse to push ships around and engage in giant space battles and land their payload for planetary invasions, but the politics, trade, public objectives etc spin out a unique, epic story with every play.

(This rating and comment is based on the system as a whole, assuming the right expansion modules are salted to taste.)

4+5

[color=gray][b]Favorite 5-player Long - Runner-up[/b][/color]

RATING: 5
I want to love this game, believe me. I appreciate it for what it is - an epic, sprawling, experience. I just wish it was a better _game_. The victory conditions are too coarse and don't reward fighting enough (even with expansion), the flow of play could be more streamlined, the political stuff does nothing, and the action cards are either horrible or gamebreakers. If I want to play a long game, I don't want THIS much randomness. It has yet to feel like someone has won for a good reason, and I've played it enough times to be sure about that. I even started thinking about my own revision for the game.

RATING: 1.4
Played TI3-basic once...won't do it again, the base game "Imperial" strategy card is just plain stupid.  I only desire to play TI3 as TI3-SE with the Shattered Empire expansion, that's just the way I like it.  If I had purchased and played the TI3 base game with no expansions, and no "Imperial II" strategy card (#8), and was forced to play only with the original "Imperial" SC#8 card, I would have thrown this game away in disgust.  Also, without the "AoE" option, or if I had been introduced to this game with the ridiculously random and dumb base rules map creation (instead of balanced pre-set maps), or had played the "Distant Suns" option, I would categorically declare this to be one of the worst games ever invented.

What makes this a truly fantastic game are the optional rules, along with the introduction of a strategy based #8 card, "Imperial II," in the expansions.  Some people play this game as a children's "fairy treasure hunt" - others, like me, play this as an actual strategy game.

RATING: 8
A wonderful SciFi game at first glance with some serious rule flaws. Luckily, some easy modifications fix it: Just drop the Imperium Card from the game and don't allow stacking counters for the overpowered fighters.

It still takes a bit too long for playing in an evening, even if you make the map a bit smaller than recommended. And some of the game components like the political phase are a bit superfluous. 

But the game is so strong on theme, tactics and intrigue that I like it a lot despite its flaws. It's a Master of Orion as a boardgame, and that's a compliment.

RATING: 8

RATING: 7.5
Oh Twilight Imperium, how I want to rate you a 10... Twilight Imperium is everything you could ever want in a 4X space board game and more. It has everything from resource management to politics and fleet logistics to a robust tech tree. Everything about the game seems like a smooth transition from a PC game to a board game. That being said... A game with this kind of depth is a real time investment. Every time we want to play a 5+ player game we have to plan a day out, while that's not a bad thing, it's also not a good thing and makes playing the game that much harder. Game play is a solid 10/10, but the time it takes to play this game knocks it down quite a few pegs.

RATING: 6
I liked this game, the theme is great, who couldn't love space plus epic battles with fleets zooming around and taking planets. The downsides however are firstly that it's a hugely long game...too long really...our game took 7 hours. This wouldn't be too bad if you felt you were making significant progress, but often a couple of sides would battle back and forth continuously over a single hex with very little outcome. There just aren't enough ways to earn VP's easily, and the Imperial Card becomes a 'must take'. If only all my battling had seen more in the way of VP's (I was trying to take a planet for my secret objective), I might have felt the time was worth it.

If a version was brought out that was quicker with more VP access, I'd be loving it...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[2012-09-23]
A Starcraft és az Eclipse után túl magas lécet kellett volna a Twilight Imperiumnak megugrania és nem sikerült neki, de sajnos még csak rezegtetnie a lécet sem, pedig a fent említett két játéknak is vannak hibái. A Twilight Imperium szabályismertetése, ha nem is strarcrafti hosszúságú, azért a sok apróság miatt majdnem olyan szintű és minimum 1 órás. A játékot véletlenszerűen húzott űrlapok lerakásával kezdjük, sajnos itt rendesen beszól a szerencse. Nagyon sok múlhat kedvező kártyák (termelő, befolyást adó bolygókkal ellátott) húzásán, mert nyilván azt a kezdő bolygója mellé fogja tenni a játékos, persze lehet a másik mellé is berakni gyengébb lapokat, de ezzel magunk számára is megengedjük ezt a lehetőséget az ellenfeleinknek. A játék parancsjelzőkkel zajlik. 8 stratégia akció közül kettőt választunk négy játékos esetén a Puerto Ricóban megismertek szerint, ezek számozottak, amik meg is határozzák a sorrendünket a játékban. Mindegyiküknek van egy elsődleges és egy másodlagos, gyengébb akciójuk, ez utóbbiakat mindenki parancsjelző befizetésével végrehajthatja. A játékban nincs kereskedés és érdekes módon az űrcsaták sem hoznak győzelmi pontot. Viszont ezen stratégia akciók egyike 2 pontot ad. 10 pont elérése a cél, amit még körönként feljövő 1 pontot érő tulajdonképpen egyszerű célok teljesítésével lehet elérni. Ezen felül mindenki egy titkos célt húz, ami 2 pontot ad, ami nem tűnik nagy szerencsefaktornak, de azért mindenképp jelentős, mert nagyon fej-fej mellett haladunk a pontszerzésben. Így kicsit olyan céltalannak tűnik a játék. A stratégiai akciók is egyértelműen sorrendbe állíthatók jóságuk szerint. Az egységek számának szabályozása és a csaták szerintem jól megoldottak. Nem könnyű, de sajnos ki lehet esni a játékból, ez nem túl jó pont. Nem rossz játék a TI, de számomra kevés jó ötletet tartalmaz a fent említett két játékhoz képest és a sok holtidő és hosszú játékidő szerintem nem igazán éri meg. 4 óra alatt sem sikerült végigjátszanunk az első játékunkat és még 1 óra tuti benne volt. Szóval nem tudom mikor ülnék le hozzá megint, de előbb játszanék a két fent megnevezettel, mint a TI-vel.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Best Game I Don't Already Own Award[/b]

WHOA! Only played this with expansions, and I was really impressed. I see loads of potential here.

Rules are pretty simple but theres lots of FUN complexity with the upgrades, cards, and LOADS of factions to play. I can tell there's a lot of replayability in this box IF you have a great group for it.

I was advised that it's pretty difficult to come back from a point deficit in this game, and that's a possible weakness, but good play seems to be able to secure you a point more often than not, and it also seems possible to go on a sprint with a big move and still win, as long as you don't consistently neglect your scoring.

And in general, the difficulty in coming back seems to be necesarry to create the desperate scramble for the victory points -- the visible missions really force things to happen, which is GREAT, because otherwise this would be a much more standstill game.

[b]VS RuneWars[/b]: I dunno, I suspect I'll like this more ultimately and that's mostly due to all of the crazy factions. But RuneWars has so much cool stuff that I think the two games happily coexist side by side despite scratching a similar itch.

[b]VS Eclipse:[/b] I think these are actually more different than I'd heard before playing TI3 -- sure there's plastic ships and loads of hexes, but the main takeaways in Eclipse are exploration and customizing your ship. Customizing your ship especially is a lot of fun and Eclipse's claim to glory.

But this games flavor suits my personal tastes much more, with its WILD personality and bursting flavor -- Eclipse is pretty solid, but feels like a void empty shell next to this.

[b]VS Starcraft: The Board Game[/b]: Starcraft feels like a smaller scale skirmish, but it's really solid for me. TI3 I suspect will do the "epic large player count" thing better I think I'll like Starcraft more for a 2-4 player skirmish. I don't know, haven't tried epic 6 player Starcraft but I think with a big epic long game like that you'd want more going on -- Starcraft has better combat with less generic units and more exciting tactical manuevers, but TI3 feels better built to handle an epic scale game with its extra elements of negotiation, politics, trade, etc.

[b]VS Cosmic Encounter[/b]: Here's this games real competition for me, and where it probably flat out loses -- I was surprised by this (that I would wind up comparing the two as similar), but I think Cosmic Encounter successfully distills all of the high points I like about this game and crams it into a much more playable game. Yeah you lose the epic build ups, but you get everything else delivered to you so fast. A game of Cosmic Encounter is like an "extract-of-TI3" being automatically pumped through your veins on demand. 

So in a sense, playing TI3 was AWESOME (one play gets it into my top 10) -- but on the other hand, it also made me appreciate Cosmic Encounter, already my most legendary game, even more.

[b]Bottom Line:[/b] Not good, but GREAT strategy game that's dripping with asymmetry and player interaction, so I naturally and automatically love it.

(5 Design + 3 Enjoyment)

Max rating potential: 10. Need to play more.

RATING: 4
I have a hard time rating this as a stand alone piece as the game is so vastly improved by the usual Fantasy Flight Expansion fix.  I'd be hard pressed to play this without Shattered Empires.  The improvements in the expansion specifically address the well sited flaws in the base game.  

The concepts are great and this really should have worked out of the box (Especially as they had two other tries to get it right), but it just has too many flaws to justify playing this on its own.  

TI3 is a fantastic work in progress. On it's own tt really should get a 4, but what works in the new version is so great that I'm hard pressed to say I don't like it.  See TI3.5 for the playable version.  (Which while even playable has some problems).

RATING: 8
This game is rated really high for me for several reasons.  I like war games.  I like strategy games. I like sci-fi.  I like pvp.  I like land grab and area control. I like quests.  I love the political aspect of this game. I love epically long games with millions of little pieces and cards. I love Euro-games that are all about victory points.  And TI is a points game disguised in a really cool sci-fi war game theme.

What's not to like? For me, this game has it all. A little on the longer side, but if you get some experienced gamers together, you can play it in a decent amount of time.

RATING: 7
Like others, I strongly recommend the Shattered Empire expansion. Even with that, I think it needs some tweaks to the Strategy Cards and a few other rules. (Fortunately, this is easy to do, and the game design even seems to invite it.) With that, I'd raise it to a 9. Downsides: it takes a while to explain the rules, and it takes a long time to setup and play. Once you know the rules, though, the game is simple. It takes the Axis & Allies combat model, research and movement; adds in the Puerto Rico role cards; and the board layout of Settlers of Catan.

Recommendations: don't use the Tech cards, but instead have a check sheet that you can also use to track the Unit capabilities. Also, provide a list of the Strategy Card abilities so everyone can read them where they sit. And have beads to put on exhausted planets instead of flipping them over.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Epic.  Magnificent.  Far far *far* too long.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Anyone who knows my taste in games knows that I avoid long games. I don't want to be stuck for several hours playing a game I may not enjoy and will likely never play again when I could be playing several games I know I enjoy. There are exceptions, but a game longer than two hours needs to be well loved for me to even try it. I knew that Twilight Imperium took a lot longer than two hours. I didn't know whether I'd enjoy it. 

I loved it. Almost immediately I saw how it integrated so much of what I like. It's asymmetric, intuitive, interactive, open, dynamic, replayable, and yes, long, but oh so worth it. There's none of what I don't like in Fantasy Flight's games, where too often game design pales in comparison to production, complexity masks otherwise simple decisions, and stories are told rather than created. In Twilight Imperium, [i]everything[/i] works.

The length is part of what makes it so great. Because no one wants to get into a conflict too early, seemingly small things like establishing a colony here and building a ship dock there can be perfectly defensible on the surface, but everyone can see the meaning behind the manoeuvring. There are moments where you know that your neighbour is pushing you, but you aren't sure if meeting him with force is worth it because you know it will change the game. At the same time, you worry about the consequences of inaction. Everyone has their hand on a grenade, waiting for the right moment, and then someone goes a bit too far and it's total war. Once the first pin is pulled, the game explodes. And amid all of this, you have to position yourself to win, which is not, after all, about imperium so much as gamesmanship.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The one time I played this game took 9 torturous hours. No thanks, I'd rather play 4 fun games in that time period without getting a splitting headache from boredom.

RATING: 7.5

Exacerbating this is that combat is so dicey - I was brought up on A&A, where, due to larger numbers of units, combat can be predicted with some accuracy.  Do I recommend it?  Well, that depends who's asking.  If you're a wargamer, then no.  If you're a light gamer who thinks the bits look cool, then sure, but be sure and read the rules carefully.  And prepare for a long game.  If you're a general gamer (playing some Euros, some wargames, etc.) who wants an epic space game, then you're in luck.

RATING: N/A
Englisch
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Twilight Imperium has just about everything I want in a game. Sure, the beginning round or so is predictable expansion (which you can simulate if it really bugs you), but after that the game opens up and becomes a tangled mass of decisions and possibilities. The randomness of combat dice rolls and cards drawn is balanced by the euro-esque strategies of role selection, efficient action management and long term technology and goal planning, with those goals being impacted by your opponents' actions. The level of player interaction is so far beyong simple invasions and combat rolls. The expansion adds heaps of new options that you can insert in to play or leave out as easily as Firefox plugins. Twilight Imperium is an experience, but unlike a lot of 'experience games' there are genuine layers and layers of actual game at its core. Instantly one of my favorites.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Right off the bat I will state that I have never played this game without the "Shattered Empires" expansion.  And yet, whether it is fair or not, I will rate the base game according to the differences that were described to me by people who were familiar with both the original and the expansion, but I will reserve most of my comments for the "Twilight Imperium 3rd Edition - Shattered Empires" entry.  As great as this game is, it sounds to me like there were some serious flaws with it that were corrected by the expansion, making the expansion pretty much a necessity.  With "Shattered Empires", I rate this game a 9/10.  Game design: 4/5  Personal enjoyment: 4/5  Total: 8/10
