RATING: 3
An interesting game, fun at first. But in the end fundamentally flawed. The last time I played, the game ended in as an hung game over a rules dispute. (it had stopped being fun a couple hours before that anyways).

The secret strategy cards are all too hard, and totally unbalanced (for instance, getting 6 GFs on mecatol rex is vastly easier than getting 4 dreadnaughts there). Even if you think that beating down on players who were lucky enough to draw a good race is a "balancing mechanism" (which it isn't), there's no way to do that when you don't know what someone's secret objective is.

I won't be wasting any more time playing this.

RATING: 9
Have played it only once (so far) and won as the Mentak Coalition. Tied on 9 points when the game ended on the 8th turn with Imperium Rex, but won the tie-break by having fulfilled more objectives.

Absolutely superb game, it has combat, politics, diplomacy, a tech tree, action cards, resource management, different unit types, alliances, trade and with a variable board and variable victory point conditions, longevity as well. The game I played did take 8 hours, so for those who do not like this then it will be a problem. We arranged a Sunday afternoon expecting this so it wasn't an issue.

Edit: Played a few more times now and still enjoy this immensely.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Many call this a 4X space game, but players do not truly develop their civilizations, rather they simply build armadas. As such, it's really an area control game hidden behind a whole lot of smoke and mirrors; more "Diplomacy in Space" than "Masters of Orion the Board Game". Still, it offers vast degree asymmetrical play and a wealth of optional elements. As much a delightful toybox as it as a game.

RATING: 7
I'm guessing I never play this.  Certainly not until I get a bigger table.

Hey hey, finally played it (3/26/11)!  That's one "Great White Whale" game taken care of.  Lots of fun and, amazingly, a 9 hour game flew by.  (Probably shouldn't take 9 hours, but the 4 hours on the box is absurd.)  Plenty of flaws and I don't think I'd play it a lot more times, but was well worth the play.  Can't get too into the competition as their are some major balance issues, single card issues, the Imperial card issue, etc.  In our game, War Suns were probably too easy to get and dominated the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Superb game that captures the feel of controlling an epic space empire. The only problems I see with the game are the high random factors and extreme length of the game.

If they could have made it more "Euro"-like --streamlining the rules, minimizing randomness, and reducing playing time -- (but NOT a Euro!) it would probably be one of the best games in my eyes.

As it stands, it is still one of the best only because it is unique and captures the feel that I love. Plus it is very modible and expandable and features INSANE replayability, which is essential to me.

The game is a 9.25 with the expansions, but without it is only an 8.75. I just decided to average the ratings for this score.

RATING: 8
Great game but it takes an absolute age to play. It's very well produced - I particularly like the different races available of which there are ten to choose from and they all play quite differently. All the game components are excellent and feature artwork of a very high standard. The problem with this game is finding at least two other players who are willing to give up the best part of a day to play the thing with. It's also quite a brutal game on people who haven't played it before and a lot of explanation has to take place. I also feel in regards to this that because of the sheer volume of rules (over 40 pages in the rulebook) a lot of allowances for inexperience should be made and hopefully there's someone in the group who has a talent for explaining games. It's a very rewarding game after repeated plays however as people become more familiar with the system of play and which tactics to employ (just like any other good game in that regard).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This review is from playing twilight imperium with both shards of the throne and shattered empire expansions.

It is THE EPIC space empire board game. Explore planets, research tech, build a might armada of ships, fight your foes, ally yourself with others, vote for political agendas that can change everything. This game has really really good potential, but without homebrew rules for victory points it is actually quite bad. Victory point rules in basic game is broken (does not work at all), it gets a little better with expansions, but it is still horrible.

With our homebrew variant:
Start with 10 victory cards face up
Seed in more conflict orientated victory cards (less of turtling cards like tech and spend x resources)
After round 3 and onwards game can end. Check at the end of status phase of round 3 if game has ended, one with most VP wins.
Use voice of the council and artifacts that give victory points on planets.
Each player can always claim only one victory card at the end of each status phase (and in addition they can claim secret objective or premiminary objective)

If the victory point rules would have been good this game deserves a 10, but when it requires homebrew rules in order to play I have to reduce the score by 1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

My thoughts on the Initiative/Imperial combo. Personally I think it's kind of clever. Also the person that takes Imperial could end the game before they get their bonus points. So taking Imperial is not a sure-fire victory.

RATING: 7
My interest in this game dates from its sold-out second edition.

We use the following two-player variant:
* remove 10 tiles from the game (4 empty systems, 1 asteroid field and 5 random tiles)
* Use the 2 player galaxy as defined in the TI2 rulebook page 5
* Do not use the "Initiative" Strategy Card, so swap the Speaker token between game rounds, and use only 7 Strategy Cards in total
* Each player selects 2 Strategy Cards, the three remaining ones get Bonus tokens like in the 5-player game
* Use the "Age of Empires" Variant, together with "Imperial II" (this is also called the "Ancient Throne" variant)

RATING: 7
An updated version of TI2. Most of the new mechanics are a welcome change and the lack of bookeeping is a huge plus. The threaded turns make for a much more interactive experience. Rating has dropped a few points due to a number of silly issues that never should have made it past playtesting. The Variant/FAQ probably add a point to the rating, but out of the box, the game has some flaws which will just turn some people off. With a few House Rules, the game can be absolutely fantastic. I think with a bit more playtesting, it could have been a real gem out of the box instead of a 'diamond in the rough'.

RATING: 1.5

RATING: 5
This review is based on one play, it was also a rules learning game for all players but 1.  We started our game at 3pm, I knew it was going to be long, I was hoping we would have begun at noon.  The end result was a stalemate (people gave up) at 4:30 am.  What happened?  I took imperial any chance I got until I was at 8 victory points, everyone then ganged up on me and wiped me out leaving me at 9 victory points.  The next highest person was then also wiped out before he could end the game while the other players sat around at 1-3 victory points.  After that occured the remaining players said screw this and ended the game. I personally felt there needs to be MORE victory points in the game, you wiped out a player should grant an automatic 1 or 2 victory points etc.  Was it a decent game?  Yeah, it was interesting seeing other games mechanics used in a long winded war game.  Did they all work, not really, some of them felt way too fiddly.  There was abit too much micro management for my liking, I spent pretty much most of the game trying to make guys, get carriers to them, then move them to uncolonized planets before I got gangbanged.  For what its worth its just WAY to freaking long, but its long and slow.  Not a whole lot went on the entire game yet it took us a retarded amount of time.  All and all, it seemed like a game where in turtling, picking imperial and having lucky planets around your home to colonize wins you the game.  Very much a game of beat up the leader.

RATING: 6
01/13/07: We played our first complete game with six players from start to finish!! Took us about 9 hours. Lowered the rating from 9 to 8 because of the a) looong playing time, b) the problems that arise from the imperial strategy-card (in this case, if some people (e.g. me) take the card whenever they can and other people passing on it and then ganging up on the people with the most VP...which generally leads to more of a) ) and the general fact that I am not a very aggressive gamer.
08/20/06: My impression after the first play (three players) is *very* good! This game combines elements of american- and euro-style games in a very clever way and the quality of the components is stunning, to say the least. The very clear and well organized rules are also worth mentioning (especially for FFG, since Arkham Horror´s rulebook almost drove me insane - pun intended). The game is quite long, but I guess after two or three plays it will move along quite nicely. I should also mention, that just preparing the first play is very timeconsuming: There are lots of tokens to punch out and bucketloads of plastic-miniatures to cut from the sprues. I guess, that this took me approximately six hours total.The game is very immersive and easy to learn (but not simple) and I am really looking forward to our next play!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have mixed feelings about this game. I'd like to love the game because it's got some really nice elements, but I have a lot of problems with it.

First off, the game is way too long. It usually takes around 6-8 hours to complete a game of TI. This is much longer than any game should be, but if it were just this that was wrong with the game, I would still love it. The main shortcoming of the game is that victory points - the mechanism for winning the game - are almost completely dissociated from what happens on the board, at least in the base game. What I mean by this is that what happens on the board will only slightly influence the victor of a game, and engaging in warfare is the worst possible move you can take, bar-none.

The base game offers no victory points for succeeding at warfare, and gives you a ton of victory points for doing things like building up, turtling and not building an army. What this means is that the game essentially gives you a really intricate battle system that sounds like a lot of fun, gives you a dynamic board which will be the stage for all this battle, and then rewards you for not using any of it and just staying in your little corner of the galaxy for 6-8 hours.

I've heard that the expansion (Shattered Empire) fixes a lot of my problems with the game, but as I don't own it, it's hard for me to say. My advice, then, is that either you buy the base game and the expansion right away, or you steer clear from it altogether. If you're not willing to shell out the money for the expansion, you're just going to be frustrating yourself for the better part of a day.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
TI3 does so many things well.  The action allowance system is well balanced, the tech tree is awesome, and the Puerto-Rico-style role selection is always a crowd pleaser.  I appreciated that victory points didn't always come from combat, and it leads you into different strategies throughout the game.

The one aspect that fell a little flat to me was politics.  I love the idea of negotiating and passing legislation for the galaxy.  But, at least in our game, the legislation was typically pretty underwhelming, so it wasn't really worth taking the politics action.

But other than that, I liked everything about the game.  It's definitely ahead of [thing=72125][/thing] for me, and probably even passes [thing=175155][/thing] to become my favorite space 4X game.  Now, if only it was a little easier to get to the table...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
As a previous player of TI2 (rating = 8), I definitely put this game at a 10.  The game mechanics are smooth and player-interactive.  The components are just awesome!  Each game is so different that the replay value is very high.  The command decision choices are numerous makes the game rich.  Sure, there are a few things to tweak or options to use, but nothing seems broken to me.  This is a regular favorite with our game group (typically six-player games).  The TI3 Shattered Empires expansion makes it better with fixes to a few problems and great enhancements!

RATING: 1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the ultimate game for me. There's an incredible amount of depth, strategy, and options here. Variable player powers, variable phase order, political posturing, and a remarkably rich theme all in one box. The biggest drawback is the playtime, but no other game feels quite as epic as Twilight Imperium.

Unlike many others, I feel that the core game works just fine and actually makes for a shorter game when played by the basic rules, but there is a certain cycle that players follow.

While I still very much enjoy the game, especially the space opera theme, unique races, and the overall concept; I have to admit that the game is showing its age. FFG has shown in more recent releases that it's capable of delivering an epic experience with far more streamlined mechanics. To date, nothing has matched the epic scale of Twilight Imperium, but at this point it may be time for a new edition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Twilight Imperium is a game unlike any other I've experienced in terms of the level of time commitment, choices, aspects, and overall scope, yet winning the game boils down to luck of the draw (in terms of what victory conditions come out via your secret goals and public goals) and a certain amount of kingmaking. Make no mistake, this is a game that makes you invested, primarily due to the amount of time you take getting invested in your ships and the galaxies being developed, but at the end of the day, it asks a lot of you and seems to leave you with a bitter taste in your mouth and a day come and gone.

RATING: 10

My main complaint: the victory points are weak in terms of theme.  I'd prefer it if victory was directly tied to control of Mecatol Rex, or other specific goals that would enable a stronger narrative.  Maybe the Lazax scenarion in the Shards of the Throne expansion would solve that?

Updated to a 10
The "Imperial card" should be recognized for what it is. That is a means to keep the game in balance for the non-agresive races. Agressive races, who merely follow their programmed scheme of building up and attacking without ever "sacrificing" a turn to take up the Imperial card, are bound to fail and shouldn't wonder, when they're losing.

RATING: N/A
Wall of Games Location: A21
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is famous, and for good reason. So big! So much table space needed! Needs so many players to live up to full potential! Such a heavy, huge, expensive box! So complicated to learn/teach! Takes so long to set up/tear down/play! And so, SO FUN.

This is a game that's a pain in the ass to find the time, space, and committed players to make a game of it happen, but is just SO worth it on the rare occasion you can make it happen. Mechanically, the game is just beautiful... there are so many ways to play, your choices flavor play so heavily, the ending typically feels satisfying win or lose, this game is just amazing. I wish to Christ someone would make a digital version so you could online matchmaking, because this game is just so damn fun, but you can own it for years and never get a chance to play it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Really enjoy this game. It's largest problem is the time-frame, it's hard to block the 6+ hours of time that this game needs. Definitely seems to play better with 5+ people (providing they can immerse themselves in this type of game for the requisite time frame).

RATING: 9
A truly epic game, both in theme as in game length. Try to rule the galaxy with a combination of warfare, technology and politics.

In 1 game you'll be fighting wars on a couple of fronts, trying to stay ahead in the technology race, while in another game you may be getting rich on trade and win by not firing a single shot. Amazingly, this game tries out dozens of ideas, and most of them work out great. Truly an accomplished design!

RATING: 10
[b]Possibility Space Landscape (Exploration=Fun)[/b]
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Challenge (Depth) Fun derived from analyzing and predicting the optimal path to take through the possibility space landscape.
:star::star::star::star::star: Variety (Width) Fun derived from trying out a large variety of meaningful paths through the possibility space landscape.
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Atmosphere (Height) Fun derived from the experience or anticipation of encounters along a path through the possibility space landscape.

[b]Gaming Skills Employed[/b]
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Analysis
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Tactics
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Strategy
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Direct Player Manipulation (Diplomacy)
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Indirect Player Manipulation (Bluffing)
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Player Reading/Prediction
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Luck

[b]Misc.[/b]
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Theme Integration
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Rules Complexity
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Bookkeeping
:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Downtime
:star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Scalability

[b]Presentation[/b]
:star::star::star::star::star: Components
:star::star::star::star::star: Artwork
:star::star::star::star::nostar: Rules

[b]Comments[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My new favorite game!!  Trying to conquer the known galaxy (and your friends) through military action, politics, trade and subversion was never so much fun.  A great game for armchair generals, politicians, tradesmen and diplomats.

This game may seem big and daunting at first, but once you begin learning the rules I find that it rolls along pretty well.

I’ve won the last two of the three games that my group has played: once (without firing a shot) as the Xxcha Kingdom and again (with minor military engagement) as the Yssaril Tribes.

I can't wait to try the Shattered Empires expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really like this game. I like that a person can't win without a balanced strategy. The first couple of times, my brother built a huge war machine and conquered planet after planet. He was surprised when he didn't win.

Out of the first three times I played, I won the second and the third, which always makes me like a game more.

Long, complex, involving and [b]totally worth it[/b].

RATING: 9

RATING: 7
This game is one of my favorites. It is a lot of fun, though definitely need a little time and space to play. The base games strategies left me with the rating, if you buy this game you should definitely buy Shattered Glass Expansion, as it greatly improves upon the base game.

Set up time is a real negative in my opinion too, but, not much you can do to change this... there is a lot going on and because of that you need a lot of pieces and a lot of cards.

Solid game, I love playing it, and am glad I bought the expansions!

RATING: 7
Really I can't think of much to say than 'TI GOOD!'.

It's NOT a war game. It's a threat-of-war game with players chasing victory conditions for points. The plastic armies are like the armies of the US and Russia circa 1970s. Large, dangerous, and only for use in proxy-war skirmishes. Full scale war devastates all parties involved.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As an experience, this is a fun game.  Lots of activity, lots of things to do.  Makes for a fun game night.

As a game, this is horrible.  Way too many problems with the rules.  The special powers are terribly unbalanced.  The setup encourages hunkering down and eking out a win rather than going out and seizing it.

The tech tree is both boring and poorly thought out.  The action cards just don't add.  The political cards are a joke.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Wow, this is a beast.  Not suitable for non gamers and people with short attention spans.  Quite free and open, and many different paths to kick some ass.  Fun, but long.  Hopefully, the playing time reduces with more experience.  A flawed game that takes forever.  It has some fantastic ideas buried in the game, but the flaws in the game just make it almost unbearable to spend the time needed to play it.  I think I may have to wait for Twilight Imperium IV.   The lack of playtesting is clearly evident(sigh and double sigh).  It contains all of the elements a game this long should have... it just wasn't hashed out enough.  Shame on  you!

Note:  I really have a disdain for house rules, but the ISC played out of the box is just too much for me to handle.  I don't mind the principle of it, its the fact so many power cards can influence it, and not every person is guaranteed it the same number of times.  It also seems unnecessary.  The game already has a timer with the objective cards!!!!  This is the only game that I refuse to play without some house rule.  Most games I refuse to take seriously unless they contain no house rules.

RATING: 1
An abortion of a game. This thing didn't only turn me off to Twilight Imperium. It made me question my love of all space opera. I was watching Force Awakens, watching Han die, and all I could think was...how did the Imperial Card make it past a single playtest...is that why the Rebels can't ever seem to catch a break? The Empire just keeps getting 2 VPs until the win while everyone else turtles around the board? There are over 500 variant articles on this game! What else does that say other than people are desperate to make this POS playable, and it ain't. Playing this game is like getting intestinal polyps removed without anesthesia. Ugh. Go play Eclipse. Enjoy your lives.

RATING: 4
I was sorely disappointed by TI3.  I expected a fantastic epic game, but found a game that was completely bogged down by a plethora of re-hashed euro mechanics.  I was particularly disappointed by the fact that this is one of those games that allows conflict and fighting, but discourages it significantly by making it too difficult and unrewarding, so people end up sitting around, building up in their own corner of the map, waiting for others to fight.  That kind of wargame is a big pet peeve of mine, so this isn't my cup of tea, although I'd probably be willing to give it a second chance.

Richly thematic and great components. I love the idea but I dread the let down that it can be which makes me very hesitant to suggest it.

RATING: N/A
(1 incomplete play) No rating because it was incomplete. If I were to rate it, it would probably be a 6. My main complaint is that it feels like there's a lot of potential imbalances -- nearby planet quality to start with, and the effects of laws and action cards moving on from that -- which are hard to rectify even diplomatically (and I'm a fan of Diplomacy). This feels problematic in a game of this length; I would be worried about getting screwed in a bad position for 4 hours of fighting from behind; no fun. But I'll sit down again *with players who have read the rules beforehand* with enough time, to try it again, if someone pushes it.

RATING: 7
Holy smokes, what a Behemoth!  My rating is based off of an initial play with 8 players, including the Shatered Nations expansion.

Now, don't get me wrong, I understand that a game of this depth and size can't be digested in a single play through.  The game is megalithic though, and new players should be prepared for a long haul, particularly if there are a lot of participants.

There is light at the end of the tunnel though, and I think I would play TI3 again... with the right crowd.  There is a lot cool material here, and I would like to dig into it more.

One thing I will mention that I have seen in other reviews... the victory points are difficult to come by, and the path to winning is odd.  Your secret objective will get you 20% of the way there or so, but after that you're left to the wim of the cards.  This Machiavelian path to victory does fit the theme though, so perhaps it is part of the overall experience.

Super Meaty, but fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[thing=12493][/thing] is a monster of a game in many ways: it is big (350+ miniatures, 400+ cards), sprawling, long, complex (but not all that much), and it has many, many moving parts.

TI3 shares the role selection mechanic that is used in games like [thing=3076][/thing] and [thing=28143][/thing], in which you choose a role, that will give you a major action and the others can "follow" the same role, but doing some minor action. To follow a role you spend Strategy tokens. There are 8 roles in the game: Initiative, Diplomacy, Politics, Logistics, Trade, Warfare, Technology, Imperial.

Every round, the players will choose a role to do, and the choosing order will go from the player that took Initiative in the last round (and the player can't choose Initiative two times in a row). The players choose a role in clockwise order, beginning with the one that took the Initiative role last round. But after this, the order of play will follow the order of the numbers on the roles. The players can activate the role anytime during his turn, and once he does it, the major action will happen, then every other player will be able to do the minor action of the role by paying one Strategy token (and usually will be necessary to spend resources also) - the Initiative role doesn't have a major action, it allows, however, to the player that selected it to use all the minor roles without spending Strategy tokens (and, of course, the player will be the first to select a role in the next round).

Also, the players will have a number of Command tokens, and they can be used, each at a time, to activate a hex (system) in the board, and is only possible to activate a hex once for round (the Warfare role allows for the possibility to activate the same hex twice). You activate a hex in order, usually, to build units (ships, ground forces, docks, PSDs) or to move units (then you place the Command token in the hex to where the ships will move).

The game revolves around these things: actions of the roles and actions (activations) made by the Command tokens. Basically the roles serve for: Initiative (be the first to act), Diplomacy (stop someone from attacking you), Politics (bring an event for voting, also to gain Action cards), Logistics (to gain tokens, that you can put in the Command, Strategy and/or Fleet Supply), Trade (gain resources, also allows for trade deals to be made, or to break all of them), Warfare (to activate twice the same system), Technology (to discover new technologies), Imperial (score points).

[thing=12493][/thing] is very rich in options, and not a lonesome game, as everyone pays attention to the others, trying to take advantage of the minor action of the roles, struggling to get the timming of actions right (like waiting to activate rolls when you know some other players won't be able to do the minor action), and, of course, because it is a game of conquest, so it is only a matter of time before the battles start to happen, especially for Mecatol (the capital center of the board), since many objectives - both public and hidden - requires the players to take and hold Mecatol.

So it is a game that puts players face to face, brawling for the same spaces, the same actions, building fleets and technologies in order to attack the planets of others. And also of politics, since you can make deals with the other races, vote for events that will benefit some (or harm others). It is, also, a very long game, with many hour of playing time.

I was enjoying it quite a bit, but, after six hours of game, one event came - the Ancient Artifact - that basically DESTROYED the whole game of one player, the one holding Mecatol. He had put a major force there (12 big ships, a dock, ground forces, a PSD), and, since he was winning, almost everyone vote to approve the event - and it was all in the hand of a die roll: 1-5 and everything in Mecatol would be wiped out; 6-10, and everyone would get 2 techs. The roll stop at 1. Now, the game basically ended for the player that was in Mecatol - he just couldn't build again his forces, specially because another players were next to his home planets, preparing for attack.

I usually don't mind be in the receiving end of a bad event - it comes with the territory when playing thematic games. But this happened around the 6th hour of the game. Six hours to be taken down by an event. The event didn't affected me, but I still was taken aback by it. Sure, we did have to approve it, but what chance have the person, alone in Mecatol, ahead in points? Not even the promise to leave, and later truce among them, brought someone to his side, because, you won't need a truce if the player is trounced and he won't need to leave if all his forces there are obliterated.

So, the event soured the whole game somewhat - since a swing of luck this big can happen in what is a strategy-heavy game.

I could play it again, but I won't ask nor miss it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Undeniably awesome, but I drop a point just cause it's got a bit more luck dependency than I wish for when I'm going to commit an entire day to play.  But on the upside, the luck issue resolves my main drawback to Game of Thrones - needing 6 equal players.  TI3's luck factor can let player skills range over a larger spread and still have a good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A glorious space epic!  I love this richly textured, multi-faceted game.  Great bits in the best AT tradition.  Lots of player interaction.  The downside is, of course, ~10 hour play time.  (I know some folks swear it can be played in 3-4, but I can't help but think it would be at the cost of losing a significant amount of the player interaction that makes the game great.  I suspect that with a group that has played together a few times that the time would tighten up to 7-8 hours.)
  
[b]Update:[/b] with a pre-built board, races assigned in advance, [i]Age of Empires[/i], and a couple other tweaks, we got the time down to [-]6.5[/-] 5 hours with 4 players.

RATING: 9
Played six times so far.  All I have to say is "WOW"!!!  TI3 is one great game.  Maybe I only say that because I've won five of six.  One slight problem I see is turtling.  In most games I've won, I've had the smallest number of forces but managed to complete my objectives more quickly then my opponents.  If you're looking for a space based slugfest - look elsewhere, unless you add optional rules. To prevent the turtling issue, we created an optional rule that lets players claim an extra 1 VP per turn for successfully taking over a planet from another player.

Probably the closest to a 10 rated game I've ever played.

Even the two-player variant here on BGG is very fun to play.

RATING: 3.5
Third time's the charm in terms of layering enough Euro-style mechanisms on top of an originally too simplistic, too diplomatic conquest game to make a game that is more interesting, more structured, and less of a diplomatic free-for-all rife with tit-for-that, manipulate the newbie, and kingmaking.

The cost, however, is an absurdly too long and complex game for what it is.  If you're fine with its length and still present diplomatic aspects, then this is an ok game and probably better than Eclipse.  Faint praise, I know...

For me, however, this is an ungainly beast.  I'd rather play Diplomacy for a diplomatic game or my own Throneworld for a pure conquest game.

RATING: 7
A military unit strategy game, it is a superior version of Runewars.  However, this game is intimidatingly long; it can run over 10 hours with a full table.  The game is very satisfying to play and do well, but if a few people decide you have to die there is little you can do to protect yourself.  A lack of bonuses on defense mean that offense is the only option which does limit tactical opportunities.  While certainly a memorable experience, the enjoyment from it will depend heavily upon how well you can play table politics.

RATING: 9.9
This is by far the most epic and well-themed game in my collection. It can be difficult to arrange full sessions of it, but it's worth it every time. Games usually clock in at 6 hours once every player knows what he's doing, but I find myself so invested that it never FEELS like it took six hours. Like Arkham Horror, Cosmic Encounter, and Netrunner (as is probably the case with most Fantasy Flight Games), every single card and character has it's own clever flavor text (and I highly recommend reading the flavor text at the beginning of the rulebook to new players, or having them read it). This would probably be my favorite game if I got to play it more often. Ameritrash at it's very best.   

Shattered Empire is a must! 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Preliminary rating after one play.

I don't mind games with long playing time but there should some excitement be involved with the game. In TI, action is almost non-existent, so we spent the exorbitant playing time (about 8 hours) doing basically nothing except for some building and choosing some cards.

The pieces on the board do not reflect the game situation, in fact, they are quite irrelevant. After six tedious hours, there was the first real attack in our game - did we care at this point? Not really, no.

Even people that like TI admit the game boils down to "turtling" and basically just sitting around. Is this indeed an exciting gaming experience?

TI is supposed to be a civilization game, not a wargame. But most of the things that you do are related to war (space ships, action cards, occupation of territory [= planets], technology advancements etc.). In the end, you never use your military power. So what? What's the point?
 
Game flow is just tedious, after some time, I completely lost interest in following the actions of the other players - it almost never involved me anyway.

As for game mechanics, the trade and political part seems grafted with very little actual relevance to the game.

In the end, this game is a real disappointment. Boredom rules on the board, IMHO the many fine components that come with the game promise more excitement than there actually is.

My rating is a 2, but just because the production value of this game is truly great.

Tudeh
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game has gotten new life with the 'No Sudden Victory' scoring variant. It takes forever, but as an all day gaming extravaganza, it is one of the most fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I owned TI3 and both expansions for a year and half before I found a chance to play it with other people.

I read anything and everything I could about TI3, strategies, and options all across the internet but nothing I read, watched, or listened to mentioned what I experienced after playing it for the first time which happened to be a 6 player game:

Twilight Imperium 3 has the most elegant mechanics in a board game that I have ever experienced. Everything from choosing strategy to tactical movement and combat to political decisions to negotiations and treaties is poetry in motion.

That first game lasted 7 hours with 6 people and I was engaged every minute of it. In fact when it ended I thought about what had happened throughout the game through the next day and wanted to play it again immediately.

You will hear how long TI3 is, how many components come it, how "complicated" it is... I suggest you throw all those opinions out, play it, and judge for yourself.

One game of TI3 is more satisfying than 10 other games played on a game night for me. 

Incredible game. If you're ever in the DC area drop me a line and we can watch the galaxy burn together.

RATING: 4
Maybe I'm giving a low score unjustly due to the high expectations I had to the game from a lot of respected reviewers who claimed that the only issue the game has is it's play time length. It was not so. Time is not an issue for me when the game is exciting. But declaring war and having battles is very bad business, even if you get by chance an objective that requires that of you. My tech was better...just unlucky I guess.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
After 2 games impression:
Veeeeeeeery long (5-10hours + setup) and yet it still seems you barely do anything before the game is over. Getting into attacking position takes too long unless you get lucky action cards or have been able to grow good techs by being left alone. In fact the way to win is to look like a non-threat that your neighbours ignore and grow big before you start doing any VP scoring and drawing attention. A lot of luck involved but this is in fact for the better. Theme and the fact that everyone has to play with unique play styles lift this one up higher.
The biggest downside is that the races are not balanced, everyone can win but some feel far better than others.

To sum it all up: One of the most interesting game experiences I've had, but too many things that outright annoy me and prevent a top rating. If you're not into the theme and/or loooong games don't even try this one, it might make you hate boardgames.
Update: After having played a lot more boardgames I can only reach one verdict... unplayable piece of ****.

RATING: 10
Spectacular game.  Epic to a fault.  Initial impressions make it seem like a wargame when it is really more about wise development.  High replayability, especially for a game of its magnitude.  Amazing blend of theme and mechanics.  This game shamelessly culls ideas from other games, but makes the ideas work together seamlessly.  No part of it seems disjointed, and it comes with tons of variants (as well as tons more in the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/22821/twilight-imperium-3rd-edition-shattered-empire]two[/url] [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgameexpansion/95802/twilight-imperium-third-edition-shards-of-the-throne]expansions[/url]) to customize it to your group's taste.  Absolutely the best space opera game out there.  No other game even comes close.

RATING: 10
An excellent epic game that nicely combines mechanics for warfare, economics and diplomacy. I really like the aim of the game being to score victory points through completion of objectives irrespective of how well you do in any of the above three measurements of power. The strategy cards mechanic is an excellent idea giving players various options and keeping gameplay variable. The game is a long one to play, but with preparation and the right players is a real journey.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Twilight Imperium is a beauty. Great graphic design, colorful and heavy duty hexes to build the gameboard and a truckload of plastic spaceships. It all can sprawl quite a bit during gameplay, but considering the game's scope, that's probably to be expected.

The game itself is an excellent design that provides for important decision making nearly every turn. The large variety of alien races and their asymmetrical racial powers make every game play out differently and the political phases can be a blast, with much bribing and backstabbing. Another nice feature is the truckload of official variants and optional rules included, which can be added or subtracted almost at will without changing the flow of the game. On the downside, the game occasionally will end before there have been any meaningful confrontations between players. (This was addressed, quite successfully, in the Shattered Empires expansion.) Also, combat resolution is a little uninspired, but it gets the job done.

While the game itself is fantastic, it doesn't hit the table nearly as much as I would like. It is simply too hard to experience Twilight Imperium on a regular basis due to its frightfully long playing time. Even with players moving at a brisk pace, it is a five or six hour endeavor, longer with more than four players. A game of Twilight Imperium pretty much excludes anything else when our gaming group gets together. As such, we usually end up playing three or four shorter games instead, which tends to do a better job of keeping everyone interested...Still, it's one of the all-time greats and should be in every gamer's collection.

Update: After almost a decade of newer, leaner games I am having a tough time staying on this band wagon. While I adore the setting and everything it tries to do, it simply no longer holds up. Too much downtime, too many fiddly rules and modifiers...this is a game for someone that only has five games in their collection, as pulling it out once a year makes for seriously tedious gaming. I've also come to realize the time investment to fun ratio is way off. Usually there is only one exciting play per game, which is far too little for a game that takes 6 or 7 hours to play. This one will live on as a fond experience in my earlier days of board gaming, but otherwise I think I am pretty much done with it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Don't mind the total play time required. Love the epic feel of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite strategy games of all time. The mechanics underlying the whole game are deceptively simple and elegant, yet the game itself is epic and grand in scale. RATING: 4
Unless you can play this game in sessions, it simply takes too long and inevitably wears out its welcome. The 4 hours stated on the box are a joke, I've never had a game take less than 8. The most recent game was over 14 (6 players, 3 of them new). In my experience, games generally end because everyone is too exhausted to go on and a winner is declared just to bring an end to it.

Significant house rules are needed to make the game faster. But even then, with both expansions this game has far too many moving parts, which need to be pruned out.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
It's bloated and has a lot of flaws, but it also has a lot of cool stuff.  The ISC as written is dumb, but there are good alternatives after all this time, so no fuss there.  HATE the tech cards...why not a single chart and markers?  Use the (presumably expensive) cards for other mechanisms where they make sense!

At the end of the day, though, this game is just too long for too little payout. The scale is all off, ending up feeling more like warring frog tribes in a small swamp. Where is the vastness of space? Why is combat such a freaking boring luckfest? Why was no effort given to address the "let's you and him fight" problems? Why are the planets so dull? Why was the political aspect toned down from 2nd edition?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
 Only 1 play (with some number of expansions) and I got utterly destroyed (1 victory point).  The game gives you so much to do, however, that earning only one victory point in four hours was extremely fun!  

The political and economic aspects are clever.  And the Puerto Rico-like roles do a good job of both enabling/constraining actions and keeping the game interesting for those that are more removed for the action (free stuff, woo!).

My only concern was that there was relatively little military action (except for one huge showdown) for a game of such length.  On the one hand, this emphasizes that the game is not strictly a war game, with economy and politics being equally important.  But on the other hand, it also seems like it really encourages turtling, which can drag things out.

Anyway, after one play, I am enthusiastically looking forward to another game, for opportunities to try out new races and new strategies.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
+ expansion:

Shattered Empire 
Shards of the Throne

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Disappointing.  I had been looking forward to this game, hoping for a clean version that was fun, and basically MOO in space.  

What I got was a LONG, drawn out affair that dragged on.  I have no problem with long games, I enjoy Empires in Arms, Diplomacy, Europe Engulfed, etc.  This just left me cold.  I was lookng forward to my actions, not because I was dying to do something on the board, but because I wanted to do something other than rearrange my spaceships.  

There was little incentive for combat for several reasons (6 player game).  First, everyone was close enough to grab 5 planets for that objective.  Second, the special objective was too difficult for me to achieve (4 planets with the same tech advantage) so I had to write that off.  Upon reviewing others special objectives, they either dealt with some aspect of Mecatrol Rex, or taking some spread of tech systems.  Unfortunately, they were all worth the same 2 VPs, even though some were obviously more difficult than others.  Third, since everyone starts at relative parity to each other, their was very little incentive to attack as the forces were so even.  This is exacerbated by the fleet supply tokens as you are forced to load up on those to gain a massive advantage to win battles.  Fourth, PDS systems seem WAY too powerful, as they can wreak havoc on an invading force and make attacking systems prohibitively expensive (combined with the fleet supply limits, this effectively halts extended campaigns).  

I will give this another try, but several players in my group are beginning to feel the same way about this game after several plays of the game, so I do not feel that my rating will improve.

RATING: 7
I played this for the first time recently at WBC at the prodding of a friend. Oddly enough it fits my science fiction-esque imagination well for playing a  multi-player economic & combat space title. I'm not so sure about the victory conditions but there's a great deal of fun to be had playing with 5 (or more with the expansion) opponents just trying to squeeze out victory from the tabletop galaxy the hexagonal tiles form. Good points include the huge number of differences each player's empire can evolve in play and that the game doesn't immediately become imbalanced due to a 'technology' change. The rules aren't overbearing, though certainly not simple as many games can be. The play went smoothly with only a few of the hiccups of a player who wanted to spend more time than necessary analyzing his every possible choice to maximize results. 

My son has also played this game a number of times and it has been enough of a favorite to him for me to pick up a copy (plus the expansion) and get it ready for some family play.

RATING: 8
TI3 is a really well done game.  However, I'd rate it higher (maybe a 9 or 10) if it was about 25% shorter.  We played a 6 player game today, admittedly with 6 newbies, and the game took (after explanation) about 7 hours.  Assuming we could cut it to 5 hours if we played again, it is still about 1 to 1.5 hours too long.

We played with the 1 point ISC/open objective card variant.  I think that the 2 point ISC card would be a lot stuffier and also more random.  I think the variant is the way to play this one.

Better yet, play with the expanision!  TI3 is much better with the expansion than without it.

Also, limit your players to 4.  More players doesn't add anything except time to the game.  4 is perfect - all the roles get selected, and the board is balanced.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the "big one" at the moment, right now holding IMHO a place similar to that which Advanced Civilization and Diplomacy have held in gaming history. To me, a serious gamer isn't one who plays cutesy games like Munchkin or Killer Bunnies, nor is he/she one who plays Euro stuff like Puerto Rico. I'm a much more forgiving person as far as games are concerned, so I'll say that those games do indeed have a place: they're shorter and lighter, and sometimes that's what's called for. But if you have an afternoon that you want to dedicate to something epic, then this is what you choose. The Third Edition components are incredible, the game play deep and involved, the options almost too much to handle. Unlike some games, there is no "down time" while you wait for someone else to hurry the heck up; you have to be paying attention all the time. Now, many complain about the Imperial Strategy Card, or ISC. Whatever. It's necessary to move the game along, and there are a variety of optional "texts" for it, so that if it REALLY bothers you, you can change the rules a little and still play. There is no excuse in fact for not playing. Which brings me to another complaint people seem to have with it: that it's too long. Prohibitively long. Well it IS long, but I've sat through tedious games of Princes of Florence and Runebound which were themselves overlong and seemed to be even longer because the games are kind of boring, whereas a four-hour game of TI3 seems to go by very quickly. And I'd rather play one game of TI3, win or lose, than four games of Puerto Rico or - God forbid - Citadels.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Owned by Brett

RATING: 7.5
Rating is for TI with the Shattered Empire expansion. Knock off a point or point and a half for just the base game, as it has some issues with turtling and the Imperial strategy card.

But, with Shattered Empire, you have a new set of strat cards that don't include the imperial, the objectives tend to be much more aggressive in nature, artifacts add additional conflict to get another VP, advanced fighters have been reigned in, and the game just works a lot better. Then it is [b]the[/b] epic 4x game.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I totally understand why people would love this game. Once you have invested in this game, to understand the mechanism and player interplay, it's a very deep game with a lot of possibilities.
There are probably some limited optimal development paths for each race. But there are likely more than 1, so there are still options to adapt to your neighboring players and how the game develops in general.
Each race does facilitate a unique playstyle, which starters probably won't pick up on ('Humans' being able to stall a turn by 'breeding' for example).

I have one mayor point against this game: It takes such a long time to finish. A lot can be optimized to reduce play time (having individual people managing certain parts of the game, being experience with the game and the race you are playing, play to a lower point ceiling, etc), but even then it's still a long sit down. I already find it hard to find people willing to put down ~4hours to play a game of Arkham Horror, so I can't really seeing me getting this game to the table more than a few times per year! For TI3, that would probably suffer a worse fate :( 
Planning a whole day to gaming, I'd rather have some variety in what I play (There are multiple games I like better than TI3) or would rather do a RPG-day.

One fix I can think of is having the ability to stretch the game out of a couple of days.  But this requires you to make effort to preserve the game state, taking pictures, leaving the board for the next day (if people are sleeping over) or look for a digital playing field like using VASSAL perhaps.

In a shorter timespan, this game would have been around 7 or 8 for me. But in it's current state it's a 6 as I would only accept playing this game when in the right mood due to it's long playtime alone (matching the  rating description).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Pipe dream. Traded for another pipe dream, Antiquity.

RATING: 3
Let the Galaxy burn, and this game along with it. My first (and only) play of this game was long, long awaited. I wanted to see why this game was so legendary.

The answer? It's length, and only it's length. There are so few interesting decisions in this game that it sucks the fun out of an 8 hour session. Seriously, I could've made more interesting decisions in a 12 minute game of For Sale:

Tile Placing = 1 interesting decision
Turn Order = 2 interesting decisions
Building = 2 interesting decisions
Attacking = Surprisingly no interesting decisions
Technology = 1 interesting decisions
Voting = interesting, but it never mattered.

Utterly lame game. I'd much rather have played Nexus Ops. 3/10
(Above comments are based on a 10 hour, 8 player game. 5 pm - 3 a.m.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
Wow!  I can't believe it took me this long to play this game!  There is no doubt that the designer of this one really polished out their intent for it and thought of almost every nuance they could.  Granted, I've still only played this three times, I can see why it is so revered.  The game itself is the perfect marriage of theme and mechanics.  
Mechanically, the distribution of Command Counters on your player board is a wonderful abstracted representation of how to command an entire race.  Do you want to be able to micromanage the movement and productivity of your race? Allocate a CC to your Command Pool.  How about if you want to make sure your people have enough infrastructure to mass up larger armies?  Bump up your Fleet Size with a couple CCs.  How about making sure you're prepared to adapt your long term strategies based on your opponents?  That what your Strategy Allocation is for.
It's an elegant system that, while easy to implement, makes for some difficult choices.  The fact that the turn-to-turn tactical movement/management and long term strategic choices are so well tied together is impressive.
Now, I will admit to only having played a 'real' game twice. And only with 3 and 4 players at that.  We never even completed either game (PEOPLE AREN'T LYING WHEN THEY SAY THIS GAME TAKES 6 HOURS MIN!!!!!  SERIOUSLY!  BLOCK AN ENTIRE DAY OFF FOR IT!!!).  But my partner and I played (and finished) an unofficial 2-player variant (http://www.preeminent.org/steve/games/ti3/ti3demo/2-player/home/index.shtml) and it was abundantly clear how well designed TI3 actually is.  Even when adapting the rules that are so obviously intended for much larger asymmetric player counts, TI3 still felt like we had to think ahead and make important short and long term decisions.  We only had to house-rule one or two things in a 5 hour game.  And those we're never difficult, since it was easy to see how the original game designers intended those rules.
To me, that flexibility was exactly what makes this game amazing.  Yes, the rule book seems daunting.  And yes, you may initially be confused as to how something as seemingly simple as ship movement works.  But, once you've seen it play out once or twice, it becomes quite clear, and you will see how versatile those mechanics make the game.  The way you can use their restrictiveness against an opponent.  The way you can exploit a bad situation to your benefit.  
This brings me to my only two criticisms of the game (all "0.1" of them).  First, as eluded to in the previous paragraph, you really need to SEE the game played (at least once or two tactical turns).  The rules are actually well written, and maybe some people will instantly know what a tactical action would look like.  However, it wasn't till two of my TI3-virgin friends had seen our experienced friend play one or two rounds that that they really got the mechanics.  And, when you're playing a LONG game like this, one or two rounds is one or two hours!  That means that, for our first (never completed) game of TI3, we were flying blind for the first 2 hours (of 4).  And, given I had already spent about 1.5 hours explaining the rules, that's a LONG LONG TIME to convince someone that a game's system is worth learning.
I, myself, had watched a number of online tutorials which had additionally prepared me for the games concepts.  I would say that TI3 almost requires that kind of preliminary exposure to make it accessible.  With out it, I can see many people, who would otherwise enjoy it, being turned off.  That's a sad (but true) fact that diminishes my final rating of TI3.  
Combined with the oft-stated inability to organize even one gameplay session in a year (due to it's long play time), and you have a game that is worthy of a prefect 10 but won't ever have the frequency of play that warrants it.
But, enough of it's (small) detracting factors.  I would be remiss if I didn't laud over the games theme!  WOW!  What a fantastic job they've done here!  
At first (first glance at the box in the store) I was quick to dismiss this game.  I mean, it has a tiger person on the cover!  How cheesy can you get!  Sure the art was good, but it's a TIGER PERSON!  It was hard not to think [TI3] was some cobbled together Star Wars fan-fic, all wrapped up in an overly convoluted game system, whose only fame comes from the loud voices of teenage boys playing in their parents basement.
However, to my surprise, the game is plastered with rich theme - to the point that it is hard to think this is actually a game that came AFTER movies/books like Star Wars and Dune.  Normally, I'm not a huge fan of the 'Space Opera', but this game really embodies the nuance of the genre.  It takes all the romantic archetypes of hysterical civilizations (the ancient Romans or Persians) and all the symbolic people of mythologies (like Sirens), abstracts them into fantastic game mechanics, and writes page upon page of background that is both fresh and recognizable.  I found myself reading every race sheet's background and envisioning real people, struggling in real ways to achieve supremacy.
It's a real testament to how well a game is designed when, after reading a fictional history of a character, you can easily remember how that character works mechanically in the game.  Those themes are so well thought out, you really do want to play out your race as they were intended.
And that's before you even get to all the (completely optional and unobtrusive) flavor text that litters the planet, political, action and objective cards!  I found myself actually reading the flavor text of a proposed law out loud while playing.  It just felt like exactly what I needed to do to muster up the votes to pass or veto the motion.
And that's TI3's charm:  You come away from the game really loving how you shaped your race.  Really caring about who was "elected minister of internal security".  Really regretting the loss of the planet "Quan'Qua Kki Xito BLAH" (making fun of the names there), whose indigenous peoples were saved by your intellectual Universities of Jol-Nar only to be ousted by the violent Sardakk N'orr.  It's the epic (yes, this is one of the few appropriate uses of the word 'epic') story that a game weaves that makes this game wonderful.
TI3, I LOVE YOU! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Mind boggling design but it's just not fun enough to devote 8 hours of a precious, precious free Saturday to playing it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 4.6
CRIPES, this has plenty of exceptions.  I think the game components could use some better naming and identification marks to show to what they correlate.  I do like, however, that there are really disparate ways to approach victory, so you can attempt whatever angle seems appropriate for your situation.  This game offers some good options, with a lot of downtime; the game's pleasure-to-length ratio is way too low for my tastes.  Our first game (2 newbs & the owner of the game) took 6 hours with 3 players.  Yecch.  I was pleased to win sneakily, but could have played several games in that amount of time.  The second game, with everyone knowing how to play, took 5 hours.

The tech tree in the game is pretty silly for a 3- or 4-player game to 10 points; however, I imagine that in a 6-player and/or 14-point game, you can flex all the game's features.  ...but I wouldn't want to.  I spent probably 80% of those 5 hours of the second game actually watching a television show marathon, rather than engaged in the game.  Incidentally, I tied for the win on the second game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The definitive space and 4X experience, better than any civ game out there (with honorable exception of Through the Ages). Not so heavy as they say, only quite saturated. Mechanically it is definitely a blend of sort, nothing particularly unique, but clever - not much downtime even though the board can get busy. Action cards make it more of an experience than 100% strategy rewarding game. When combined with race that uses them efficiently action cards can turn the game into something I almost dislike. Beside that, no other flaws in my opinion. Considering time, you simply cannot have it that epic without time investment - same as in TTA. You can make great games like Exodus Proxima Centauri or Nations, mechanically much more flawless than TI3 and TTA... and somehow you wouldn't come even close to their greatness and epic feel. I leave to someone else to find out why is that so.

Very interesting design notes - wonderful insight into some aspects of modern gaming by one the most powerful persons in the business.

Among other inspirations, Asimov's Foundation is probably the most relevant.

RATING: 8

The game builds up nicely and even if you get annihilated in space, it is relatively easy to bounce back. What I did find clunky were the victory conditions with, in the expansion, the possibility to shoot far ahead if you manage to use a certain card allowing you to get multiple victory conditions at once. In addition, there is also a tendency where you simply build up the hugest fleet possible and using a bucket of dice approach clobber any enemy near the center of the board. Certainly a better game with 5 or 6 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My second purchase.

And the one that was most complicated for me to get :-).

Living in Serbia while being a gamer is not easy.

First of all, we are in Europe. Which means that our prices (compared to USA) are quite high. 

Then. We are in Europe, but not in European union. This means that importing (via post/dhl/ups/usps) anything from abroad which costs more than € 20.- is subject to customs of 20% + VAT of 18% + inspection fee of € 9.-. 

Buying board games in Serbia was also not easy (and still is not). We had like 1.5 (one and a half :-)) game stores that were selling games for € MSRP + some extra on top :-(.

Just do your math, this is not pleasant to your valet :-).

Anyhow, as I have a friend who is living in Vienna, and as my job takes me to Vienna on (at that time) monthly basis, it was matter of few emails and one visit to http://www.maelstromgames.co.uk/ and both: Twilight Imperium and Shattered Empires where on the way to my friends address in Vienna.

This was and still is my favorite game of epic proportions! I'm always willing to play it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The only problems I have with this game are that it doesn't hit the table often enough and I can't really justify buying the expansion right now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my new favorite game.  After only one play through we barely scratched the surface of the depth of this game.  With so many different ways to get he points you need to win, multiple races and of course a modular board that changes with every new game the replayability is off the chart.  Might be a little long for some, but in order to appreciated the multiple challenges and variances in outcomes you need that time.  Rules can be challenging to learn at first, but once you get rolling the game flows smoothly and seamlessly.  If you are into epic games but haven't tried this one it needs to be on your list.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Looks great, plays great - just wish I had more opportunities to play, as the game is quite long and you need many players.

There is no question you get an epic feel from this. But has the usual multiplayer pitfalls, and takes an awful long time without much action.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
1/22/09 -- As is, without modifying the strategy cards, this game is pretty lame.  What's funner than earning 1/5th of the VPs you need to win simply by going first in a turn?  Almost everything.  And the irrelevant political cards/phase seemed like a nostalgic vestige from a previous edition that no longer had a place in this "euroized" update.  Some good ideas, but a poor execution that was only later saved by a $50 expansion.

12/13/05 - After 2 plays, I couldn't figure out if this game was crappy or good.  The revisions that were put into the game from the previous edition dramatically decreased the play time, but I'm not sure if it was for the better or not.  I ultimately sold it for lack of regular opponents, but I think I'll always wonder if that was the right decision.  I'd play it again in a heartbeat if someone else were to bring it to the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Drool
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A good space empire game with war, diplomacy and economic elements.

Lots of tension and plenty of options. The biggest problem is that what's important isn't readily visible - you need to play this game multiple times to really get a feel of how it works together.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The internet seems to love this game, and the ideas in this game make it seem really fun, but every time I've played has been boring, not engaging, and just a chore. Too much going on that ultimately ends up resolving itself in random dice rolls. No narrative has really developed in any game I've played. It's not the people I'm playing with either! They really enjoy thematic games and can pull a story out of thin air! They love RPG's, and working together to make a game an experience! But this game doesn't support that, it tells you you're a space virus that gives you a neat little ability, but mostly you play the same as everyone else and you've spent 8 hours pushing ships around on a board. I wish the galactic council was actually the focus of this game! It's the one redeeming factor, and I wish it played a bigger role! Instead it's just another option to let the player in the lead start winning more.

I've said a lot about this game because I *want* it to be good. I *want* it to be Cosmic Encounter with an actual map and real diplomacy and a real story. But it fails at just about everything it does in practice, which is disappointing. Don't at me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
This game has loads going on, but each rule is relatively simple.  TI3 is one of my favorites, but the length of play and the real estate needed to set it up means it doesn't hit the table nearly as much as I'd like on games days.

Rating dropped a little bit for Runewars giving the same feel in an infinitely more playable package and length.
